Description: FLINT REGISTRY (FR) 2022-2027 - THIS PROPOSAL AIMS TO CONTINUE SUPPORTING THE FLINT REGISTRY (FR), A DESIGNATED PUBLIC HEALTH AUTHORITY THAT IS ADDRESSING THE PUBLIC HEALTH EMERGENCY CREATED WHEN ~100,000 RESIDENTS OF FLINT, MICHIGAN, WERE EXPOSED TO LEAD IN DRINKING WATER FROM 4/25/2014 TO 10/15/2015 (KNOWN AS THE FLINT WATER CRISIS). THE FR ADDRESSES THE CRITICAL NEED TO IDENTIFY EXPOSED INDIVIDUALS FOR LONG-TERM SURVEILLANCE AND SUPPORT, AND TO DETERMINE THE NEURODEVELOPMENTAL, MEDICAL, AND SOCIOECONOMIC IMPACT OF THE CRISIS. WITH WIDESPREAD COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIP, THE FR HAS BUILT A FULLY OPERATIONAL PUBLIC HEALTH INFRASTRUCTURE THAT HAS ENROLLED ALMOST 20,000 INDIVIDUALS AND MADE MORE THAN 25,000 CONNECTIONS TO PUBLIC HEALTH PROMOTING RESOURCES. BY CONNECTING PARTICIPANTS TO A COMMUNITY NETWORK OF SERVICE PROVIDERS WITH PROGRAMS DESIGNED TO IMPROVE HEALTH AND DEVELOPMENT, AS WELL AS BY REDUCING ONGOING LEAD EXPOSURES, THE FR IS ALREADY REDUCING HEALTH DISPARITIES. THE FR CONTINUES TO ADDRESS THE ONGOING PUBLIC HEALTH IMPACT OF THE WATER CRISIS BY MAINTAINING THE FR COHORT FOR LONG-TERM SURVEILLANCE AND PARTICIPANT SUPPORT AND BY CONTINUING TO RECRUIT AND ENROLL ADDITIONAL ELIGIBLE PARTICIPANTS. LEVERAGING THE FR'S CURRENTLY BUILT INFRASTRUCTURE, WE WILL MAINTAIN AND EXPAND THE FR TO ACCOMPLISH THE FOLLOWING AIMS: 1) CONTINUE ACTIVE AND TARGETED MARKETING AND OUTREACH, WITH ONGOING LEAD ELIMINATION TRAINING AND PROGRAMMING; 2) IDENTIFY AND RECRUIT HIGH-RISK INDIVIDUALS; 3) SURVEY THOSE ENROLLED IN THE REGISTRY TO MEASURE REGISTRANTS' EXPOSURE, HEALTH, DEVELOPMENTAL MILESTONES, AND SERVICE UTILIZATION AND REFER REGISTRANTS TO SERVICES TO REDUCE OR CONTROL LEAD EXPOSURE EFFECT; 4) MAINTAIN, SURVEY, AND REFER COHORT OF ENROLLED PARTICIPANTS; AND 5) EVALUATE AND DISSEMINATE FINDINGS AND SHARE BEST PRACTICES.

LPP, CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN - LEAD IS A HIGHLY TOXIC METAL THAT EXERTS IRREVERSIBLE EFFECTS ON NEARLY EVERY ORGAN SYSTEM. CHILDREN UNDER THE AGE OF SIX YEARS ARE ESPECIALLY AT RISK. LEAD EXPOSURE CAN CAUSE NEUROLOGICAL DAMAGE AND IS LINKED TO DEVELOPMENTAL DELAYS, LEARNING DISABILITIES, MEMORY LOSS, HEARING PROBLEMS, ATTENTION DEFICITS, AND HYPERACTIVITY. SINCE THE 1970S, EXTENSIVE PUBLIC POLICY AIMED AT REDUCING CHILD BLLS HAVE BEEN ENACTED, THE MOST NOTABLE BEING THE BAN OF LEAD-BASED PAINTS AND REMOVAL OF LEAD FROM GASOLINE.  STILL, PROMINENT SOURCES FOR LEAD EXPOSURE ARE STILL ACCESSIBLE, WITH SOME POPULATIONS AND GEOGRAPHIC AREAS AT A DISPROPORTIONATELY HIGH RISK. ARIZONA HAS A NUMBER OF REGIONALLY-SPECIFIC RISK FACTORS THAT HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED, INCLUDING LIVING IN PROXIMITY TO THE MEXICO-ARIZONA BORDER, MINING, AND RECENT IMMIGRATION STATUS. OTHER LEAD EXPOSURE SOURCES IDENTIFIED IN EBLL CASES IN ARIZONA INCLUDE CERAMIC POTTERY, MEXICAN CANDY, TRADITIONAL SPICES, FOLK MEDICINES, AND PARENTAL HOBBIES AND OCCUPATIONS. ON AVERAGE, 400 UNIQUE CHILDREN HAVE ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS EVERY YEAR.ARIZONA HAS LOW SCREENING RATES ACROSS THE STATE; ARIZONA ESTIMATED THAT 27.1% OF AT-RISK CHILDREN RECEIVED A BLOOD LEAD TEST AT 12 MONTHS OF AGE IN 2019. THERE IS ALSO A CONTINUED NEED TO IMPROVE KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN IN ARIZONA BECAUSE CHILDREN ARE STILL LEAD EXPOSED EVERY YEAR. SERVICES ARE NEEDED TO ENSURE LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN RECEIVE PROPER FOLLOW-UP AND LEAD SOURCES ARE IDENTIFIED AND REMOVED IN A TIMELY MANNER TO PREVENT DETRIMENTAL HEALTH EFFECTS.THE CDC-RFA-EH2102 FUNDING WILL BE USED TO ADDRESS THREE MAJOR STRATEGIES:1) ENSURE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING BY CONDUCTING OUTREACH WITH HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS AND FAMILIES TO ENSURE BLOOD LEAD TESTING OF AT-RISK CHILDREN. A LEAD ADVISORY COMMITTEE WILL ALSO BE ESTABLISHED WHICH WILL BE COMPRISED OF DIFFERENT STAKEHOLDERS WHICH WILL FUNCTION TO MAKE STATEWIDE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR BLOOD LEAD TEST ING BASED ON LOCAL DATA 2) STRENGTHEN SURVEILLANCE THROUGH THE USE OF ARIZONA?S BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM, MEDSIS BY ENSURING QUALITY, TIMELY, AND COMPLETE REPORTING FROM LABORATORIES AND HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS AND REPORTING TO THE CDC. 3) IMPROVE LINKAGES OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES BY MAINTAINING COMMUNICATIONS WITH REFERRAL AGENCIES AND ENSURING EFFECTIVE AND EFFICIENT COORDINATION OF CARE.CLPPP WILL EVALUATE THE ABILITY OF IMPLEMENTING THESE ACTIVITIES AND AFFECTING THE SHORT-TERM OUTCOMES IN THE DESIRED DIRECTION OF CHANGE: 1) IMPROVED BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING RATES FOR CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE AT RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE 2) IMPROVED USE OF SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM DATA TO CAPTURE MISSING DATA ON CHILD DEMOGRAPHIC AND FOLLOW-UP INFORMATION 3) IMPROVED RATES OF CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE WITH BLOOD LEAD LEVELS GREATER THAN OR EQUAL TO THE CDC BLOOD LEAD REFERENCE VALUE WHO ARE LINKED TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES, AND 4) DECREASED DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BY RACE/ETHNICITY AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS.

HOUSTON CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM(HCLPPP) - THE HOUSTON HEALTH DEPARTMENT (HHD) IS APPLYING FOR FUNDING FROM THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION (CDC) UNDER THE FUNDING OPPORTUNITY ANNOUNCEMENT CDC-RFA-EH21-2102, ?CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD? FOR SUPPORT ACROSS THE JURISDICTION OF HOUSTON, TEXAS FOR A FIVE-YEAR PERIOD, BEGINNING SEPTEMBER 30TH, 2021. THE HHD PROVIDES TRADITIONAL PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICES AND SEEKS TO USE INNOVATIVE METHODS TO MEET THE COMMUNITY?S PRESENT AND FUTURE NEEDS. THE HHD?S MISSION IS TO WORK IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE COMMUNITY TO PROMOTE AND PROTECT THE HEALTH AND SOCIAL WELL-BEING OF ALL HOUSTONIANS. THE HHD IS NOW THE FIRST HEALTH DEPARTMENT IN TEXAS AND THE SECOND IN A LARGE U.S. CITY TO EARN NATIONAL ACCREDITATION. THE HHD IS COMMITTED TO THE HEALTHY PEOPLE 2030 LEAD-RELATED GOALS OF REDUCING: (1) EXPOSURE TO LEAD, AND (2) BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN AGES 1-5 YEARS.IF AWARDED, THE FUNDING WILL SUPPORT THE HHD?S HOUSTON CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM?S (HCLPPP) ACTIVITIES TO DEVELOP STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS AND POLICIES TO IMPLEMENT TARGETED POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS AIMED AT PRIMARY PREVENTION OF LEAD EXPOSURE WITH A FOCUS ON COMMUNITY-BASED APPROACHES FOR LEAD HAZARD ELIMINATION. THE PROGRAMMATIC OUTCOMES INCLUDE: (1) IMPROVED POLICIES FOR TARGETED COMMUNITY-BASED APPROACHES AIMED AT PRIMARY PREVENTION OF LEAD EXPOSURE IN CHILDREN, (2) INCREASED BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, (3) DECREASED LEAD HAZARDS IN HOUSING OCCUPIED BY VULNERABLE POPULATIONS (E.G., CHILDREN), AND (4) DECREASED NON-PAINT SOURCES OF LEAD EXPOSURE IN TARGETED COMMUNITIES. HCLPPP, IN COLLABORATION WITH CURRENT AND FUTURE STRATEGIC PARTNERS, WILL DEVELOP DETAILED POLICY DESIGN/IMPLEMENTATION AND EDUCATION PLANS. HCLPPP WILL ALSO CONTINUE TO PROVIDE EDUCATION AND OUTREACH, WITH EXPANSION FOCUSING ON INNOVATIVE PARTNERSHIPS/COLLABORATIONS AND VULNERABLE POPULATIONS, INCLUDING:1.HOUSING-RELATED LEAD SOURCE AWARENESS AND HAZARD REMOVAL,2.NO N-HOUSING/NON-TRADITIONAL LEAD SOURCE AWARENESS (E.G., SPICES, POTTERY),3.REFUGEE AND RECENT IMMIGRANT POPULATIONS,4.MEDICAID POPULATIONS,5.VITAL STATISTICS, PREGNANT WOMEN AND THEIR MEDICAL PROVIDERS,6.HOME VISITATION PROGRAMS, 7.HUD LEAD-BASED PAINT HAZARD CONTROL PROGRAM AND HOUSTON?S CODE ENFORCEMENT, AND 8.HEAD STARTS, DAYCARES, CHILDCARE FACILITIES, AND LOCAL SCHOOL DISTRICTS.

EH21-2102: LEAD POISONING PREVENTION CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION - VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAMCDC-RFA-EH21-2102PROJECT ABSTRACTPURPOSETHE VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH?S CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PROGRAM (CLPPP) AIMS TO REDUCE LEAD HAZARDS AND REDUCE CHILDHOOD LEAD EXPOSURE AND POISONING, ESPECIALLY IN CHILDREN LESS THAN SIX YEARS OF AGE, IN VIRGINIA.THROUGH COLLABORATION WITH KEY INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL STAKEHOLDERS, ENHANCEMENTS TO LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, IMPROVEMENTS TO LEAD DATA SURVEILLANCE, AND INCREASED CASE MANAGEMENT EFFORTS, THE CLPPP WILL AIM TO ACCURATELY ASSESS BLOOD LEAD LEVELS AND ADDRESS THE EFFECTS OF LEAD EXPOSURE IN VIRGINIA?S CHILDREN. FURTHER, THROUGH ROBUST EDUCATION, OUTREACH, INCREASED LINKAGES BETWEEN LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN AND SERVICES, AND TARGETED POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS, THE PROGRAM AIMS TO IDENTIFY AND REDUCE LEAD SOURCES AND ULTIMATELY DECREASE HEALTH DISPARITIES RELATED TO BLOOD LEAD LEVELS.OUTCOMES TO ENHANCE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, THE CLPPP WILL INCREASE COLLABORATION BETWEEN DIVERSE STAKEHOLDERS AND ESTABLISH ROUTINE REVIEW OF VIRGINIA?S EXISTING BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING RECOMMENDATIONS. THE CLPPP WILL ALSO AIM TO INCREASE AWARENESS ABOUT BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING TO FAMILIES, PHYSICIANS, LABORATORIES, AND PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONALS.TO ENHANCE BLOOD LEAD DATA SURVEILLANCE IN VIRGINIA, THE CLPPP WILL INCREASE THE DATA COLLECTION CAPACITY OF ITS ELECTRONIC DISEASE SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM (VEDSS). THE CLPPP WILL ALSO ENHANCE LEAD DATA ANALYSIS BY INCREASING THE NUMBER OF PAPER LAB REPORTS SENT TO VEDSS AND INCREASING THE NUMBER OF PARTNERSHIPS FORMED BETWEEN THE CLPPP AND ORGANIZATIONS WITH COMPLEMENTARY DATA SYSTEMS. TO STRENGTHEN DATA DISSEMINATION, THE CLPPP WILL INCREASE ACCESS TO SURVEILLANCE DATA THROUGH ANNUAL REPORTS, DATA DASHBOARDS, AND DATA SHARING WITH INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL PARTNERS.TO IMPROVE LINKAGES BETWEEN LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN AND SERVICES, THE CLPPP WILL INCREASE AWARENESS (IN HEALTH DEP ARTMENT STAFF AND RELEVANT STAKEHOLDERS) ABOUT PROPER FOLLOW-UP PROTOCOLS FOR LEAD CASE INVESTIGATIONS. FURTHER, THE CLPPP WILL INCREASE COLLABORATIONS WITH ORGANIZATIONS THAT PROVIDE RECOMMENDED SERVICES FOR CHILDREN WITH LEAD EXPOSURE.TO STRENGTHEN TARGETED INTERVENTIONS, THE CLPPP WILL PARTNER WITH THE DEPARTMENT OF HOUSING AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT TO INCREASE AWARENESS ABOUT LEAD ABATEMENT SERVICES AND INCREASE REFERRALS FROM VDH TO THESE SERVICES. THE CLPPP WILL ALSO INCREASE EDUCATION ABOUT HOUSING-RELATED LEAD ISSUES FOR THE PUBLIC AND KEY STAKEHOLDERS. TO ENHANCE EACH OF THESE STRATEGIES, THE CLPPP WILL INCREASE PARTNERSHIPS WITH OTHER FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL AGENCIES AND STAKEHOLDERS WORKING IN LEAD POISONING PREVENTION.THESE ACTIVITIES WILL EXPAND UPON EXISTING LEAD POISONING PREVENTION EFFORTS IMPLEMENTED BY THE CLPPP SINCE ITS ESTABLISHMENT IN 2018 UNDER THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT CDC-RFA-EH18-1806.

CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM, KENTUCKY - THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE FUNDING FOR KENTUCKY?S HIGH-RISK REGIONS FOR CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING AND FURTHER BLOOD SURVEILLANCE ACROSS THE COMMONWEALTH. THROUGH THESE EFFORTS, THE DESIRED OUTCOMES WILL BE TO REDUCE THE NUMBER OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING CASES GREATER THAN OR EQUAL TO 5 ?G/DL FOR KENTUCKY CHILDREN UNDER 6 YEARS OF AGE. WHILE KENTUCKY HAS 120 COUNTIES AND 62 HEALTH DEPARTMENTS AND HEALTH DEPARTMENT DISTRICTS, THE KENTUCKY CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM HAS DECIDED TO FOCUS ITS EFFORTS ON THE TWO REGIONS WITH THE HIGHEST INCIDENCE OF BLOOD LEAD POISONING TO CHILDREN UNDER 6 YEARS OF AGE. THESE REGIONS INCLUDE LOUISVILLE METRO IN JEFFERSON COUNTY AND NORTHERN KENTUCKY INDEPENDENT HEALTH DISTRICT WHICH INCLUDES BOONE, KENTON, CAMPBELL AND GRANT COUNTIES. BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE IS AN IMPORTANT PART OF THIS PROJECT AND IS HANDLED THROUGH THE STATE DEPARTMENT FOR PUBLIC HEALTH. THIS DATA WILL BE SHARED WITH RELEVANT STAKEHOLDERS WHERE APPROPRIATE IN ORDER TO IMPROVE OUTREACH EFFORTS AND FURTHER THE OVERALL GOAL OF REDUCING INCIDENCE OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING. THIS DATA WILL ALSO BE PROVIDED TO THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION QUARTERLY.

THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT ACTIVITIES TO REDUCE LEAD EXPOSURE, INCLUDING SCREENING, DATA MANAGEMENT, SURVEILLANCE, REPORTING OF BLOOD LEAD DATA TO CDC, AND TARGETED POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS. - WISCONSIN (WI) HAS A STRONG LEAD POISONING PREVENTION SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM.  LABORATORIES AND HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS REPORT ALL LEAD TEST RESULTS TO WI DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH SERVICES (DHS) UNDER STATE LAW. THE WI CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (WCLPPP) HAS STRONG RELATIONS WITH HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS INCLUDING MEDICAID (MA), PUBLIC HEALTH AGENCIES INCLUDING WOMEN INFANTS AND CHILDREN (WIC) PROGRAMS AND HOUSING AGENCIES. WCLPPP UTILIZES DATA SO THAT ALL PARTIES CAN FOCUS ON DELIVERING TESTING, FOLLOW-UP AND PRIMARY PREVENTION SERVICES TO HIGH-RISK CHILDREN. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO STRENGTHEN WI?S WELL ESTABLISHED SURVEILLANCE PROGRAM. USING THE REFERENCE VALUE OF 5 MCG/DL HAS CREATED A STRONG CHALLENGE TO THE EXISTING INFRASTRUCTURE TO BETTER PROTECT MORE CHILDREN FROM LEAD HAZARDS.  LEAD POISONING RATES IN WI CONTINUE TO EXCEED THE NATIONAL AVERAGE.  IN 2019 ALONE, 3,111 (3.73% OF CHILDREN TESTED) WI CHILDREN UNDER 6 YEARS OF AGE HAD BLOOD LEAD LEVELS (BLLS) >5 ?G/DL. MA CHILDREN ARE 2.3 TIMES MORE LIKELY TO BE LEAD-POISONED THAN CHILDREN NOT ENROLLED IN MA; MA CHILDREN CONSISTENTLY MAKE UP MORE THAN 80% OF ALL CONFIRMED LEAD POISONED CHILDREN IN WI. IN 2020, WHILE 60% OF CHILDREN TESTED STATEWIDE WERE ENROLLED IN MA, 80.5% CHILDREN ENROLLED IN MA WERE LEAD POISONED. MINORITY POPULATIONS SHARE A GREATER BURDEN OF THE LEAD POISONING PROBLEM. BLACK CHILDREN HAVE THE HIGHEST RATE OF LEAD POISONING. ALTHOUGH BLACK CHILDREN MADE UP ONLY 18.5% OF CHILDREN TESTED, BLACK CHILDREN MADE UP 45.3% OF ALL LEAD-POISONED CHILDREN. WCLPPP HAS ON-LINE ACCESS IN REAL TIME TO THE WISCONSIN MA ELIGIBILITY DATABASE. THIS ALLOWS STAFF TO ROUTINELY CONDUCT DATA MATCHES AND ANALYZE MA TESTING ON AN ?AS NEEDED? BASIS.  WCLPPP PARTNERS WITH MA AND WIC PROGRAMS TO IDENTIFY INDIVIDUAL CHILDREN WHO NEED TESTING AND WILL CONTINUE WORKING TO RAISE THE PERCENT OF MA CHILDREN WHO RECEIVE THE REQUIRED TESTS.  WCLPPP CALCULATES SCREENING PREVALENCE RATES FOR INDIVIDUAL COMMUNITIES AND MAKES THESE DATA AVAILABLE. MILWAUKEE HAS THE HIGHEST BURDEN OF LEAD-POISONED CHILDREN (1, 210 OR 6.41% OF CHILDREN TESTED IN 2020) AND THEY WILL BE A KEY PARTNER IN THIS PROPOSAL. WCLPPP CONTRACTS WITH ALL LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (LHDS) TO PROVIDE STATE FUNDING FOR CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION ACTIVITIES AND TO ASSURE THAT LHDS PROVIDE SERVICES TO LEAD POISONED CHILDREN. THE WCLPPP SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM INCLUDES DEMOGRAPHIC, SOCIO-ECONOMIC AND HOUSING (CENSUS AND TAX ASSESSOR DATA) VARIABLES THAT ALLOW WCLPPP TO IDENTIFY MAJOR RISK FACTORS FOR LEAD POISONING, SUCH AS HOUSING AGE, FAMILY INCOME, CHILD AGE, RACE, ETHNICITY OR CENSUS TRACT.  WCLPPP PROGRAM STAFF HAS A SOPHISTICATED LEVEL OF ANALYTICAL AND GIS MAPPING CAPABILITY. THE STATEWIDE SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM CAPTURES ALL TEST RESULTS FOR CHILDREN TESTED, AS WELL AS NURSING AND ENVIRONMENTAL CASE MANAGEMENT INFORMATION.  STAFF CAN DISTINGUISH BETWEEN NEW AND ONGOING CASES, AND CAN PRESENT UNDUPLICATED COUNTS OF CHILDREN IN ALL DATA TABLES. WCLPPP USES GIS TO COMBINE BLOOD LEAD TEST RESULTS WITH CENSUS AND TAX ASSESSOR DATA TO MAP COMMUNITIES, AND TO IDENTIFY HIGH RISK HOUSES AND AREAS. WISCONSIN HAS RECEIVED STATE AND FEDERAL (CDC, EPA, OR HUD) FUNDS SINCE 1991 FOR STATEWIDE AND TARGETED CLPP AND HEALTHY HOMES WORK. IN FY21, PROGRAM GOALS WILL BE TO: (1) INCREASE THE NUMBERS OF CHILDREN UNDER AGE 6 WHO GET A BLOOD LEAD TEST; (2) IMPROVE DATA USAGE THAT LEADS TO A GREATER IDENTIFICATION OF GEOGRAPHIC AREAS AND POPULATIONS AT HIGH-RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE; (3) INCREASE THE ABILITY TO TARGET INTERVENTIONS (E.G., EDUCATION AND OUTREACH) TO HIGH-RISK GEOGRAPHIC AREAS AND POPULATIONS; (4) INCREASE THE KNOWLEDGE AND AWARENESS OF PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONALS, LEAD PREVENTION WORKFORCE, PARTNERS AND OTHER STAKEHOL

OHIO DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION GRANT - THE OHIO DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH?S OHIO HEALTHY HOMES AND LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM?S SUBMITS AN APPLICATION TO THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION?S CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN (FUNDING OPPORTUNITY #: CDC-RFA-EH21-2102). THE OHIO HEALTHY HOMES AND LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM IS APPLYING FOR THE MAXIMUM GRANT AWARD OF $850,000 FOR THE BUDGET PERIOD OF 9/30/2021 THROUGH 9/29/2022. WITH THIS FUNDING, THE OHIO DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH WILL CONTINUE A STATEWIDE SURVEILLANCE AND PRIMARY PREVENTION PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES TRACKING OF ALL BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN THE STATE, PROVIDE DIRECT SERVICES TO CHILDREN, COORDINATE CARE OF CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS, AND PREVENT CHILDREN FROM BEING POISONED IN THE FIRST PLACE. THE OHIO DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH APPLIES FOR THE MAXIMUM AMOUNT OF COMPONENT A ($500,000) AND THE MAXIMUM AMOUNT FOR COMPONENT B ($350,000) FOR THE TOTAL POSSIBLE AWARD FOR THE OHIO DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH IS $850,000.

CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION - COMPONENT A GHHLPPP HAS WORKED DILIGENTLY TO GET GEORGIA’S HIGH-RISK CHILDREN TESTED FOR LEAD POISONING WHILE ALSO IDENTIFYING THOSE WHO ARE LEAD POISONED, REQUIRING ENVIRONMENTAL FOLLOW UP AND CASE MANAGEMENT. IN 2014, GHHLPPP WAS AWARDED FUNDING FROM CDC TO MAINTAIN THE LEAD PROGRAM. SINCE THAT FUNDING WAS GRANTED, GHHLPPP HAS MADE GREAT STRIDES IN IMPROVING GEORGIA’S BLOOD LEAD SCREENING RATES. OVER THE PAST FIVE YEARS, THE STATEWIDE BLOOD LEAD SCREENING RATE HAS RISEN FROM 105,772 (2014) BLL TESTS TO 118,351 (2019.)  ADDITIONALLY, OVER 4,000 MORE CHILDREN LIVING IN GEORGIA’S HIGH-RISK AREAS WERE SCREENED FOR LEAD IN 2019 (54,082) THAN WERE SCREENED IN 2018 (50,057.) HOWEVER, THERE IS NEED FOR CONTINUED FUNDING TO IMPLEMENT STRATEGIES TO IMPROVE THE SCREENING RATES, PARTICULARLY IN THE HIGH-RISK AREAS.  GHHLPPP PROPOSES TO UTILIZE THIS FUNDING TO: MONITOR CHILDREN FOR LEAD EXPOSURE AND FOLLOW UP LEAD POISONED CHILDREN WITH CASE MANAGEMENT REFERRALS TO LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENTS FOR ENVIRONMENTAL INVESTIGATIONS. CONTINUE TO GUIDE AND ASSIST THE MEDICAL COMMUNITY TO PROMOTE LEAD SCREENINGS AND BETTER REPORTING, UTILIZING RISK EVALUATIONS AND TO EDUCATE CLINICIANS ON TRADITIONAL AND NONTRADITIONAL SOURCES OF LEAD POISONING. SUSTAIN A CONSORTIUM OF STRATEGIC PARTNERS TO ADDRESS BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE AND UPDATE SCREENING PLAN STRATEGIES. MAINTAIN AND ENHANCE THE GHHLPPP SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM TO BETTER PROCESS DATA AND REPORT IT TO THE CDC AS REQUIRED, INCLUDING ABLES DATA. CONTINUE TO ENGAGE ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE AND FAITH BASED PARTNERS TO EDUCATE THE COMMUNITY CONCERNING THE DANGERS OF LEAD POISONING AND IDENTIFYING VULNERABLE POPULATIONS THAT MAY SUFFER THE MOST FROM THESE HEALTH THREATENING SOURCES OF EXPOSURE. CONTINUE TO BUILD STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS ACROSS THE STATE, MAINTAIN THE GEORGIA HEALTHY HOMES COALITION AND THE LEAD ADVISORY COMMITTEE.  EMPLOY INDICATOR-BASED EVALUATION TECHNIQUES TO EVALUATE EVERY ASPECT OF THE PROGRAM TO INCREASE EFFICIENCY AND IMPLEMENT RESPONSIBLE  PLANNING AND UTILIZATION OF RESOURCES. COMPONENT B THE ATLANTA AREA IS A HIGH-RISK AREA FOR CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING DUE TO HOUSING FACTORS, DISPARAGED POPULATIONS AND HIGH REFUGEE AND IMMIGRANT POPULATIONS. GHHLPPP PROPOSES TO UTILIZE THIS FUNDING TO: ESTABLISH A PROGRAM TO ADDRESS THE LEGACY OF ENVIRONMENTAL LEAD IN ATLANTA (FULTON COUNTY) AND THE SIX SURROUNDING METRO COUNTIES. OUR PROGRAM, TALL, IS AN ACRONYM FOR TARGET ATLANTA’S LEAD LEGACY. TALL’S GOAL IS TO ENSURE LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND LEAD HAZARD ELIMINATION THROUGH COMMUNITY-BASED APPROACHES, POLICY DEVELOPMENT AND TARGETED STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS IN THE ATLANTA METRO REGION.  TALL’S OVER-ARCHING STRATEGIES INCLUDE: 1) DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT TARGETED POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS AND 2) FOCUS ON COMMUNITY-BASED PRIMARY PREVENTION APPROACHES FOR LEAD HAZARD ELIMINATION. THE TALL PROGRAM WILL CONDUCT ALL OF THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES: PROVIDE ENVIRONMENTAL RISK INVESTIGATIONS FOR ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD  (EBL) CHILDREN AND FOLLOW UP WITH CASE MANAGEMENT AND REFERRALS TO OTHER APPROPRIATE SERVICES, UTILIZE RISK EVALUATIONS AND TO EDUCATE CLINICIANS ON TRADITIONAL AND NONTRADITIONAL SOURCES OF LEAD POISONING, SUSTAIN A CONSORTIUM OF STRATEGIC PARTNERS TO ADDRESS PRIMARY PREVENTION PLAN STRATEGIES FOR ATLANTA’S COMMUNITIES, ASSURE THAT FOLLOW UP CARE AND INTERVENTIONS ARE PROVIDED FOR VULNERABLE POPULATIONS WHO SUFFER DISPROPORTIONATELY, ENGAGE ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE AND FAITH BASED PARTNERS, TRAIN COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKERS TO EDUCATE THE COMMUNITY CONCERNING THE DANGERS OF LEAD POISONING, COLLABORATE WITH THE CITY OF ATLANTA AND OTHER HOUSING DEPARTMENTS TO DEVELOP LEAD PAINT ELIMINATION POLICIES AND ENGAGE AND SUPPORT COMMUNITIES WITH STRATEGIES THAT ELIMINATE LEAD HAZARDS. THE TALL PROGRAM WILL PRODUCE OUTCOMES THAT WILL: DECREASE HAZARDS IN HOUSING, DECREASE LEAD EXPOSURE SOURCES AND IMPROVE LEAD POLICIES IN THE ATLANTA METRO AREA THAT FOCUS ON

IOWA CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM SUPPORT FOR COMPONENT A AND COMPONENT B ACTIVITIES RELATED TO BLOOD LEAD TESTING, SURVEILLANCE, LINKAGE TO SERVICES, AND TARGETED INTERVENTIONS. - COMPONENT A FUNDING WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT ONGOING STRATEGIES AND DEVELOPMENT OF NEW STRATEGIES AND POLICIES RELATED TO SECONDARY PREVENTION AND PRIMARY PREVENTION OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING THROUGH: (1) ENSURING BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, (2)ENHANCING BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE, AND (3) IMPROVING LINKAGES TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES. SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM DATA FROM IOWA?S HEALTHY HOMES AND LEAD POISONING SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM (HHLPSS) AND OTHER DATA SYSTEMS WILL BE ANALYZED TO IDENTIFY GEOGRAPHIC AREAS, AND POPULATIONS AT RISK FOR ELEVATED LEAD TO DEVELOP TARGETED INTERVENTIONS THAT ARE DATA-DRIVEN. DATA WILL BE SUBMITTED TO THE CDC AND RELEASED TO PARTNERS, STAKEHOLDERS, AND AGENCIES TO SUPPORT A COMPREHENSIVE NETWORK OF REFERRAL, CASE MANAGEMENT, FOLLOW-UP TESTING AND INTERVENTION SERVICES FOR CHILDREN IN IOWA.PROPOSED PROJECT OUTCOMES FROM THE STRATEGIES AND ACTIVITIES EMPLOYED WILL BE:? IMPROVING BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING RATES FOR CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE AT RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE (E.G., SCREENING/TESTING PENETRANCE AND THE INCIDENCE AND PREVALENCE OF CHILDREN WITH BLOOD LEAD LEVELS GREATER THAN OR EQUAL TO THE CDC BLOOD LEAD REFERENCE VALUE) AND OTHER IMPORTANT BLOOD LEAD LEVELS CATEGORIES.? IMPROVING THE USE OF SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM DATA TO CAPTURE MISSING DATA ON CHILD DEMOGRAPHIC AND FOLLOW-UP INFORMATION (E.G., ADDRESS, RACE/ETHNICITY, SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS, SMALL GEOGRAPHIC AREA [ZIP CODE OR CENSUS TRACT], REFERRALS TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES, COMPLETION OF SERVICES BY TYPE).? IMPROVING RATES OF CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE WHO MEET STATE CASE DEFINITIONS WHO ARE LINKED TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES (E.G. ENVIRONMENTAL INSPECTIONS, MEDICAL EVALUATIONS, NUTRITIONAL COUNSELING, DEVELOPMENTAL MILESTONES).WITH COMPONENT B FUNDING IOWA WILL SEEK TO DEVELOP A REGIONAL PLAN FOR IOWA?S RURAL COUNTIES AND CITIES ON HOW TO ACQUIRE FUNDING AND ADMINISTER A LEAD HAZARD REMEDIATION PROGRAM TO ADDRESS AGING HOUSE STOCK THROUGH COALITION BUI LDING AND ALLOCATION OF RESOURCES. THE REGIONAL PLAN FOR LEAD HAZARD ELIMINATION IN RURAL COUNTIES WILL FOCUS ON PRIMARY AND SECONDARY PREVENTION STRATEGIES THROUGH:? DEVELOPING TARGETED POPULATION BASED POLICY AND PROGRAM INTERVENTIONS? IDENTIFYING COMMUNITY-BASED STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS AND COLLABORATIONS? DEVELOPING COMMUNITY-BASED APPROACHES BASED ON THE SPECIFIC NEEDS OF COUNTIES/CITIES WITHIN A GEOGRAPHIC AREA OF THE STATE ? IDENTIFYING OUTREACH AND EDUCATIONAL STRATEGIES TO REACH TARGETED POPULATIONS AT-RISK AND GEOGRAPHIC AREAS WITH AGING HOUSING STOCK IN NEED OF FUNDING FOR LEAD HAZARD ELIMINATION.? LEVERAGING RESOURCES FROM FEDERAL, STATE AND LOCAL PROGRAMS, CHARITY, NONPROFIT OR FOR-PROFIT ENTITIES, OR INTERNAL AGENCY PROGRAMS.DURING THE PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE (YEAR 1) IOWA WILL SEEK TO ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING SHORT-TERM OUTCOMES? INCREASED COLLABORATION AND COORDINATION BETWEEN APPROPRIATE STAKEHOLDERS.? INCREASED AWARENESS OF PEDIATRIC HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS AND CLINICAL LABORATORIES OF STATE BLOOD LEAD TESTING RECOMMENDATIONS AND REPORTING REQUIREMENTS.? INCREASED LINKAGES BETWEEN COMPLEMENTARY DATA SYSTEMS (E.G., MEDICAID, IMMUNIZATION, ADULT BLOOD LEAD, VITAL STATISTICS).? INCREASED IDENTIFICATION OF GEOGRAPHIC AREAS AND POPULATIONS AT-RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE USING ENHANCED DATA LINKAGES.? INCREASED IDENTIFICATION, TRACKING, AND RECOMMENDED SERVICES FOR CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS.? INCREASED ABILITY FOR PUBLIC HEALTH AGENCIES, HEALTH CARE PROFESSIONALS, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS TO PROVIDE LINKAGES TO SERVICES AND REDUCE LOSS TO FOLLOW-UP.? IMPROVED POLICIES FOR TARGETED COMMUNITY- BASED APPROACHES AIMED AT PRIMARY PREVENTION OF LEAD EXPOSURE IN CHILDREN.

THE DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT?S DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS PROGRAM (DC CLPPP) - COMPONENT A THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA?S DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT?S (DOEE) DC CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS PROGRAM (DC CLPPP) WILL BUILD ON LONG-ESTABLISHED PARTNERSHIPS TO MEET THE NEEDS OF QUICKLY GROWING CHILD POPULATION AND AN AGING HOUSING STOCK. TO REDUCE THE OCCURRENCE AND IMPACT OF LEAD EXPOSURE AMONG CHILDREN BELOW SIX YEARS OF AGE,?DC CLPPP?WILL?IMPLEMENT AN?INTEGRATED, INTEROPERABLE BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE?AND REFERRAL?SYSTEM?ABLE TO?COMMUNICATE AND EXCHANGE DATA SECURELY ACROSS DIFFERENT SYSTEMS?TO IMPROVE?BLOOD LEAD SCREENING?AND REPORTING,?IDENTIFY?HIGH-RISK POPULATIONS, REDUCE BLOOD LEAD LEVEL DISPARITIES, AND ENSURE?EFFECTIVE FOLLOW-UP FOR CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS.?THE BENEFITS TO CHILDREN LESS THAN SIX YEARS OLD IN THE DISTRICT INCLUDE INCREASED BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, IMPROVED COLLECTION OF CHILD DEMOGRAPHIC AND FOLLOW-UP INFORMATION, IMPROVED RATES OF CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS LINKED TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES, AND DECREASED DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BY RACE/ETHNICITY AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS.? COMPONENT B THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA?S DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT?S (DOEE) DC CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS PROGRAM (DC CLPPP) WILL WORK TO REDUCE OR ELIMINATE PRIMARY SOURCES OF LEAD?FROM?CHILDREN?S?ENVIRONMENTS?TO?PROTECT CHILDREN EFFECTIVELY AND RELIABLY FROM?THE HARMFUL EFFECTS?OF LEAD?EXPOSURE.?DC CLPPP IDENTIFIES AND ELIMINATES LEAD?HAZARDS?AND ASSOCIATED?RACIAL/ETHNIC AND SOCIOECONOMIC DISPARITIES?IN CHILDHOOD LEAD EXPOSURE IN THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA?THROUGH?STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS,?POLICIES, AND?TARGETED, POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS.?OUTCOMES INCLUDE DECREASING LEAD HAZARDS ASSOCIATED WITH HOUSING, SUCH AS LEAD-CONTAMINATED PAINT, DUST, AND SOIL, AND OTHER?SOURCES OF LEAD EXPOSURE, SUCH AS CERAMIC WARE, TRADITIONAL HOME HEALTH REMEDIES, AND SPICES GROWN IN LEAD-CONTAMINATED SOIL.?IN THE LONG TERM, THESE EFFORTS WILL IMPROVE LEAD SURVEILLANCE AND REDUCE LEAD HAZARD RISKS, LEADING TO FEWER CHILDREN LESS THAN SIX YEARS OF AGE IN THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA BEING EXPOSED TO LEAD, LOWER OVERALL BLOOD LEAD LEVELS, AND REDUCED?DISPARITIES IN ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS.

NEVADA CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM - NEVADA HAS ONE OF THE FASTEST-GROWING AND MOST DEMOGRAPHICALLY DIVERSE POPULATIONS IN THE U.S., AND LARGE PROPORTIONS OF THIS POPULATION FACE HEALTH DISPARITIES BY RACE/ETHNICITY, SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS, AND GEOGRAPHIC LOCATION. A WIDE RANGE OF SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH PLAY A CRITICAL ROLE IN THE OUTCOMES OF VULNERABLE POPULATIONS; HOWEVER, HOUSING CONTINUES TO BE A PERSISTENT DETERMINANT THAT DISPROPORTIONALLY IMPACTS OUR LOW-INCOME COMMUNITIES, OFTEN HIGHLY POPULATED BY COMMUNITIES OF COLOR. HOUSING QUALITY CONCERNS IN NEVADA HAVE BEEN AND REMAIN A CONCERN.  NEARLY ONE IN FOUR HOMES IN THE STATE WERE BUILT BEFORE 1979, AND GIVEN THE VARIETY OF NON-TRADITIONAL SOURCES OF LEAD AND THE DIVERSITY OF THE STATE, THE STATE GRAPPLES WITH MORE THAN LEAD-BASED PAINT EXPOSURES. DESPITE THE RISK TO LEAD HAZARDS IN NEVADA, LESS THAN 4 PERCENT OF CHILDREN UNDER THE AGE OF SIX ARE TESTED FOR LEAD AND EVEN FEWER SINCE THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. IN 2017 THE UNLV SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH REVITALIZED AND EXPANDED THE CLARK COUNTY CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM INTO THE FIRST STATEWIDE NEVADA CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (NVCLPPP) BY IMPLEMENTING A FOUR-PRONGED APPROACH TO LEAD POISONING PREVENTION THAT ENGAGED HEALTH DISTRICTS, MEDICAL PROVIDERS, SERVICE PROVIDERS, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS ALL TOWARD THE GOAL OF STRENGTHENING TESTING, REPORTING, SURVEILLANCE, AND PREVENTION. DURING THIS TIME, WE HAVE EXPANDED OUR ADVISORY BOARD, PASSED LEGISLATIVE CHANGES TO IMPROVE REPORTING, IMPLEMENTED A NOVEL APPROACH TO ENGAGE PROVIDERS, INCREASED BLOOD LEAD TESTING, IMPROVED LINKAGES TO SERVICES, AND ENGAGED A DIVERSE SET OF STAKEHOLDERS IN LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND EDUCATION. DESPITE THESE SUCCESSES, THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC HAS HAMPERED PROGRESS ON ALL APPROACHES IMPLEMENTED AND HAS LEFT THE COMMUNITIES AT GREATEST RISK IN A MUCH MORE VULNERABLE POSITION. AS OUR STATE BEGINS TO MOVE INTO A PERIOD OF RECOVERY, IT IS MORE CRITICAL THAN EVER TO REENG AGE AND REVITALIZE PRIMARY AND SECONDARY LEAD PREVENTION APPROACHES. THE NVCLPPP TEAM IS SPEARHEADED BY AN EXPERIENCED TEAM OF PROFESSIONALS IN ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH, PUBLIC HEALTH, SOCIOLOGY, EPIDEMIOLOGY, AND BIOSTATISTICS TO EMPLOY LEAD PREVENTION, LEAD-HAZARD REDUCTION, SURVEILLANCE, AND EDUCATION AND OUTREACH. THROUGH THE USE OF COMMUNITY-ENGAGED APPROACHES, THE NVCLPPP WILL UTILIZE CDC FUNDS TO CONTINUE TO BUILD UPON THE EVIDENCE-BASED WORK CONDUCTED OVER THE PAST THREE YEARS. PRIMARY PREVENTION APPROACHES WILL CONTINUE TO USE A COMMUNITY-BASED APPROACH TO PREVENTION. WE ARE COMMITTED TO INTEGRATING COMMUNITY MEMBERS INTO DEVELOPING STRATEGIES THAT RESONATE AND ADDRESS THEIR CONCERNS. WE WILL CONTINUE TO USE NOVEL APPROACHES TO ENGAGE PROVIDERS, SUCH AS THE IMPLEMENTATION OF AN ACADEMIC DETAILING MODEL FOUND TO BE EFFECTIVE IN CREATING SUSTAINABLE PRACTICE CHANGES. STRENGTHENING AND LEVERAGING PARTNERSHIPS IS AT THE CORE OF OUR WORK; THUS, WE ENGAGE A DIVERSE GROUP OF SERVICE PROVIDERS WHO WORK WITH YOUNG CHILDREN AND THEIR FAMILIES TO EXPAND OUR REACH. LASTLY, WE UNDERSTAND THE ROLE STRUCTURES AND SYSTEMS PLAY IN HEALTH INEQUITIES; THEREFORE, WE ARE COMMITTED TO DEVELOPING STRATEGIC AND WELL-PRIORITIZED POLICY APPROACHES TO INFLUENCE POLICIES AND PRACTICES THAT HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO PROTECT THE HEALTH OF OUR FAMILIES FROM LEAD HAZARDS INTO THE LONG TERM. SECONDARY PREVENTION MEASURES WILL INCLUDE IMPLEMENTING STRATEGIES IN COLLABORATION WITH STATE AND HEALTH DISTRICTS TO IMPROVE LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, ESPECIALLY FOR CHILDREN AT HIGHER RISK OF EXPOSURE, SUCH AS THOSE ON MEDICAID, RACIAL MINORITIES, AND IMMIGRANT/REFUGEE FAMILIES. FINALLY, IMPROVE LINKAGES OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES. THE NVCLPPP IS DEDICATED TO REDUCING HEALTH DISPARITIES AMONG THE MOST VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES, PARTICULARLY YOUNG CHILDREN FROM LOW-INCOME AND MINORITY BACKGROUNDS WHO BEAR A DISPROPORTIONATE BURDEN TO LEAD EXPOSURE.

LEAD POISONING PREVENTION-CHILDHOOD LEAD PREVENTION - MISSOURI?S CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (CLPPP) PROVIDES SERVICES TO CHILDREN THROUGHOUT THE STATE.  SURVEILLANCE DATA COLLECTED OVER THE YEARS HAS SHOWN THAT LOW-INCOME AND MINORITY CHILDREN BEAR A DISPROPORTIONATE BURDEN OF ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS.   MISSOURI BASES THE LEVEL OF INTERACTION AND SERVICES PROVIDED TO CHILDREN AND THEIR FAMILIES ON THE CHILD?S BLOOD LEAD LEVEL.  SERVICES ARE EQUALLY DISTRIBUTED WITHIN OUR JURISDICTION WITHOUT INCLUSION OF OTHER IDENTIFIERS SUCH AS RACE, ETHNICITY, OR SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS; HOWEVER, SURVEILLANCE DATA COLLECTED AND ANALYZED CAN PROVIDE ADVANTAGES IN THE FIGHT TO REDUCE BLOOD LEAD LEVELS THROUGHOUT THE STATE.  THE DATA MAY ASSIST IN IDENTIFYING AN AREA OR COMMUNITIES WITH CHILDREN AND PREGNANT WOMEN THAT MAY BE CONSIDERED HIGH RISK DUE TO A CONCENTRATION OF OLDER HOUSING STOCK OR A DECLINE IN PROPERTY MAINTENANCE AND/OR MOVEMENT OF POPULATIONS DUE TO SOCIOECONOMIC IMPACTS IN THE AREA.  IDENTIFICATION OF INFLUENCING FACTORS THAT CONTRIBUTE TO BLOOD LEAD LEVEL ELEVATIONS NOT ONLY ALLOWS STAFF TO ADDRESS THESE FACTORS DURING CASE MANAGEMENT, RISK ASSESSMENTS, AND COMMUNITY EVENTS, BUT ALSO ALLOWS STAFF TO BEGIN A MORE FOCUSED PREVENTION CAMPAIGN TO SPECIFICALLY TARGET AT-RISK CHILDREN AND VULNERABLE POPULATION GROUPS.  MISSOURI HAS FACTORS THAT ARE UNIQUE TO THE STATE THAT CONTRIBUTE TO ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS AND CONTINUES TO IDENTIFY NEW POPULATIONS AT RISK.  POPULATIONS WILL BE IDENTIFIED WHERE POSSIBLE TARGETED TESTING, OUTREACH, AND EDUCATION MAY BE BENEFICIAL, SUCH AS, FOR CHILDREN WITH A CONFIRMED VENOUS BLOOD LEAD LEVEL OF 5 ?G/DL OR GREATER, ETHNIC AND OCCUPATIONAL POPULATIONS, AND PREGNANT WOMEN WITHIN THE STATE.  DHSS CONSTANTLY LOOKS FOR AVENUES TO LINK THOSE POPULATIONS WITH APPROPRIATE RESOURCES OR SERVICES AND ADDRESS THE ISSUES BEYOND WHAT IS CURRENTLY BEING PROVIDED BY CLPPP.  THE CLPPP WILL ALSO COLLABORATE WITH INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL STAKEHOLDERS TO ENSURE EFFICIENT  AND EFFECTIVE COORDINATION ON LEAD EDUCATION AND OUTREACH AT THE EARLIEST OPPORTUNITIES AND TO EMPHASIZE PREVENTION.PARTICIPATION IN THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW MISSOURI TO STRENGTHEN THE EXISTING CLPPP THROUGH THE USE OF SURVEILLANCE DATA TO IDENTIFY, PRIORITIZE, AND PROVIDE OR LINK APPROPRIATE INTERVENTIONS TO TARGET POPULATIONS, INCLUDING LOW INCOME/MINORITY CHILDREN WHO BEAR A DISPROPORTIONATE BURDEN.  MISSOURI CLPPP WILL WORK TO DECREASE THE PREVALENCE OF CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS INCLUDING VULNERABLE POPULATIONS WITH HEALTH EDUCATION TARGETED THROUGH THE APPROPRIATE USE OF SURVEILLANCE DATA.WHILE MISSOURI?S CHILDHOOD BLOOD LEAD POISONING INCIDENT RATE HAS MIRRORED THE NATIONAL DECLINE, EFFORTS TO INCREASE STATEWIDE BLOOD LEAD TESTING VIA PROGRAMMATIC PROCEDURAL CHANGES INCLUDING STATE RULES REVIEW AND UPDATE, TO IMPROVE HEALTH AND LEAD SAFETY EDUCATION, AND TO IMPROVE FOLLOW-UP TESTING AMONG POTENTIALLY AT-RISK POPULATIONS HAS BEEN HAMPERED BY COVID-19.  THOSE IDENTIFIED INCLUDE AREAS OF HIGH POVERTY AND PRE-1978 HOUSING, AND INDIVIDUALS PREVIOUSLY TESTING ELEVATED WITHOUT CONFIRMATION; EFFORTS ARE ALSO UNDERWAY TO INCREASE HEALTH AND SAFETY EDUCATION FOR AREAS IN AND SURROUNDING THE STATE?S CURRENT AND HISTORICAL LEAD MINING INDUSTRY, AS WELL AS, AREAS OF LEAD INTENSIVE OCCUPATIONS LIKE BATTERY RE-MANUFACTURING.THE CLPPP WORKS IN CLOSE PARTNERSHIP WITH THE ENVIRONMENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH TRACKING (EPHT), MATERNAL CHILD HEALTH (MCH), WOMEN, INFANT, CHILD (WIC), ADULT BLOOD LEAD EPIDEMIOLOGY AND SURVEILLANCE (ABLES), AND LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH AGENCIES (LPHAS) IN ALL FACETS OF THE PROGRAM.

THE OKLAHOMA CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM HAS IDENTIFIED THREE GOALS TO ENSURE PROJECT SUCCESS INCLUDING ENHANCED SURVEILLANCE, IMPROVED LINKAGE TO CARE, AND INCREASED TESTING. - THE OKLAHOMA CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (OCLPPP) AT THE OKLAHOMA STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH (OSDH) IS MANDATED BY STATE STATUTE O.S. 63-1-114.1 AND ANNUALLY MONITORS APPROXIMATELY 50,000 CHILDREN BETWEEN 6 AND 72 MONTHS OF AGE FOR LEAD POISONING. IN ADDITION TO SURVEILLANCE ACTIVITIES, THE PROGRAM PROVIDES FOLLOW-UP MANAGEMENT, ENVIRONMENTAL INVESTIGATIONS, EDUCATION, OUTREACH, AND OTHER PRIMARY PREVENTION ACTIVITIES. THIS PROPOSAL FOCUSES ON IMPLEMENTING AND SUPPORTING ACTIVITIES TO REDUCE LEAD EXPOSURE AND LEAD POISONING. THESE ACTIVITIES WILL CONCENTRATE ON INCREASING COMPLIANCE WITH THE STATE?S CURRENT BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING PLAN AS WELL AS ENHANCING THE CURRENT SURVEILLANCE AND CASE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR THE PURPOSES OF RECORDING MORE COMPLETE DEMOGRAPHIC INFORMATION, INCLUDING RACIAL AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS. THE FOCUS OF THESE ACTIVITIES WILL ALSO BE TO IMPROVE THE IDENTIFICATION OF LEAD EXPOSED CHILDREN IN ORDER TO PROVIDE ENHANCED LINKAGE TO SERVICES AND POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS. THE COMPREHENSIVE GOAL OF WHICH IS TO ELIMINATE HEALTH DISPARITIES IN LEAD EXPOSURE RISK BASED ON SOCIAL, DEMOGRAPHIC, AND GEOGRAPHIC FACTORS AND TO ELIMINATE CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING IN OKLAHOMA. THE PROGRAM HAS IDENTIFIED THREE GOALS TO ENSURE PROJECT SUCCESS: 1. INCREASED TESTING AND REPORTING  2. ENHANCED BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE  3. IMPROVED LINKAGES OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE COLLABORATION WITH APPROPRIATE STAKEHOLDERS IN THE COMMUNITY TO INCREASE AWARENESS OF OKLAHOMA?S UNIVERSAL LEAD SCREENING RECOMMENDATIONS AND MANDATORY REPORTING OF LEAD RESULTS; IMPROVE THE RATES OF CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS WHO RECEIVE APPROPRIATE SERVICES; AND IMPROVE THE USE OF THE CURRENT SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM TO CAPTURE MISSING DEMOGRAPHIC DATA FOR IMPROVED IDENTIFICATION OF CHILDREN LIVING IN ENVIRONMENTS AT HIGH RISK FOR EXPOSURE. THESE GOALS ARE IN KEEPING WI TH THE OKLAHOMA STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH?S MISSION TO PROTECT AND PROMOTE HEALTH, TO PREVENT DISEASE AND INJURY, AND TO CULTIVATE CONDITIONS BY WHICH OKLAHOMANS CAN BE HEALTHY.   SHORT-TERM OUTCOMES INCLUDE: INCREASED COLLABORATION AND AWARENESS OF LEAD EXPOSURE CONCERNS FOR APPROPRIATE STAKEHOLDERS, INCREASED LINKAGES BETWEEN DATA SYSTEMS AND IDENTIFICATION OF GEOGRAPHIC AREAS OR POPULATIONS AT RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE THROUGH ENHANCED DATA LINKAGES, INCREASED REFERRALS TO OUTSIDE AGENCIES FOR CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS TO REDUCE LOSS TO FOLLOW-UP AND IMPROVE TRACKING. INTERMEDIATE OUTCOMES INCLUDE: IMPROVED BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING RATES IN OKLAHOMA FOR CHILDREN UNDER SIX YEARS OF AGE, IMPROVED USE OF THE CURRENT SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM TO CAPTURE MISSING DEMOGRAPHIC DATA, AND AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN WHO RECEIVE REFERRALS TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES BASED ON ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS. LONG-TERM OUTCOMES INCLUDE: AN OVERALL DECREASE IN HEALTH DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BY RACE/ETHNICITY AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS, DECREASED ADVERSE HEALTH EFFECTS FOR CHILDREN DUE TO LEAD EXPOSURE, DECREASED SOCIETAL COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH LEAD EXPOSURE SUCH AS HEALTHCARE, SPECIAL EDUCATION, AND THE CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEM.

CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN - THE COLORADO DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENT (CDPHE) IS APPLYING FORCOOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FUNDING TO SUPPORT CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION IN THE STATE.THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE COLORADO CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM(CCLPPP) ARE INTENDED TO ACCOMPLISH OVERARCHING PROGRAM STRATEGIES TO ENSURE BLOOD LEADTESTING AND REPORTING, ENHANCE BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE, AND IMPROVE LINKAGES OF LEAD-EXPOSEDCHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES.THIS 5-YEAR COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL FUND CDPHE TO COMPLETE ALL CDC-DIRECTED ACTIVITIES.THE PURPOSE OF THESE ACTIVITIES IS TO BUILD SURVEILLANCE CAPACITY TO AID IN PREVENTING, ANDULTIMATELY, ELIMINATING CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING AS A MAJOR PUBLIC HEALTH PROBLEM INCOLORADO. THIS PROPOSAL GOES BEYOND HISTORICAL SURVEILLANCE EFFORTS AND PROPOSES TO USE NEWAND EXISTING PARTNERSHIPS AND DATA TO IDENTIFY AT-RISK GEOGRAPHIES AND POPULATIONS, COORDINATESTATEWIDE SCREENING AND TESTING, AND ENHANCE CAPACITY TO SUPPORT LINKAGES TO SERVICES WITH ANEW CARE COORDINATOR POSITION.

CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN - THOUGH THE PREVALENCE OF ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS HAS DECREASED DRAMATICALLY IN THE UNITED STATES AND TEXAS SINCE THE 1970S, NO SAFE BLOOD LEAD LEVEL IN CHILDREN HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED. EVEN LOW LEVELS OF LEAD IN THE BLOOD AFFECT A CHILD'S IQ, ABILITY TO PAY ATTENTION, AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. AS OF 2003, TEXAS STATUTE (TEXAS HEALTH AND SAFETY CODE CHAPTER 88) AND ADMINISTRATIVE RULE (TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE, TITLE 25, PART 1, CHAPTER 37, SUBCHAPTER Q) MANDATE THE REPORTING OF ALL BLOOD LEAD TESTS FOR PERSONS UNDER AGE 15 YEARS BY PHYSICIANS, LABORATORIES, HOSPITALS, CLINICS, AND OTHER HEALTHCARE FACILITIES TO THE TEXAS DEPARTMENT OF STATE HEALTH SERVICES (DSHS). THIS LAW ALSO MANDATES DSHS ADOPT RULES FOR CONDUCTING ENVIRONMENTAL LEAD INVESTIGATIONS AND SUPPORT CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION.PROBLEM STATEMENTGEOGRAPHIC AND SOCIOECONOMIC DISPARITIES AND EXPOSURE TO LEAD IS AN ONGOING PROBLEM IN TEXAS. A RECENT TEXAS DEMOGRAPHIC CENTER REPORT SHOWS THAT TEXAS' MOST VULNERABLE POPULATIONS ARE BLACK AND HISPANIC RENTERS, WITH LOW-INCOME DISPARITIES WITH CHILDREN PRESENT, PARTICULARLY THOSE HEADED BY SINGLE MOTHERS WHO RECEIVED PUBLIC ASSISTANCE. LEAD-BASED PAINT AND LEAD DUST ARE THE MOST PERVASIVE SOURCES OF EXPOSURE TO CHILDREN. HOMES AND BUILDINGS BUILT BEFORE 1978 ARE LIKELY TO CONTAIN SOME LEAD-BASED PAINT. CHILDREN UNDER THE AGE OF 6 ARE MOST VULNERABLE TO LEAD. IN 2017, DSHS CERTIFIED LEAD RISK ASSESSORS FOUND AT LEAST ONE SAMPLE WITH DETECTABLE LEAD IN 79% OF ENVIRONMENTAL LEAD INVESTIGATIONS CONDUCTED IN TEXAS. UNDERSTANDING TEXAS' VULNERABLE POPULATIONS AND THE FACTORS THAT PUT CHILDREN AT GREATER RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE WILL AID IN BETTER TARGETING PREVENTION EFFORTS TO IMPROVE HEALTH EQUITY.  PURPOSETHE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AND EXPAND EXISTING STATEWIDE STRATEGIES RELATED TO PRIMARY AND SECONDARY PREVENTION OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING. SECONDARY PREVENTION EFFORTS OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENT ION WILL ENSURE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, ENHANCE BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE, AND IMPROVE LINKAGE TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES. NEW PRIMARY PREVENTION EFFORTS WILL DEVELOP A TARGETED POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTION FOR CHILD CARE FACILITIES IN THE DALLAS ? FORT WORTH METROPLEX. THE TEXAS CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (TXCLPPP) WILL LEVERAGE COLLABORATIVE RELATIONSHIPS WITH OTHER STATE AGENCIES, HEALTH FACILITIES, ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS, AND LOCAL AFFILIATES TO INCREASE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND IDENTIFY AND TARGET HIGH-RISK POPULATIONS FOR PRIMARY AND SECONDARY PREVENTION ACTIVITIES. OUTCOMESTHE PROPOSED STRATEGIES AND ACTIVITIES WILL IMPROVE STATEWIDE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, USE DATA INTEGRATION EFFORTS TO REDUCE MISSING DATA, CONTINUE TO IDENTIFY AND FOLLOW UP WITH CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS, AND EDUCATE FAMILIES IN HIGH-RISK GEOGRAPHIC AREAS AND POPULATIONS THROUGH TARGETED INTERVENTIONS. COLLABORATIVE ACTIVITIES WILL PROVIDE DIRECT SUPPORT TO LOCAL HEALTH JURISDICTIONS TO INCREASE THE ABILITY TO PROVIDE LINKAGES TO SERVICES AND REDUCE LOSS TO FOLLOW-UP THROUGHOUT THE STATE. ENHANCED SURVEILLANCE ACTIVITIES WILL ALLOW TXCLPPP TO EVALUATE AND REDUCE DISPARITIES AND BETTER INTEGRATE OTHER DATA SOURCES FOR MORE PRECISE IDENTIFICATION OF HIGH-RISK AREAS IN TEXAS. FINALLY, THE PROPOSED STRATEGIES AND ACTIVITIES WILL FOCUS ON POLICIES FOR TARGETED COMMUNITY-BASED APPROACHES TO DECREASE LEAD HAZARDS, RAISE AWARENESS AND INCREASE LEAD PREVENTION AND REMEDIATION KNOWLEDGE AMONG CHILD CARE PROVIDERS AND PARENTS IN THE DALLAS ? FORT WORTH METROPLEX.

NH CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN - COMPONENT A - THE STATE OF HEALTHY HOMES AND LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM IS EXCITED TO CONTINUE OUR LONGSTANDING RELATIONSHIP WITH THE CDC?S NATIONAL CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH, BRAIDING RESOURCES WITH SEVEN STATE AND FEDERAL SOURCES TO SUPPORT A ROBUST PROGRAM THAT HAS BEEN THE LOCAL AUTHORITY IN THE STATE TO PREVENT CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING SINCE 1984. THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT PROPOSAL IS TO RALLY RESOURCES TO ASSIST OUR EXISTING PROGRAM?S ABILITY TO REDUCE THE BURDEN OF LEAD POISONING BY IMPROVING BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, THE USE OF OUR NEW SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM TO CAPTURE THIS DATA, AND TO IMPROVE THE NUMBER OF YOUNG CHILDREN WITH BLOOD LEAD ELEVATIONS THAT ARE SUCCESSFULLY CONNECTED TO NECESSARY SERVICES.  NEW HAMPSHIRE (NH) WILL USE CDC FUNDS TO SUPPORT ALL OR PORTIONS OF SEVEN EMPLOYEES THAT INCLUDE A DIRECTOR (AUTHORIZING SIGNATURE), BUREAU CHIEF, PROGRAM MANAGER (PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR), EPIDEMIOLOGIST, CARE COORDINATOR, HEALTH PROMOTION ADVISOR, AND A PROGRAM ASSISTANT.  THE HEALTH PROMOTION ADVISOR, EPIDEMIOLOGIST AND THE CARE COORDINATOR WILL HAVE PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY FOR IMPLEMENTING THE THREE STRATEGIES OF COMPONENT A, SUPPORTED BY AMENDING EXISTING CONTRACTS WITH THE COMMUNITY HEALTH INSTITUTE AND THE CITY OF MANCHESTER HEALTH DEPARTMENT.  TO IMPROVE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND COMPREHENSIVE REPORTING IN UNDERPERFORMING REGIONS, NH WILL FOCUS RESOURCES ON SUPPORTING THE HEALTH PROMOTION ADVISOR?S ACTIVITIES WITH THE MEDICAL COMMUNITY, EDUCATING HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS ON NH?S UNIVERSAL TESTING REQUIREMENTS AND DISTRIBUTING THE UPDATED CHILDHOOD LEAD SCREENING AND MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES THAT INCLUDE FOLLOW-UP TESTING AND APPROPRIATE REFERRALS FOR EARLY INTERVENTION. NH WILL CONTINUE TO COLLABORATE WITH THE STATEWIDE CLINICAL LEAD ADVISORY COMMITTEE, THE NH CHAPTER OF THE ACADEMY OF PEDIATRICS, AND THE NH CHILDHOOD LEAD STAKEHOLDERS GROUP TO DISTRIBUTE OUR NEWLY DEVELOPED CHILDREN?S BOARD BOOK HAPPY, HEALTHY, LEAD-FREE ME AND TWO VIDEOS AIMED AT INCREASING TESTING RATES.  WITH THESE STRATEGIES IN PLACE, NH?S OUTCOME FOR YEAR ONE WILL BE TO REESTABLISH TESTING RATES FOR ONE AND 2 YEAR OLDS TO PRE-PANDEMIC RATES OF X AND Y.  STRENGTHENING SURVEILLANCE WILL REQUIRE RESOURCES ALLOCATED TOWARDS THE EPIDEMIOLOGIST AND INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY STAFF TO SUPPORT THE CDC?S NEWLY IMPLEMENTED HEALTHY HOMES AND LEAD POISONING SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM (HHLPSS), REPLACING A TWENTY-YEAR-OLD SURVEILLANCE DATABASE. THE EPIDEMIOLOGIST WILL FOCUS ON IMPROVING QUALITY CONTROL, IMPLEMENTING OUR NEW DATA-SHARING PLAN WITH THE OFFICE OF MEDICAID, AND PROVIDING QUARTERLY DATA EXTRACTS TO THE CDC.  THIS WILL IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF NH?S SURVEILLANCE DATA ALLOWING SUBMISSIONS TO CDC TO BE 100% ON TIME AND 95% FREE OF ERRORS.  TO STRENGTHEN NH?S EXISTING SYSTEM THAT LINKS CHILDREN WITH BLOOD LEAD ELEVATIONS TO SERVICES THAT PROVIDE EDUCATION AND FAMILY SUPPORT RESOURCES TO HELP MITIGATE THE IMPACT OF THE ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD, RESOURCES WILL BE TO CONTINUE TO FUND OUR CARE COORDINATOR. THE CARE COORDINATOR WILL MAKE, DOCUMENT, TRACK AND FOLLOW-UP ON REFERRALS FOR FIVE CORE REFERRALS THAT INCLUDE HOME VISITS, ENVIRONMENTAL INVESTIGATIONS, FOLLOW-UP WITH THE MEDICAL PROVIDER, EARLY CHILDHOOD INTERVENTION, AND, IF LEAD HAZARDS ARE FOUND, THE LOCAL HUD LEAD HAZARD CONTROL GRANT PROGRAM.  IF SUCCESSFUL, IT IS EXPECTED LINKAGES FOR THE CORE REFERRALS WILL INCREASE BY THE END OF YEAR ONE TO 98% (NURSE CASE MANAGEMENT), 86% (ENVIRONMENTAL INVESTIGATIONS), 38% (WIC), 34% (EARLY INTERVENTION) AND 54% (HUD LEAD HAZARD CONTROL GRANT.  NH?S EVALUATION AND PERFORMANCE MEASUREMENT PLAN, IMPLEMENTED IN OCTOBER 2019, WILL BE UPDATED DURING THIS PROJECT PERIOD TO REFLECT A SIMPLER APPROACH TO EVALUATION BASED ON LESSONS LEARNED IN NUE2EH001408.  MODIFICATIONS TO OUR EVALUATION AND PERFORMANCE MEASUREMENT PLAN WILL INCLUDE INCREASED INVOLVEMENT OF NH?S TWO STAKEHOLDER

MASSACHUSETTS CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM - THE MASSACHUSETTS DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (CLPPP) IS SEEKING FUNDING FROM THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION AS A COMPETITIVE GRANTEE. COMPONENT A WILL SUPPORT AND EXPAND CLPPP?S WORK TO 1) ENSURE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING; 2) ENHANCE BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE; AND 3) IMPROVE LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES. CDC FUNDS WILL BE USED TO SUSTAIN, EXPAND, AND ENHANCE OUR EXTENSIVE CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM THAT INCLUDES COMPREHENSIVE CASE MANAGEMENT TEAMS CONSISTING OF CLINICAL CARE, ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH INSPECTORS, AND COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKERS. CLPPP EPIDEMIOLOGY AND SUPPORT STAFF, TO BE FUNDED BY CDC, IS RESPONSIBLE FOR COMPREHENSIVE CHILDHOOD BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE AND EPIDEMIOLOGY, INCLUDING MANAGEMENT OF BLOOD LEAD AND ENVIRONMENTAL DATABASES. DATA COLLECTED WILL CONTINUE TO DIRECT THE PROGRAM?S EFFORTS AND INFORM THE PUBLIC WITH THE GOAL OF REDUCING CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING. COMPONENT B WILL DEVELOP TARGETED, POPULATION POLICY INTERVENTIONS WITH THE CITY OF WORCESTER AND DEVELOP STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS WITH REFUGEE AND IMMIGRANT SERVICE PROVIDERS IN THE GREATER WORCESTER AREA. CDC FUNDS WILL BE USED TO PILOT THE EXPANSION OF CASE MANAGEMENT SERVICES TO TARGETED CHILDREN WITH BLLS OF CONCERN AND TO FURTHER ENGAGE WORCESTER COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS, ESPECIALLY THOSE FOCUSED ON CHILDREN?S HEALTH, IMMIGRANTS, REFUGEES, HOUSING, AND HEALTH EQUITY. THE GEOGRAPHIC AND ECONOMIC COMPOSITION OF MASSACHUSETTS, OWING TO ITS AGE AND HISTORY, RESULTS IN A SIGNIFICANT LEAD BURDEN FOR CHILDREN IN OUR JURISDICTION. THE MOST RECENT AMERICAN COMMUNITY SURVEY 5-YEAR ESTIMATE FROM THE US CENSUS INDICATES THAT MASSACHUSETTS HAS THE THIRD HIGHEST PERCENTAGE OF PRE-1978 HOUSING UNITS OF ANY STATE, WITH 69% OF ALL HOUSING HAVING BEEN BUILT PRIOR TO 1978 AND POTENTIALLY CONTAMINATED WITH LEAD. FURTHERMORE, EVALUATING DATA ON BLOOD LEAD SCREENING AND ELEVATED CHILDHOOD B LOOD LEAD INCIDENCE REVEALS RELATIONSHIPS WITH ECONOMIC INDICATORS THAT RESULT IN AREAS OF THE STATE AT PARTICULAR HIGH RISK. IN 2019, 2,728 CHILDREN WERE IDENTIFIED WITH A BLOOD LEAD VALUE OF 5 ?G/DL OR GREATER THAT WOULD REQUIRE FOLLOW-UP INTERVENTION FOR SECONDARY AND TERTIARY PREVENTION AND 17 OUT OF 351 TOTAL MASSACHUSETTS COMMUNITIES WERE IDENTIFIED AS HIGH RISK FOR ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD BASED UPON AN ALGORITHM OF AGE OF HOUSING, POVERTY LEVEL, AND INCIDENCE OF ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD. PRELIMINARY DATA ALSO SUGGESTS THAT OTHER POPULATIONS ARE UNDERSERVED WITH RESPECT TO THE RISK FOR ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD INCLUDING REFUGEES, CHILDREN OF NON-WHITE RACE OR OF HISPANIC ETHNICITY, AND RURAL POPULATIONS. RECOGNIZING THAT SURVEILLANCE IS ONLY THE BEGINNING OF OUR WORK, WE SEE ADDITIONAL NEED FOR PROGRESS IN PRIMARY PREVENTION AND IMPROVEMENT OF OUR HOUSING THROUGH PRIVATE SECTOR INSPECTIONS AND REMEDIATION. THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL ENHANCE OUR STATE-OF-THE-ART CHILDHOOD BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE, CASE MANAGEMENT, AND PREVENTION PROGRAM TO TARGET HIGH RISK COMMUNITIES, TO EXPAND OUR COLLABORATIONS, AND TO DEVELOP NEW METHODS OF EVALUATION IN OUR EFFORT TO MAKE MORE HOMES LEAD SAFE AND TO SEE FEWER ADVERSELY IMPACTED CHILDREN IN MA.

A COLLABORATIVE APPROACH TO CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION, TESTING, AND SURVEILLANCE IN NORTH CAROLINA - THE NORTH CAROLINA CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (NC CLPPP) PROPOSES TO IMPLEMENT A COMPREHENSIVE STATEWIDE PROGRAM AIMED AT PRIMARY AND SECONDARY PREVENTION OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING. FOR COMPONENT A, NC CLPPP WILL PARTNER WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA INSTITUTE FOR THE ENVIRONMENT (UNC-IE) AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS TO INCREASE BLOOD LEAD TESTING RATES AND IMPROVE REPORTING OF TEST RESULTS; IDENTIFY AND PROVIDE FOLLOW-UP SERVICES FOR CHILDREN EXPOSED TO LEAD; IMPROVE INTER-AGENCY COORDINATION TO CONNECT FAMILIES OF CHILDREN WITH CONFIRMED ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS (EBLS) =5 ΜG/DL TO SERVICES THAT HELP MITIGATE THE EFFECTS OF LEAD EXPOSURE AND PROVIDE OTHER NEEDED SUPPORT; AND WORK WITH PARTNERS TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS AIMED AT PRIMARY PREVENTION THROUGH OUTREACH AND EDUCATION TO ADDRESS KNOWN INEQUITIES. FOR COMPONENT B (PARTNERSHIPS TO ENHANCE ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH LITERACY (PEEHL)), UNC-IE WILL LEAD A PROJECT TO ENHANCE UNDERSTANDING OF LEAD EXPOSURES AMONG PUBLIC HEALTH, CHILD CARE PROFESSIONALS, AND RESIDENTS OF HIGH-RISK, RURAL COUNTIES AND FACILITATE ACTION TO PREVENT EXPOSURE BY IMPLEMENTING TARGETED, POPULATION-BASED PRIMARY PREVENTION INTERVENTIONS.  THE PERCENT OF CHILDREN <6 IN NC WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS =5 ΜG/DL ON AT LEAST ONE BLOOD LEAD TEST DECREASED FROM 5.5% (N=41,127/754,562) IN 2006-2010 TO 1.4% (N=8,278/598,107) IN 2016-2019, SUGGESTING THAT THE STRATEGIES EMPLOYED BY NC CLPPP ARE EFFECTIVELY REDUCING CHILDHOOD LEAD EXPOSURE. HOWEVER, 12 OF THE 100 NC COUNTIES HAD RATES OF CHILDREN WITH CONFIRMED EBLS =5 ΜG/DL THAT WERE DOUBLE THE STATE RATE OR HIGHER DURING 2015-2019; AND 10 OF THOSE 12 WERE RURAL COUNTIES IN THE NORTHEAST AND EAST. BY WORKING WITH STRATEGIC COMMUNITY PARTNERS NC CLPPP WILL INCREASE INFORMATION DISSEMINATED TO THESE COUNTIES TO REDUCE HEALTH DISPARITIES.  WE AIM TO ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING OUTCOMES OVER FIVE YEARS: COMPONENT A - IMPROVE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING RATES FOR CHILDREN <6 YEARS OLD THROUGH PROVIDER AND LABORATORY OUTREACH - SUSTAIN AND DEVELOP PARTNERSHIPS WITH AGENCIES THAT SERVE OUR TARGET POPULATIONS TO CREATE A STATEWIDE LEAD ADVISORY COMMITTEE THAT ISSUES RECOMMENDATIONS BASED ON LOCAL DATA - INCREASE UNDERSTANDING OF CURRENT LEAD-RELATED GUIDELINES AMONG PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONALS - ENHANCE THE SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM’S ABILITY TO CAPTURE MISSING CHILD DEMOGRAPHIC AND FOLLOW-UP DATA BY MATCHING SURVEILLANCE DATA WITH MEDICAID DATA - IMPROVE THE RATE AT WHICH EBL CHILDREN <6 YEARS ARE LINKED TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES - STRENGTHEN CLINICAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL CASE COORDINATION THROUGH SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM IMPROVEMENTS - REDUCE DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BY RACE/ETHNICITY AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS BY TARGETING HIGH-RISK AREAS, ESPECIALLY IN THE RURAL NORTHEAST, FOR INTERVENTION AND OUTREACH COMPONENT B - INCREASE PRIMARY PREVENTION OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING THROUGH COORDINATION WITH LOCAL AND REGIONAL HEALTH AGENCIES AND COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS BY: O BUILDING THE CAPACITY OF EDUCATORS TO CONDUCT PRIMARY PREVENTION ACTIVITIES; O ENGAGING THE MOST VULNERABLE POPULATIONS THROUGH OUTREACH TO RESIDENTS IN HIGH-RISK AREAS; O SHARING INFORMATION ON HEALTH DISPARITIES IN LEAD POISONING WITH PUBLIC HEALTH DECISION-MAKERS TO BUILD SUPPORT FOR PREVENTION OF LEAD POISONING IN CHILDREN; O CONDUCTING HOME ASSESSMENTS TO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL LEAD HAZARDS IN HOMES; O COLLABORATING WITH THE STATE’S RRP PROGRAM TO TRAIN PROFESSIONALS TO BUILD CAPACITY WITHIN THE COUNTY AND REGION TO IMPLEMENT LEAD-SAFE WORK PRACTICES;  FOR OVER 20 YEARS, NC CLPPP HAS BUILT MEANINGFUL PARTNERSHIPS WITH KEY STAKEHOLDERS, DEVELOPING SURVEILLANCE CAPABILITIES AND BUILDING CAPACITY TO REDUCE THE BURDEN OF LEAD POISONING IN NORTH CAROLINA. THROUGH THIS PROPOSED WORK, OUR PARTNERSHIPS WILL BE LEVERAGED TO REACH THE MOST VUL

CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION - COMPONENT B.- THE BALTIMORE CITY HEALTH DEPARTMENT (BCHD) COMBATS CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING THROUGH MEDICAL CASE CASE MANGEMENT OF LEAD POISONED CHILDREN, ENVIRONMENTAL INSPECTIONS OF HOMES WITH LEAD HAZARDS AND ENFORCEMENT OF APPLICABLE LAWS, PROSECUTION OF NONCOMPLIANT PROPERTY, AND REFERRALS OF FAMILIES TO LEAD ABATEMENT PROGRAMS.DESPITE THE MODERATE SUCCESS OF THE LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM, MUCH MORE NEEDS TO BE DONE TO REACH THE GOAL OF ELIMINATING CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING.  INCREASED TESTING, OUTREACH AND PARTNERSHIP ARE VITAL TO INCREASING LEAD TESTING RATES, INCREASING EDUCATION OF BALTIMORE CITY RESIDENTS AND STRENGTHENING LOCAL AND STATE PARTNERSHIP.

PREVENTING CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING IN MAINE - IN 2019, APPROXIMATELY 1 OUT OF EVERY 40 MAINE CHILDREN UNDER AGE 6 YEARS WHO WERE TESTED FOR LEAD IN THE BLOOD HAD LEAD POISONING. THIS MEANS THAT AN ESTIMATED 347 OUT OF 14,367 (2.4%) CHILDREN TESTED FOR LEAD POISONING HAD A BLOOD LEAD LEVEL (BLL) OF 5 MICROGRAMS OF LEAD PER DECILITER OF BLOOD (?G/DL) OR HIGHER. WHILE BOTH THE NUMBER AND THE PERCENTAGE OF CHILDREN IDENTIFIED WITH LEAD POISONING HAS BEEN DECLINING IN MAINE SINCE 2003 WHEN AN ESTIMATED 1,500 CHILDREN, OR NEARLY 11 PERCENT OF CHILDREN TESTED, HAD A BLL OF 5 ?G/DL OR HIGHER, THE MAINE CENTER FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION?S CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION UNIT (CLPPU) CONTINUES TO PURSUE ITS LONGSTANDING GOAL OF ERADICATING CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING IN MAINE, AND TO OPERATE UNDER THE PRINCIPLE THAT THERE IS NO SAFE LEVEL OF LEAD IN A CHILD?S BODY.MAINE HAS ALREADY ESTABLISHED A ROBUST, COMPREHENSIVE PRIMARY AND SECONDARY LEAD POISONING PREVENTION EFFORT. IN 2016, MAINE BECAME ONE OF THE FIRST JURISDICTIONS IN THE U.S. TO PROVIDE CASE MANAGEMENT AND ENVIRONMENTAL INTERVENTIONS FOR CHILDREN WITH BLOOD LEAD LEVELS AS LOW AS 5 UG/DL (THE U.S. CDC?S CURRENT REFERENCE LEVEL FOR ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD IN CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OLD). IN 2019, IN RESPONSE TO PERSISTENTLY LOW BLOOD LEAD TESTING RATES, THE MAINE LEGISLATURE AMENDED STATE LAW TO REQUIRE ALL CHILDREN TO BE TESTED FOR LEAD AT AGES 1 AND 2 YEARS. MAINE CLPPU ALSO CONDUCTS STATEWIDE ACTIVITIES TARGETED TO AT-RISK POPULATIONS AND COMMUNITY-BASED PRIMARY PREVENTION ACTIVITIES IN HIGH-RISK AREAS THROUGH A DEDICATED STATE REVENUE STREAM. THE PROPOSED PROJECT, THEREFORE, BUILDS UPON THIS SOLID FOUNDATION TO FILL KEY PROGRAM GAPS AND STRENGTHEN EXISTING EFFORTS.FUNDING FROM THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL BE USED FOR THE SECONDARY PREVENTION OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING, INCLUDING TO: 1) IMPROVE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING IN MAINE IN ALIGNMENT WITH MAINE AND FEDERAL BLOOD LEAD TESTING REQUIREMENTS; 2) MAINTAIN AND EXPAND M AINE?S CAPACITY TO CONDUCT BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE; AND 3) IMPROVE MAINE?S ABILITY AND PROCESSES TO LINK LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES.MAJOR ACTIVITIES SUPPORTED BY THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT, OR LEVERAGED USING STATE RESOURCES, WILL INCLUDE: A) WORKING WITH A  STATEWIDE LEAD ADVISORY COMMITTEE AND PARTNERS INCLUDING MAINE?S MEDICAID ADMINISTRATION AGENCY TO IMPROVE TO IMPROVE BLOOD LEAD SCREENING IN HIGH-RISK AREAS AND AMONG MAINECARE-ENROLLED CHILDREN THROUGH THE USE OF BLOOD LEAD TESTING REPORT CARDS; B) OPERATING AND UPGRADING A LEAD POISONING CASE MANAGEMENT AND SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM IN ORDER TO COLLECT, ANALYZE, REPORT, AND DISSEMINATE IMPORTANT DATA ABOUT LEAD POISONING IN MAINE; AND, C) IMPROVING MAINE?S PROCESSES TO LINK LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO SERVICES SUCH AS ENVIRONMENTAL LEAD INVESTIGATIONS OF THE HOME ENVIRONMENT AND OTHER RECOMMENDED SERVICES SUCH AS NURSING VISITS AND EARLY INTERVENTION SERVICES.THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN IMPROVED BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING RATES FOR CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE AT RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE; IMPROVED USE OF SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM DATA TO CAPTURE MISSING DATA ON CHILD DEMOGRAPHIC AND FOLLOW-UP INFORMATION; IMPROVED RATES OF CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS LINKED TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES; AND, DECREASED DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BY RACE/ETHNICITY AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS.

IN CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION & SURVEILLANCE PROGRAM - INDIANA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH LEAD AND HEALTHY HOMES PROGRAMCDC CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN CDC-RFA-EH21-2102- COMPONENT AABSTRACT:THE INDIANA LEAD AND HEALTHY HOMES PROGRAM (LHHP) IS LOCATED WITHIN THE PUBLIC HEALTH PROTECTION AND LABORATORY SERVICES COMMISSION OF THE INDIANA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH (IDOH). IN 2019, IDOH RECEIVED 84,769 BLOOD LEAD TEST RESULTS, BOTH VENOUS AND CAPILLARY TESTS, FROM MEDICAL PROVIDERS, LABORATORIES AND OTHER PUBLIC HEALTH PARTNERS. OF THESE RESULTS, 916, OR 1.1%, WERE CONSIDERED ELEVATED. THESE RESULTS INCLUDED TESTS FROM 77,807 UNIQUE CHILDREN UNDER AGE 7 WHO WERE TESTED IN INDIANA. OF THOSE CHILDREN, 607 (0.78%) HAD AT LEAST ONE ELEVATED RESULT, AND 196 (0.25%) HAD A CONFIRMED ELEVATED RESULT WITH A BLOOD LEAD RESULT > 10 ?G/DL, OR IN THE CITY OF EAST CHICAGO AT >5 ?G/DL.BASED ON THE DATA COLLECTED AND ANALYZED, THE LHHP EMPHASIZES A GEOGRAPHICAL TARGETED COMMUNITY APPROACH TO PRODUCE THE GREATEST REDUCTION IN ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN INDIANA. THIS COMMUNITY PLAN APPROACH INCLUDES THE FOLLOWING COMPONENTS: STATISTICAL MAPPING TO PREDICT GEOGRAPHICAL AREAS HAVING POTENTIALLY HIGHER RATES OF LEAD HAZARDS AND CHILDREN AT-RISK; TARGETED ENVIRONMENTAL INVESTIGATION AND PRIMARY PREVENTION EFFORTS, TARGETED BLOOD TESTING OF AT-RISK CHILDREN, MEDICAL MANAGEMENT, LABORATORY SUPPORT, CASE MANAGEMENT, DEVELOPMENT OF A HOUSING DATABASE, DEVELOPMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF A SURVEILLANCE DATABASE, PUBLIC AND PROFESSIONAL EDUCATION, AND COMMUNITY EMPOWERMENT THROUGH RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT.ILHHP HAS MADE SIGNIFICANT PROGRESS IN BUILDING A SOLID FOUNDATION AND COMPREHENSIVE NETWORK OF STRATEGIC PARTNERS THROUGHOUT THE STATE. THESE EFFORTS ARE MULTIPLIED THROUGH THE INCREDIBLE ASSEMBLAGE OF STAKEHOLDERS ACCEPTING TO ELIMINATE LEAD POISONING AS A PUBLIC HEALTH CONCERN IN INDIANA?S CHILDREN. WITH THE HELP OF OUR PARTNERS, THE PROPOSED OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT ARE:?INCREASE D NUMBER OF CHILDREN TESTED FOR ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS, ESPECIALLY MEDICAID?DECREASED NUMBER OF CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS ?5UG/DL?INCREASED PARTNERSHIPS TO ELIMINATE LEAD POISONING AS A PUBLIC HEALTH CONCERN?INCREASED TARGETED EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES FOR HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS AND PARENTS?INCREASED USE OF SURVEILLANCE DATA IN PROGRAMMATIC ACTIVITIES AND INTERVENTIONS?IMPROVED SURVEILLANCE AND CASE COORDINATION FOR CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEVELSINDIANA DEMONSTRATES BOTH THE NEED FOR CONTINUED FUNDING AND THE CAPACITY TO MEET THE CHALLENGES FACING LEAD AND HEALTHY HOMES PROGRAMS IN 2021 AND BEYOND. THE IDOH LHHP HAS PROVIDED, AND WITH THIS FUNDING WILL CONTINUE TO PROVIDE, KEY PROGRAMMATIC STRATEGIES,INTERVENTIONS, AND SERVICES TO STRENGTHEN OUR STATE?S CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM. THOSE VALUABLE SERVICES WILL CONTINUE TO INCLUDE IMPROVING BLOOD LEAD SCREENING TEST RATES, IDENTIFYING HIGH-RISK POPULATIONS THROUGH SURVEILLANCE, AND ENSURING EFFECTIVE REFERRAL AND FOLLOW-UP FOR CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS.

CONNECTICUT?S CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAMS - COMPONENT A - BACKGROUND /PROBLEM:  CONNECTICUT?S HOUSING STOCK IS CONSIDERABLY OLDER THAN THE NATIONAL AVERAGE, WITH 70% BUILT PRIOR TO 1980 AND 43% BUILT PRIOR TO 1960 (2019 AMERICAN COMMUNITY SURVEY 5-YEAR ESTIMATES U.S. CENSUS). THIS HAS SIGNIFICANTLY CONTRIBUTED TO THE INCREASED RISK OF LEAD-EXPOSURE AND ASSOCIATED ADVERSE HEALTH EFFECTS IN CHILDREN UNDER SIX YEARS OLD.  FURTHER COMPOUNDING THE PROBLEM, IS THE FACT THAT AN EVEN LARGER PROPORTION OF THE OLDER HOUSING STOCK EXISTS IN DENSELY POPULATED CITIES WHERE CHILDREN ARE MORE LIKELY TO LIVE IN POVERTY AND MORE LIKELY TO BE BLACK OR HISPANIC, WIDENING THE HEALTH DISPARITY GAP. OVER THE PAST 20 YEARS, CONNECTICUT HAS SEEN A STEADY DECLINE OF ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS (?5 MCG/DL) IN CHILDREN UNDER SIX YEARS OLD.  THIS STEADY DECLINE HAS BEEN, IN LARGE PART, DUE TO THE CONSISTENT SUPPORT RECEIVED BY THE CDC AS WELL AS THE CONNECTICUT DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH?S CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM?S (CLPPP) ORGANIZATIONAL CAPACITY AND SUSTAINED ENGAGEMENT WITH FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL PARTNERS.PURPOSE: THE CLPPP IS INTENT ON ELIMINATING CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING BY: 1) ENSURING BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, 2) ENHANCING BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE, 3) IMPROVING LINKAGES TO ENSURE LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN RECEIVE RECOMMENDED SERVICES, AND 4) DEVELOPING TARGETED POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO SEEK GRANT FUNDING TO ADEQUATELY SUPPORT AND SUSTAIN THESE GOALS.STRATEGIES AND OUTCOMES: THROUGH CDC FUNDING WE EXPECT TO ENSURE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING BY INCREASING COLLABORATION WITH COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND STAKEHOLDERS, ADDRESS OUTDATED LEGISLATION, AND INCREASE PROVIDER COMPLIANCE SCREENING AND REPORTING LAWS. THE CLPPP WILL ALSO ENHANCE BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE BY IMPROVING COMPLETENESS OF DATA COLLECTION, INCREASING EFFICIENCY OF DATA PROCESSING, EMPLOYING DATA MATCHING METHODS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND SCREENING RATES IN MEDICAID AND REFUGEE POPULATIONS, AND BY PUBL ISHING SURVEILLANCE REPORTS MAKING DATA PUBLICLY AVAILABLE FOR USE BY LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (LHDS).  WE WILL IMPROVE LINKAGES OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES BY CREATING LEGISLATION THAT REQUIRES LHDS TO UTILIZE THE SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM AND BY ENSURING LHDS CONDUCT TIMELY ENVIRONMENTAL INVESTIGATIONS WHILE PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE. THE CLPPP WILL ALSO COLLABORATE WITH THE OFFICE OF EARLY CHILDHOOD?S BIRTH TO THREE PROGRAM TO PROVIDE APPROPRIATE RESOURCES TO LEAD POISONED CHILDREN AND WE WILL CONTINUE TO PARTNER WITH REGIONAL LEAD TREATMENT CENTERS TO PROVIDE PEER TO PEER EDUCATION AND RESOURCES FOR CASE MANAGEMENT. FINALLY, THE CLPPP WILL STRENGTHEN TARGETED POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS AND ADDRESS HEALTH DISPARITIES BY UTILIZING GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS TO MAP AND ENHANCE KNOWLEDGE OF LOCATIONS WITH HIGH PREVALENCE AND INCIDENCE OF LEAD POISONING. THIS INFORMATION WILL FURTHER BE USED TO INFORM MEDIA CAMPAIGNS AND COMMUNITY OUTREACH FOCUSED ON HIGH RISK BLACK AND HISPANIC POPULATIONS TO REDUCE KNOWN DISPARITIES.SIGNIFICANCE:  BY FUNDING THIS ACTIVITY, THE CDC WILL CONTINUE TO SUPPORT THE OVERALL DECLINE OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING IN CONNECTICUT, WHILE REDUCING RACIAL AND ETHNIC HEALTH DISPARITIES, AND IMPROVING HEALTH EQUITY FOR OTHER NOTORIOUSLY UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS.  THESE ACCOMPLISHMENTS WILL HAVE FAR REACHING POSITIVE EFFECTS ON CHILDREN?S HEALTH DURING EARLY DEVELOPMENT AND WILL IMPROVE THEIR CHANCES FOR LATER SUCCESS.

HAWAII CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM - PURPOSE: THE HAWAII CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (HI-CLPPP) WILL (A) IMPROVE BLOOD LEAD SCREENING TEST RATES ESPECIALLY AMONG THE HIGHEST RISK POPULATIONS; (B) MAINTAIN AND IMPROVE THE SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM BY WORKING WITH LABORATORIES AND HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS TO IMPROVE THE COLLECTION OF SOCIODEMOGRAPHIC AND GEOGRAPHIC RISK FACTORS FROM BLOOD LEAD TESTING DATA TO BETTER IDENTIFY THE HIGHEST RISK POPULATIONS AND IMPROVE HEALTH EQUITY; AND (C) COLLABORATE CLOSELY WITH HEALTHCARE AND SERVICE PROVIDERS TO ENSURE A COMPREHENSIVE SYSTEM OF FOLLOW-UP FOR CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVEL (EBLL) THAT EFFICIENTLY CONNECTS THEM WITH RECOMMENDED SERVICES AND TRACKS THEIR PROGRESS.BACKGROUND: LEAD-BASED PAINT WAS BANNED FOR RESIDENTIAL USE IN 1978. OVER 54% OF HAWAII?S HOUSING AND 61% OF HONOLULU?S HOUSING WERE BUILT BEFORE 1980. HAWAII?S WARM AND HUMID TROPICAL CLIMATE CREATES A CORROSIVE ENVIRONMENT THAT ACCELERATES PAINT DETERIORATION. HAWAII ALSO HAS THE HIGHEST COST OF LIVING IN THE COUNTRY COMBINED WITH MODERATE SALARIES AND A VERY COMPETITIVE RENTAL MARKET. THESE FACTORS PREVENT MANY PEOPLE WHO CAN AFFORD TO OWN FROM PROPERLY MAINTAINING THEIR HOMES, WHILE RENTERS OFTEN AVOID ASKING THEIR LANDLORDS FOR REPAIRS FOR FEAR OF BEING GIVEN NOTICE TO MOVE OUT. HAWAII ALSO CONTINUES TO WELCOME A SIGNIFICANT NUMBER OF IMMIGRANTS FROM COUNTRIES THROUGHOUT THE ASIA PACIFIC RIM, CREATING LARGE POPULATIONS OF NON-ENGLISH SPEAKING GROUPS THAT OFTEN LIVE IN MULTI-FAMILY HOMES WITHIN AREAS ALREADY AFFECTED BY TRADITIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE ISSUES, INCLUDING HIGHER RATES OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING. LEAD SOURCES AND DATA: RECENT LEAD ENVIRONMENTAL INVESTIGATIONS IDENTIFIED LIKELY SOURCES OF LEAD EXPOSURE FOR CHILDREN AS LEAD-BASED PAINT, HOME SMELTING OF FISHING SINKERS, CONTAMINATED SOIL, SOUVENIR MAGNETS, SALVAGED WOOD, USED FURNITURE, CERAMIC TILES, ANTIQUE JARS, DISHES, BEACH DEBRIS, OLD TOYS, AND OCCUPATIONAL EXPOSURE. HAWAII?S STATEWIDE E BLL RATE IN 2020 WAS 1.09%, BUT A NEIGHBOR ISLAND LIKE HAWAII ISLAND HAD HIGHER EBLL RATES (2.47%). THE TOTAL NUMBER OF CHILDREN TESTED FOR BLOOD LEAD DROPPED SIGNIFICANTLY (19.1%) IN 2020 DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. TWENTY-FIVE PERCENT (25.0%) OF ALL 1- AND 2-YEAR-OLD CHILDREN WERE TESTED FOR BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN 2020 (UP FROM A 23.8% BASELINE IN 2017, BUT DOWN FROM THE PEAK OF 26.7% IN 2018). OF CHILDREN ENROLLED IN MEDICAID, 43.4% OF 1- AND 2-YEAR-OLD CHILDREN WERE TESTED IN 2019 (UP FROM A 37.8% BASELINE IN 2016), BUT THESE 2019 NUMBERS THAT DO NOT YET REFLECT THE EFFECTS OF COVID-19 IN 2020. PROJECT PERIOD OUTCOMES:?IMPROVE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING RATES FOR CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE AT RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE (E.G., SCREENING/TESTING PENETRANCE AND THE INCIDENCE AND PREVALENCE OF CHILDREN WITH BLOOD LEAD LEVELS GREATER THAN OR EQUAL TO THE CDC BLOOD LEAD REFERENCE VALUE) AND OTHER IMPORTANT BLOOD LEAD LEVELS CATEGORIES.?IMPROVE USE OF SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM DATA TO CAPTURE MISSING DATA ON CHILD DEMOGRAPHIC AND FOLLOW-UP INFORMATION (E.G., ADDRESS, RACE/ETHNICITY, SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS, SMALL GEOGRAPHIC AREA [ZIP CODE OR CENSUS TRACT], REFERRALS TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES, COMPLETION OF SERVICES BY TYPE).?IMPROVED RATES OF CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS LINKED TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES (E.G., ENVIRONMENTAL INSPECTIONS, MEDICAL EVALUATIONS, NUTRITIONAL COUNSELING, DEVELOPMENTAL SERVICES).?DECREASE DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BY RACE/ETHNICITY AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS.

GENESEE, LIVINGSTON, ORLEANS, WYOMING COUNTIES CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (GLOW CLPP) - PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYTHE PURPOSE OF THE GLOW CLPP (GENESEE, LIVINGSTON, ORLEANS, AND WYOMING COUNTIES CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION) PROGRAM IS TO ELIMINATE LEAD HAZARDS AND CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING BY DEVELOPING TARGETED POPULATION-BASED POLICIES AND INTERVENTIONS.  THE GLOW REGION IS COMPRISED OF FOUR SMALL, RURAL COUNTIES WHICH ARE GEOGRAPHICALLY LOCATED BETWEEN THE CITIES OF ROCHESTER AND BUFFALO IN WESTERN NEW YORK. THERE ARE OVER 50,000 HOMES IN THE GLOW REGION THAT WERE BUILT BEFORE 1978, AND MANY STILL CONTAIN LEAD HAZARDS. MOST OF THESE HOMES ARE IN RURAL AREAS OF THE REGION AND ARE OCCUPIED BY OUR TARGET POPULATIONS. THE TARGET POPULATIONS FOR THE GLOW CLPP PROGRAM ARE CHILDREN UNDER THE AGE OF SIX (WITH A SPECIFIC FOCUS ON CHILDREN UNDER THREE YEARS OLD) FROM LOW-INCOME, MIGRANT, NON-ENGLISH SPEAKING, NATIVE AMERICAN, AMISH, AND OTHER ETHNIC MINORITY FAMILIES. NEARLY 10% OF THE GLOW REGION?S POPULATION LIVES BELOW THE POVERTY LINE, WITH LIVINGSTON COUNTY HAVING THE HIGHEST LOW-INCOME POPULATION AT 13.8%. SPECIFICALLY, CHILDREN ARE GREATLY IMPACTED, WITH APPROXIMATELY 18% OF CHILDREN UNDER 18 LIVING IN POVERTY THROUGHOUT THE GLOW REGION. THE GLOW CLPP PROGRAM WILL IMPLEMENT THE FOLLOWING POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS AIMED AT PRIMARY PREVENTION OF LEAD EXPOSURE: ?DEVELOP AND ORGANIZE THE GLOW LEAD PREVENTION COALITION TO ADVOCATE FOR PUBLIC POLICY CHANGE REGARDING ELIMINATING         CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING IN THE HOME, AS WELL AS OTHER SOURCES OF POTENTIAL LEAD EXPOSURE ACROSS THE GLOW REGION. ?DELIVER LEAD PREVENTION EDUCATION AND OUTREACH TO THE LEAD WORKFORCE, THE PUBLIC, PARTNERS, AND STAKEHOLDERS ACROSS THE         GLOW REGION.?IMPLEMENT A PUBLIC AWARENESS CAMPAIGN TO INCREASE LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AWARENESS AND INCREASE CHILDHOOD BLOOD         LEAD TESTING RATES THROUGHOUT THE GLOW REGION.?DELIVER LEAD SAFE PRACTICE TRAININGS AND/OR WORKSHOPS TO INDIVIDUALS, HOMEOWNERS, RENTERS, LANDLORDS, CODE ENFORCEMENT  OFFICERS, AND THE LEAD WORKFORCE. ?CONDUCT ENVIRONMENTAL HOME INSPECTIONS. ?DEVELOP A LEAD SAFE HOUSING REGISTRY FOR THE GLOW REGION.THE GLOW CLPP PROGRAM WILL COLLABORATE WITH MANY OF THE VARIOUS PARTNERS AND STAKEHOLDERS OPERATING THROUGHOUT THE GLOW REGION. COORDINATION WITH THESE ORGANIZATIONS WILL ASSIST US WITH TARGETED MARKETING AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES THAT WILL MORE HOLISTICALLY REACH THOSE WHO ARE ABLE TO BENEFIT WITHIN THE GLOW COMMUNITY. IN ORDER TO EVALUATE THE SUCCESS AND IMPACT OF THE STRATEGIES AND ACTIVITIES IMPLEMENTED, BOTH PROCESS AND OUTCOME EVALUATION WILL BE COMPLETED. SURVEYS, FOCUS GROUPS, INTERVIEWS, OBSERVATIONS, QUESTIONNAIRES, EVENT LOGS, SURVEILLANCE DATA, RECORD REVIEWERS, RECORDKEEPING AND TRACKING TO COLLECT DATA WILL BE USED TO EVALUATE THE PERFORMANCE MEASURES. PARTNER AND STAKEHOLDER INCLUSION WILL BE KEY TO THE SUCCESS OF THE GLOW CLPP PROGRAM, AND EACH WILL PARTICIPATE IN THE PROGRAM EVALUATION AND PERFORMANCE PLANNING PROCESS THROUGH THE GLOW LEAD PREVENTION COALITION EVALUATION WORK GROUP.

MINNESOTA CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM - PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYTHE MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH?S CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (MCLPPP) IS SEEKING FUNDING FROM CDC TO CONTINUE ITS EFFORTS TO ELIMINATE LEAD EXPOSURE IN MINNESOTA CHILDREN. IN 2019, 89,858 MINNESOTA CHILDREN AGED < 6 YEARS WERE BLOOD LEAD TESTED. AMONG THESE, 608 (0.68%) HAD A CONFIRMED ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVEL (EBLL). WHILE THE PREVALENCE OF EBLLS IN MINNESOTA CHILDREN HAS DECLINED SUBSTANTIALLY OVER THE PAST DECADES, THE PREVALENCE OF EBLLS IS NOT EQUITABLY DISTRIBUTED THROUGHOUT THE STATE. THERE ARE GEOGRAPHIC AREAS AND POPULATIONS WITH PREVALENCES MUCH HIGHER THAN THE STATE PREVALENCE. THESE AREAS TEND TO HAVE HIGHER LEVELS OF POVERTY, OLDER HOUSING STOCK, AND LARGER PROPORTIONS OF PERSONS OF COLOR. MCLPPP IS COMMITTED TO ADDRESSING THESE DISPARITIES THROUGH TARGETING INTERVENTIONS TO HIGH-RISK AREAS AND POPULATIONS. THE MCLPPP HAS OPERATED CONTINUOUSLY SINCE 1995 IN ITS EFFORTS TO MONITOR AND ELIMINATE LEAD EXPOSURE IN MINNESOTA. IT IS AUTHORIZED UNDER MINNESOTA STATUES TO MAINTAIN A STATEWIDE LEAD SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM. THIS SYSTEM INFORMS AUTHORIZED AGENCIES (MDH AND COMMUNITY HEALTH BOARDS) OF LEAD EXPOSED CASES SO THAT THE FAMILY CAN BE REACHED WITH EDUCATION AND ENVIRONMENTAL RISK ASSESSMENTS. THESE AGENCIES ARE AUTHORIZED TO ISSUE ENFORCEABLE CORRECTION ORDERS FOR IDENTIFIED LEAD HAZARDS. IN ORDER TO IMPROVE UPON AND CONTINUE THE OPERATION OF THE MCLPPP, FUNDS RECEIVED THROUGH THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT ACTIVITIES TO REDUCE LEAD EXPOSURES AND LEAD POISONING IN MINNESOTA. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: SCREENING, REPORTING OF BLOOD LEAD DATA TO CDC, DATA MANAGEMENT/SURVEILLANCE, AND TARGETED POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS. MCLPPP WILL DEMONSTRATE THAT PROCESSES ARE IN PLACE TO IDENTIFY LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN AND LINK THEM TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES. THE PROGRAM WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH AGENCIES, PARTNERS, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS SERVING CHILDREN TO ENSURE THAT A COMPREHENSIVE SYSTEM OF REFERRAL, CASE MANAGEMENT,  FOLLOW-UP AND EVALUATION IS IN PLACE.DEMONSTRABLE OUTCOMES OF THE FUNDING WILL INCLUDE: (1) IMPROVED BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING RATES FOR CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE AT RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE. (2) IMPROVED USE OF SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM DATA TO CAPTURE MISSING DATA ON CHILD DEMOGRAPHIC AND FOLLOW-UP INFORMATION. (3) IMPROVED RATES OF CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE WHO MEET STATE CASE DEFINITIONS WHO ARE LINKED TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES. (4) DECREASED DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BY RACE/ETHNICITY AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS. (5) IMPROVED POLICIES FOR TARGETED COMMUNITY-BASED APPROACHES AIMED AT PRIMARY PREVENTION OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN.STRATEGIES AND ACTIVITIES THAT WILL PRODUCE THESE OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: (1) ENSURE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING. (2) ENHANCE BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE. (3) IMPROVE LINKAGES OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES. (4) DEVELOP TARGETED POPULATION-BASED POLICY INTERVENTIONS. THE SUCCESS OF THESE STRATEGIES WILL DEPEND HEAVILY ON THE ONGOING COLLABORATION WITH STRATEGIC PARTNERS AT FEDERAL, STATE AND LOCAL LEVELS. MCLPPP HAS A LONG HISTORY OF SUCH COLLABORATIONS AND IS PART OF A STRONG NETWORK OF ORGANIZATIONS AND AGENCIES ENGAGED IN ELIMINATING LEAD EXPOSURE IN MINNESOTA.SUCCESS WILL ALSO DEPEND ON ONGOING EVALUATION AND PERFORMANCE MEASUREMENT OF THE MCLPPP. A RIGOROUS PLAN FOR EVALUATION AND PERFORMANCE MEASUREMENT WILL BE CREATED WITHIN THE FIRST 6 MONTHS OF THE PROJECT PERIOD. THIS WILL BE USED TO MEASURE THE EFFECTIVENESS AND EFFICIENCY OF PROGRAM PROCESSES TOWARDS ACHIEVING THE INTENDED OUTCOMES. RESULTS FROM EVALUATIONS WILL BE USED TO ADJUST AND REFINE PROGRAM OPERATIONS.

CALIFORNIA CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION (CLPP): COMPONENT A + B - COMPONENT A: CALIFORNIA?S CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION BRANCH (CLPPB) WAS ESTABLISHED TO REDUCE THE INCIDENCE OF LEAD EXPOSURE AND IDENTIFY AND MANAGE THE CARE OF CHILDREN WITH LEAD POISONING. IF THIS PROPOSAL IS FUNDED, CLPPB WILL MOVE FORWARD WITH DEVELOPING ANIMPROVED PREVENTION, SCREENING AND TESTING PLAN AND ESTABLISHING STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS AND POLICIES TO ENSURE A COMPREHENSIVE SYSTEM EXISTS FOR THE IDENTIFICATION, LINKAGE TO CARE, AND PROVISION OF APPROPRIATE SERVICES TO CHILDREN EXPOSED TO LEAD WITH BLOOD LEADLEVELS ABOVE THE CDC REFERENCE LEVEL OF 5 MICROGRAMS PER DECILITER (MCG/DL).TO ACHIEVE THESE OUTCOMES, CLPPB WILL ESTABLISH AN INDEPENDENT STATEWIDE ADVISORY COMMITTEE THAT WILL DEVELOP STATEWIDE PREVENTION, SCREENING AND TESTING PLAN AND MONITOR CLPPB'S EFFORTS. TOGETHER WE WILL ESTABLISH STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS AT THE LOCAL AND STATE LEVEL, CO-DEVELOP STRATEGIES FOR ENHANCING LEAD POISONING PREVENTION STRATEGIES AND REDUCING HEALTH DISPARITIES, AND CREATE A DETAILED POLICY DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION PLAN.
