CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN - CHILDHOOD LEAD EXPOSURE IS A SERIOUS, BUT PREVENTABLE PUBLIC HEALTH PROBLEM.  THE NEW YORK CITY (NYC) DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND MENTAL HYGIENE IS A NATIONAL LEADER IN DEVELOPING PUBLIC HEALTH INTERVENTIONS WITH A FOCUS ON PRIMARY PREVENTION, DATA-DRIVEN PROGRAMS AND EVALUATION. IN 2019, 3,076 NEW YORK CITY (NYC) CHILDREN < 6 YEARS HAD BLOOD LEAD LEVELS (BLL) AT OR ABOVE THE CDC REFERENCE LEVEL OF 5 ?G/DL.  OF THESE, ABOUT 600 CHILDREN HAD BLL ?10 ?G/DL.  WHILE THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN WITH BLL ?5 ?G/DL HAS DECLINED MORE THAN 90% SINCE 2005, AS A RESULT OF STRONG POLICIES AND COLLABORATIONS BETWEEN HEALTH AND HOUSING AGENCIES, THE RATE OF DECLINE HAS SLOWED IN RECENT YEARS.  THERE IS NO SAFE BLOOD LEAD LEVEL AND MORE WORK IS NEEDED TO REDUCE CHILDHOOD LEAD EXPOSURES.THE PURPOSE OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO DECREASE DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BY SOCIAL, DEMOGRAPHIC AND GEOGRAPHIC FACTORS, AND ULTIMATELY ELIMINATE CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING IN NYC.  BUILDING ON A STRONG HISTORY OF USING DATA TO INFORM PROGRAM AND POLICY ACTION TO REDUCE LEAD EXPOSURE AND WORKING WITH OTHER AGENCY AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS, THE NYC HEALTHY HOMES PROGRAM (HHP) WILL ENSURE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, ENHANCE BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE, IMPROVE LINKAGES TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES THROUGH COMPONENT A; AND WILL DEVELOP TARGETED POPULATION-BASED PRIMARY PREVENTION INTERVENTIONS THROUGH COMPONENT B.THIS PROPOSAL STRIVES TO ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING OUTCOMES BY THE END OF THE PROJECT PERIOD: 1) IMPROVED BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING RATES FOR CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE AT RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE; 2) IMPROVED USE OF SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM DATA TO CAPTURE MISSING DATA ON CHILD DEMOGRAPHIC AND FOLLOW-UP INFORMATION; 3) IMPROVED RATES OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE LINKED TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES; AND 4) DECREASED DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BY RACE/ETHNICITY AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS.SPECIFIC STRATEGIES AND ACTIVITIES PROPOSED TO ACHIEVE THESE OUTCOME S INCLUDE:?ENSURING BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, WITH A FOCUS ON CHILDREN AT GREATER RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSUREOSUSTAINING A CITYWIDE LEAD ADVISORY COMMITTEEODATA MATCHING TO IDENTIFY MEDICAID-ENROLLED CHILDREN WHO REQUIRE A BLOOD LEAD TEST, AND CHILDREN WHO ARE OVERDUE FOR A BLOOD LEAD TEST AT AGE 1 AND 2OTARGETED OUTREACH TO INCREASE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND ELECTRONIC REPORTING?ENHANCING BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE THROUGH DATA COLLECTION, ANALYSIS AND DISSEMINATIONOUSING SURVEILLANCE DATA TO IDENTIFY HIGH-RISK GEOGRAPHIC AREAS AND POPULATIONSODISSEMINATING DATA TO CDC AND THE PUBLIC ?IMPROVING LINKAGES OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICESOUSING LEADQUEST TO TRACK THE TIMELINESS OF SERVICE DELIVERY AND FOLLOW-UP ?DEVELOPING TARGETED POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS THROUGH STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS OCOLLABORATING WITH CBOS SERVING HIGH-RISK POPULATIONS TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE TARGETED INTERVENTIONS ODEVELOPING TOOLS FOR EDUCATION AND OUTREACH AND SYSTEMATIC TRACKING OF NON-PAINT SOURCESOEXPANDING LEAD WORKFORCE CAPACITY IN TARGETED HIGH-RISK GEOGRAPHIC AREAS AND POPULATIONS

CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION - PROJECT ABSTRACT COMPONENT A APPROXIMATELY 14,800 WEST VIRGINIA CHILDREN RECEIVE A BLOOD LEAD LEVEL TEST EACH YEAR. IN 2019, THE CENTERS FOR MEDICARE-MEDICAID SERVICES REPORT (CMS-416), REPORTED OF THE 68,695 MEDICAID ELIGIBLE CHILDREN <72 MONTHS OLD, 13,977 (20.3%) RECEIVED A BLOOD LEAD SCREENING TEST. MORE CHILDREN WERE TESTED AT 12 AND 24 MONTHS, BUT OF THE 24,153 OF THESE MEDICAID ELIGIBLE CHILDREN, ONLY 42.7% WERE TESTED, LEAVING 57.3% THAT WERE NOT TESTED. HOMEOWNERSHIP IN WEST VIRGINIA BETWEEN 2015-2019 WAS 73.4% WHILE THE NATIONAL AVERAGE IS 64.1 % AS OF JANUARY 2020. MANY WEST VIRGINIANS PASS THE FAMILY HOMESTEAD DOWN THROUGH GENERATIONS TO THEIR CHILDREN OR GRANDCHILDREN. PER THE U.S. CENSUS, OF ALL WEST VIRGINIA OCCUPIED UNITS, 59.3% WERE BUILT BEFORE 1980. OF THE HOMES BUILT BEFORE 1980, 73.4% ARE OWNER OCCUPIED AND 26.6% ARE RENTER OCCUPIED. POPULATION ESTIMATES FOR 2019 FROM THE UNITED STATES CENSUS BUREAU (CENSUS.GOV/QUICKFACTS/WV) REPORTED THAT 93.5% OF WEST VIRGINIA RESIDENTS ARE CAUCASIAN, 3.6% BLACK OR AFRICAN AMERICAN, 0.3% AMERICAN INDIAN AND ALASKA NATIVE, 0.8% ASIAN, 1.89% OTHER. 1.7% OF WEST VIRGINIANS ARE OF HISPANIC AND LATINO ETHNIC ORIGIN. PER THE 2019 SMALL AREA INCOME AND POVERTY ESTIMATE (SAIPE) OF THE 347,481 WEST VIRGINIA CHILDREN UNDER THE AGE OF 18, 69,844 (20.1 %) LIVE IN POVERTY COMPARED TO THE UNITED STATES AVERAGE OF 18%. TWENTY-FIVE PERCENT OF THE 91,589 WEST VIRGINIA CHILDREN, UNDER THE AGE OF FIVE, LIVE IN POVERTY. SEVENTEEN PERCENT OF ALL WEST VIRGINIANS LIVE IN POVERTY. APPROXIMATELY 54% OF WEST VIRGINIA BIRTHS WERE PAID FOR BY MEDICAID. WHILE BOTH CAUCASIANS AND AFRICAN AMERICANS HAVE POVERTY RATES ABOVE THE NATIONAL AVERAGE, DISPARITIES EXIST ACROSS ALL AGE GROUPS. OVERALL, 29.6% OF AFRICAN AMERICANS ARE IN POVERTY COMPARED TO 17.05% OF CAUCASIANS. AFRICAN AMERICAN ADULTS ALSO EXPERIENCE SIGNIFICANTLY HIGHER POVERTY LEVELS, INCLUDING ONE IN FOUR WORKING-AGE ADULTS AND ONE IN FIVE SENIORS. THE WV C HILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM'S (WVCLPPP) PURPOSE IS TO ATTAIN OUTCOMES THAT IMPROVE CHILDREN'S HEALTH. OUTCOMES WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH INCREASED TESTING OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS OF CHILDREN UNDER 6 YEARS OF AGE BY 3% EACH YEAR OF THE REPORTING PERIOD; IMPROVED SURVEILLANCE WITH DEMOGRAPHIC INFORMATION RECEIVED BY DOCTORS AND LABORATORIES WITH NO MORE THAN A 5% ERROR RATE; INCREASING THE PERCENTAGE OF LABORATORY RESULTS RECEIVED ELECTRONICALLY. DECREASED ERRORS ALLOW FOR GREATER IDENTIFICATION OF GEOGRAPHIC AREAS AND POPULATIONS AT HIGH-RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE HAZARDS. THE WVCLPPP WILL CONTINUE TO ENGAGE THE HIGH-RISK TARGET GEOGRAPHIC AREAS AND POPULATIONS THROUGH EDUCATION AND OUTREACH AT COMMUNITY HEALTH FAIRS, BABY SHOWERS AND OUTDOOR EVENTS. THE WVCLPPP WILL IMPROVE THE KNOWLEDGE OF PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONALS, PARTNERS, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS ABOUT THE IMPLICATIONS OF LEAD POISONING, PRIMARY PREVENTION AND SECONDARY PREVENTION THROUGH TRAINING PROGRAMS AND WORK TOWARD POLICY-BASED INTERVENTIONS. CURRENTLY, THE WVCLPPP PARTNERS WITH OTHER PROGRAMS TO IDENTIFY CHILDREN EXPOSED TO LEAD AND REFER THEM TO APPROPRIATE SERVICES. THE WVCLPPP WILL CONTINUE TO STRENGTHEN THESE PARTNERSHIPS TO DETERMINE ADDITIONAL STRATEGIES TARGETED TO MEET PROGRAM OUTCOMES.

CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM IN MICHIGAN - THE MICHIGAN CLPPP HAS BEEN IN EXISTENCE SINCE 1998 AND HAS PROVIDED STATEWIDE SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS AND REFERRALS OF CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS (EBLL) SINCE ITS INCEPTION. EFFORTS OF CLPPP AND PARTNERS HAS HELPED TO REDUCE THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN WITH EBLL ?5?G/DL BY 86.5%, BUT SIGNIFICANT WORK REMAINS TO BE DONE DUE TO THE AVERAGE AGE OF THE HOUSING STOCK AND THE SIGNIFICANT NUMBER OF CHILDREN LIVING BELOW THE POVERTY LINE IN MICHIGAN. CLPPP ALSO WORKS CLOSELY WITH PARTNERS IN DETROIT INCLUDING THE DETROIT HEALTH DEPARTMENT TO ADDRESS THE LARGE BURDEN OF LEAD WITHIN THE COMMUNITY. EACH YEAR DETROIT CHILDREN ACCOUNT FOR 33% OF ALL EBLL CASES IN MICHIGAN WITH 1299 CHILDREN IDENTIFIED IN 2019 ALONE. EFFORTS IN DETROIT HAVE BEEN SUCCESSFUL IN DECREASING THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN WITH EBLL, BUT THE NEED FOR ADDITIONAL EMPHASIS ON PRIMARY PREVENTION HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED, COVERED IN COMPONENT B.COMPONENT A:THE MICHIGAN CLPPP IS APPLYING FOR THE FULL COMPONENT A FUNDING TO ENSURE THE PROGRAM MAINTAINS AND ENHANCES STATEWIDE SCREENING AND TESTING, ROBUST BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE, AND LINKAGES TO SERVICES INCLUDING NURSING CASE MANAGEMENT AND EDUCATION EFFORTS FOR CHILDREN WITH EBLLS. SPECIFIC FOCUS WILL BE ON IDENTIFYING AND ADDRESSING DISPARITIES IN TESTING AND EBLL BY RACE AND ETHNICITY, AS WELL AS CHILDREN ENROLLED IN MEDICAID. COMPONENT BTHE MICHIGAN CLPPP IS APPLYING FOR THE FULL FUNDING AWARD FOR COMPONENT B TO DEVELOP SPECIFIC PROGRAM AND POLICY ACTIVITIES DEDICATED TO DETROIT INCLUDING ESTABLISHING A COMMUNITY-BASED COALITION, PILOTING A PROJECT TO INCREASE ELIGIBILITY FOR HOME LEAD ABATEMENT WORK, AND INCREASING BLOOD LEAD TESTING IN ACCORDANCE WITH DETROIT UNIVERSAL TESTING ORDINANCE WHICH WILL ASSIST CLPPP IN IDENTIFYING HIGH-RISK AREAS OF DETROIT. THESE PROJECTS WILL AIM TO REDUCE EXPOSURE TO LEAD, IMPROVE HOUSING CONDITIONS, COORDINATE EFFORTS AMONG LOCAL AGENCIES, PROVIDE INCREASED EDUCATION AND OUTREACH TO HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS AND COMMUNITIES, AND PROVIDE DEDICATED SUPPORT TO THE LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENT AND OTHER DETROIT ORGANIZATIONS TO DECREASE THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS AND ENSURE ALL CHILDREN WITH EBLL ARE AFFORDED COMPLETE CARE AND FOLLOW-UP. SUCCESS OF THESE PROJECTS WILL ASSIST CLPPP IN ESTABLISHING DETROIT AS A MODEL FOR CREATING A LEAD SAFE COMMUNITY.PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE OUTCOMES?IMPROVED BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING RATES FOR CHILDREN <6 YEARS OF AGE AT RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE.?IMPROVED USE OF SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM DATA TO CAPTURE MISSING DATA ON CHILD DEMOGRAPHIC AND FOLLOW-UP INFORMATION.?IMPROVED RATES OF CHILDREN <6 YEARS OF AGE WITH EBLL LINKED TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES.?DECREASED DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BY RACE/ETHNICITY AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS. ?INCREASED COLLABORATION AND COORDINATION BETWEEN APPROPRIATE STAKEHOLDERS.?INCREASE AWARENESS OF PEDIATRIC HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS AND CLINICAL LABORATORIES OF STATE BLOOD LEAD TESTING RECOMMENDATIONS AND REPORTING REQUIREMENTS.?INCREASE IDENTIFICATION OF GEOGRAPHIC AREAS AND POPULATIONS AT-RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE USING ENHANCED DATA LINKAGES.?IMPROVED POLICIES FOR TARGETED COMMUNITY-BASED APPROACHES AIMED AT PRIMARY PREVENTION OF LEAD EXPOSURE IN CHILDREN?DECREASED LEAD HAZARDS IN HOUSING OCCUPIED BY VULNERABLE POPULATIONS?DECREASED NUMBER OF CHILDREN LIVING IN ENVIRONMENTS AT HIGH RISK OF LEAD EXPOSURE

LOUISIANA CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN - LHHCLPPP PROJECT ABSTRACT-ACCORDING TO THE CDC, SIGNIFICANT PROGRESS HAS BEEN MADE IN REDUCING POPULATION EXPOSURES TO LEAD IN THE UNITED STATES DUE, IN LARGE PART, TO SUCCESSFUL POLICIES AIMED AT THE REMOVAL OF LEAD IN GASOLINE AND CONTROL OF LEAD IN RESIDENTIAL PAINT AND CONSUMER PRODUCTS.  YOUNG CHILDREN ARE PARTICULARLY VULNERABLE TO THE LONG-TERM HEALTH AND DEVELOPMENTAL EFFECTS OF LEAD EXPOSURE INCLUDING INTELLECTUAL AND BEHAVIORAL DEFICITS. THE PRIMARY SOURCE OF LEAD EXPOSURE TO CHILDREN IS THE HOME ENVIRONMENT. TWENTY-FOUR MILLION HOMES HAVE SIGNIFICANT LEAD-BASED PAINT HAZARDS AND AT LEAST 6-10 MILLION HOMES HAVE LEAD SERVICE LINES THAT MAY RESULT IN EXPOSURE TO LEAD FROM DRINKING WATER. LOW-INCOME AND MINORITY CHILDREN BEAR A DISPROPORTIONATE BURDEN OF THIS CONDITION CAUSED BY UNHEALTHY HOUSING. PURPOSE AND OUTCOMES-COMPONENT A: LOUISIANA IS A DIVERSE STATE WITH ITS OWN SET OF UNIQUE CHALLENGES AND OPPORTUNITIES. THE STATE CONTINUES TO STRUGGLE WITH INCREASING NUMBERS OF AT RISK AND VULNERABLE POPULATIONS. THE 2020 LOUISIANA ASSET LIMITED, INCOME CONSTRAINED, EMPLOYED (ALICE) REPORT4 REVEALS 33% OF ALL LOUISIANA HOUSEHOLDS ARE ALICE AND ANOTHER 18% LIVE BELOW FEDERAL POVERTY LEVEL. TOGETHER, 51% OF ALL LOUISIANA HOUSEHOLDS CANNOT AFFORD BASIC EXPENSES – HOUSING, CHILD CARE, FOOD, TRANSPORTATION, HEALTH CARE, AND TAXES (BELOW ALICE THRESHOLD). THERE WERE GROUPS WITH DISPROPORTIONAL HIGH PERCENTAGE OF FAMILIES BELOW ALICE THRESHOLD SUCH AS BLACK FAMILIES (70%) OR SINGLE-FEMALE-HEADED FAMILIES WITH CHILDREN (87%). THE PURPOSE OF LHHCLPPP’S APPLICATION FOR FUNDING IS TO IMPROVE BLOOD LEAD TESTING RATES, IDENTIFY HIGH-RISK POPULATIONS AND ENSURE EFFECTIVE FOLLOW-UP FOR CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLLS. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY IMPLEMENTING PROGRAM STRATEGIES THAT WILL INCREASE THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE WHO ARE SCREENED FOR LEAD BY THE DEVELOPMENT OF A STATEWIDE SCREENING AND TESTING PLAN. LHHCLPPP WILL IMPROVE BLOOD LEA D SURVEILLANCE SYSTEMS TO ADDRESS THE CAUSES, RISK FACTORS OF DISEASE AT THE SOURCE, IMPROVE DATA USAGE TO IDENTIFY GEOGRAPHIC HIGH RISK AREAS, PREVALENCE OF ELEVATED BLLS BY RACE/ETHNICITY AND SES STATUS. LHHCLPPP WILL ENSURE A STATEWIDE SYSTEM OF CARE THAT IDENTIFIES, REFERS AND MONITORS CHILDREN EXPOSED TO LEAD. LHHCLPPP WILL LINK AFFECTED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES AND REPORT ALL BLOOD LEAD DATA TO CDC IN A TIMELY AND EFFICIENT MANNER. IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PROGRAM STRATEGIES IN THIS NARRATIVE WILL LEAD TO THE OUTCOMES LISTED BELOW: - IMPROVED BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING RATES FOR CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS (72 MONTHS) OF AGE AT RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE. - DECREASED DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BY RACE/ETHNICITY AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS. - IMPROVED USE OF SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM DATA TO CAPTURE MISSING DATA ON CHILD DEMOGRAPHIC AND FOLLOW-UP INFORMATION. - IMPROVED RATES OF CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS LINKED TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES. PURPOSE AND OUTCOMES-COMPONENT B: THE PURPOSE OF LHHCLPPP’S APPLICATION FOR FUNDING IS TO IMPLEMENT COMPONENT B OF THE 2021 CDC NOFO WHICH IS TO DEVELOP TARGETED POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS FOR LOCAL JURISDICTIONS. THE PRIMARY OUTCOME OF COMPONENT B IS TO DEVELOP STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS AND POLICIES TO IMPLEMENT TARGETED, POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS AIMED AT PRIMARY PREVENTION OF LEAD EXPOSURES FOCUSING ON COMMUNITY-BASED APPROACHES FOR LEAD HAZARD ELIMINATION. LHHCLPPP WILL STRENGTHEN PARTNERSHIPS WITH KEY STAKEHOLDERS FROM COMMUNITY- BASED ORGANIZATIONS, HOUSING PARTNERS (I.E. HOUSING NOLA) FAITH-BASED INSTITUTIONS (PEOPLES UMC), HEAD START CENTERS, WIC, HOUSING AGENCIES AND HUD LEAD HAZARD CONTROL GRANTEES, ENVIRONMENTAL TRACKING PROGRAM SOIL SHOP TO ESTABLISH THE LHHCLPPP-COMMUNITY ACTION NETWORK (CAN) TEAMS. THESE CAN TEAMS WILL IMPLEMENT TARGETED, POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS AIMED AT PRIMARY

PREVENTING LEAD POISONING IN PHILADELPHIA THROUGH SURVEILLANCE, EDUCATION, AND ENFORCEMENT - CITY OF PHILADELPHIADEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTHLEAD AND HEALTHY HOMES PROGRAMAPPLICATION FOR: CDC RFA-EH21-2102CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN  PROJECT TITLE:THE PHILADELPHIA PROJECT: PREVENTING LEAD POISONING IN PHILADELPHIA THROUGH SURVEILLANCE, EDUCATION AND ENFORCEMENT  THE PHILADELPHIA DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH (PDPH) LEAD AND HEALTHY HOMES PROGRAM (LHHP) HAS OVER FORTY YEARS OF EXPERIENCE IMPROVING CONDITIONS WHICH CAUSE CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING THROUGH EDUCATION, HAZARD REMEDIATION AND ENFORCEMENT OF HOUSING CODES.  WE HAVE REDUCED THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN WITH AN ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVEL OF 10 ?G/DL OR HIGHER TO 324 IN 2019, EXPANDING OUR MISSION TO ADDRESS THOSE CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BETWEEN 5 AND 9 ?G/DL.  HOWEVER, OUR GOAL OF ERADICATING LEAD POISONING REMAINS ELUSIVE.  MANY OF PHILADELPHIA?S CHILDREN ARE SPENDING INCREASED TIME IN BUILDINGS HOUSING CHILDCARE ESTABLISHMENTS WITH CHIPPING AND PEELING PAINT DUE TO AGE, DEFERRED OR POOR MAINTENANCE, UNSAFE REMEDIATION OR WEAR AND TEAR ON HIGH FRICTION AND IMPACT AREAS SUCH AS DOORS AND WINDOWS CREATING POISONOUS LEAD DUST.  WE RECOGNIZE THAT THERE IS NO SAFE LEVEL OF LEAD AND THAT MORE WORK NEEDS TO BE DONE.ALSO OF CONCERN ARE THE BLOOD LEAD SCREENING RATES, WHICH HAVE DROPPED SIGNIFICANTLY OVER THE PAST YEAR DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.  THE LHHP PROJECT, PREVENTING LEAD POISONING IN PHILADELPHIA THROUGH SURVEILLANCE, EDUCATION AND ENFORCEMENT WILL PROVIDE INDIVIDUALLY TARGETED EDUCATION ON THE IMPORTANCE OF BLOOD LEAD SCREENING AND COMMUNITY-LEVEL EDUCATION AND ADVOCACY ON THE ELIMINATION OF LEAD HAZARD EXPOSURES IN HIGH RISK ZIP CODES, WHICH WILL BE IDENTIFIED USING HEALTH AND HOUSING SURVEILLANCE DATA. WE HAVE ESTABLISHED AN EXPANDED SET OF PARTNERS ? COMMUNITY-BASED AGENCIES, COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATIONS, LEGAL SERVICES AND CHILDCARE PROVIDERS TO DEVELOP SHARED ADVOCACY STRATEGIES INCLUDING PROACTIVE BU ILDING CODE INSPECTION AND ENHANCED CHILDCARE HEALTH CODE REGULATION.THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD ON OUR PREVIOUS ENDEAVORS, INCLUDING CLOSE COLLABORATION WITH COMMUNITY GROUPS AND PARTNERS IN THE TARGETED ZIP CODES TO CREATE A COMMUNITY-SPECIFIC STRATEGIC PLAN TO ADDRESS BLOOD LEAD SCREENING AND LEAD HAZARD EXPOSURE. LHHP WILL PROVIDE VIRTUAL HOME VISITS, WHERE EDUCATION AND HOME HAZARDS ASSESSMENTS WILL BE PROVIDED. COMMUNITY LEVEL EDUCATION WILL BE PROVIDED FOR CHILDCARE STAFF IN THE TARGET ZIP CODES. THE LHHP WILL RECOMMEND THAT CHILDCARE FACILITIES PROACTIVELY OBTAIN LEAD SAFE/LEAD FREE CERTIFICATION.  LASTLY, LHHP WILL ENGAGE OUR COMMUNITY PARTNERS FOR ADVOCACY AND ENFORCEMENT TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH AND SAFETY OF CHILDCARE FACILITIES IN THE TARGET ZIP CODES.

CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN (CDC-RFA-EH21-2102) - THE GOAL OF THIS FIVE-YEAR GRANT IS TO SUPPORT PRIMARY AND SECONDARY PREVENTION STRATEGIES FOR CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE BY ENSURING BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING; ENHANCING BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE; IMPROVING LINKAGES TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES AND DEVELOPING POLICIES FOR TARGETED, POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS WITH A FOCUS ON COMMUNITY-BASED APPROACHES TO REDUCE LEAD EXPOSURES AND LEAD POISONING IN PENNSYLVANIA (PA). PROGRAM STRATEGIES FOCUS ON IMPROVING BLOOD LEAD SCREENING TEST RATES, IDENTIFYING HIGH-RISK POPULATIONS, AND ENSURING EFFECTIVE FOLLOW-UP FOR CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS. OUTCOMES WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES:1.  DEVELOP AND SUSTAIN A STATEWIDE LEAD ADVISORY COMMITTEE.2.  DEVELOP OR UPDATE AN APPROPRIATE STATEWIDE SCREENING PLAN BY IDENTIFYING BARRIERS TO UNIVERSAL TESTING FOR  MEDICAID (MA) ENROLLED CHILDREN AND DEVELOPING STRATEGIES TO ADDRESS THEM. PARTNERING WITH HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS TO ASSESS BARRIERS TO TESTING CHILDREN WHO ARE NOT ENROLLED IN MA.3.  UPDATE AND MAINTAIN A BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM AND IMPLEMENT PLANS FOR SURVEILLANCE DATA COLLECTION,     DATA QUALITY, AND DATA DISSEMINATION.4.  CONDUCT ANALYSIS OF SURVEILLANCE DATA TO IDENTIFY LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN, HIGH-RISK POPULATIONS AND GEOGRAPHIC AREAS.5.  DEVELOP SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM ALERTS TO FLAG AND TRACK CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS (EBLL'S) REQUIRING FOLLOW-UP.6.  CONNECT CHILDREN TO MEDICAL, ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIAL SERVICES BY UTILIZING COLLABORATIVE PARTNERSHIPS TO CONFIRM THAT CHILDREN WITH EBLL'S ARE PROVIDED REFERRALS FOR RECOMMENDED FOLLOW-UP SERVICES AND THEY HAVE RECEIVED FOLLOW-UP SERVICES.  7.  DEVELOP PARTNERSHIPS TO IMPLEMENT TARGETED POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS AIMED AT PRIMARY PREVENTION OF LEAD EXPOSURE WITH A FOCUS ON COMMUNITY-BASED APPROACHES BY ENGAGING THE PUBLIC, LOCAL PARTNERS, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS IN HIGH-RISK GEOGRAPHIES AND POPULATIONS THROUGH O UTREACH AND EDUCATION. THE DEPARTMENT WILL ALSO COORDINATE WITH PARTNERS TO INCREASE CAPACITY FOR LOCAL INTERVENTIONS BY SUPPORTING INFRASTRUCTURE IMPROVEMENT INITIATIVES WITH SMALL COMMUNITY-BASED GRANTS FOR LEAD HAZARD ELIMINATION.

A COMPREHENSIVE APPROACH TO REDUCING CHILDHOOD BLOOD LEAD LEVELS THROUGH EVIDENCE BASED INTERVENTIONS AND SURVEILLANCE - SEVENTY-SEVEN PERCENT OF NEW JERSEY?S HOUSING STOCK WAS BUILT PRIOR TO 1980 INCLUDING 30% BUILT PRIOR TO 1950. NEW JERSEY IS HOME TO A RACIALLY AND ETHNICALLY DIVERSE POPULATION WITH 17.5% BEING FOREIGN BORN PERSONS (US: 11.1%) AND 25.5% OF RESIDENTS 5 YEARS AND OLDER SPEAKING A LANGUAGE OTHER THAN ENGLISH AT HOME (US: 17.9%).  THE NEW JERSEY DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH (NJ DOH) WILL USE CDC FUNDING IN PHASE 1 (YEAR 1) TO FURTHER STRENGTHEN ITS DATA COLLECTION AND DATA SHARING CAPABILITIES AND PARTNERSHIPS.  YEAR 1 EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE THAT MEMORANDUMS OF AGREEMENT (MOAS) AND MEMORANDUMS OF UNDERSTANDING (MOUS) BETWEEN THE NJ DOH AND ITS FEDERAL, STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTAL PARTNERS ARE REVIEWED AND ESTABLISHED, AS APPLICABLE, TO ENFORCE LAWS, TARGET PRIMARY PREVENTION INTERVENTIONS, AND LEVERAGE RESOURCES; HIGHEST-RISK GEOGRAPHIC AREAS, UNDERSERVED HIGH-RISK POPULATIONS, AND EMERGING SOURCES OF LEAD ARE DETERMINED USING GEOMAPPING METHODOLOGIES AND JURISDICTIONAL LEVEL SURVEILLANCE DATA; AND, BENCHMARKS AND STRATEGIC GOALS ARE SET TO IDENTIFY LEAD POISONED CHILDREN AND THE QUALITY OF SERVICES THEY RECEIVE FROM LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENTS. PHASE 2 (YEARS 2,3, 4, AND 5) WILL FOCUS ON DATA DRIVEN PRIMARY PREVENTION INITIATIVES AT ALL LEVELS OF GOVERNMENT.  THIS WILL BE DONE IN A STRATEGIC WAY THAT INCLUDES INPUT FROM CULTURALLY DIVERSE COMMUNITY REPRESENTATIVES.  STRATEGIES AND ACTIVITIES IN PHASE 2 WILL BE BASED UPON THE NATIONAL PREVENTION STRATEGY: HEALTHY AND SAFE COMMUNITY ENVIRONMENTS.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE:  CONVENING DIVERSE PARTNERS AND FACILITATING COLLABORATION AMONG DIVERSE SECTORS WHEN PLANNING, IMPLEMENTING, AND EVALUATING COMMUNITY HEALTH EFFORTS AND/OR WHEN MAKING DECISIONS LIKELY TO HAVE A SIGNIFICANT EFFECT ON HEALTH;  ACTIVELY INVOLVING MEMBERS OF THE SOUTH ASIAN (PRIMARILY INDIAN) AND HISPANIC (PRIMARILY MEXICAN AND DOMINICAN REPUBLICAN) COMMUNITIES IN PROGRAM PLANNING;  INCORPORATING HEALTHY HOMES ASSESSMENTS AND RELATED REFERRAL S INTO DIRECT SERVICES PROVISION; AND INCREASING THE NUMBER OF PEOPLE WHO HAVE BEEN TRAINED IN LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND HEALTHY HOMES, USE RELEVANT ASSESSMENTS AND MAKE RELATED REFERRALS.  BY THE END OF THE PROJECT PERIOD, THE NJ DOH EXPECTS THAT THE PERCENTAGE OF CHILDREN AGED 1-5 YEARS WHO HAVE AN INITIAL BLOOD LEAD LEVEL >/=10 ?G/DL WILL DROP FROM 0.5% TO 0.3% (HEALTHY NJ 2020 TARGET IS 0.9%) AND THAT THE MEAN BLOOD LEAD LEVEL IS REDUCED FROM 1.7  ?G/DL TO 1. 2 ?G/DL (HEALTHY NJ 2020 TARGET IS 3.4 ?G/DL).

FLORIDA'S RESPONSE TO ADDRESS CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS - IN ORDER TO PREVENT CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING, THE FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH WOULD USE THIS GRANT TO ACHIEVETHESE OUTCOMES:1) REDUCED DISPARITIES IN CHILDREN <6 YEARS OLD WITH LEAD POISONING BASED ON RACE, ETHNICITY, OR SOCIOECONOMICSTATUS2) SUSTAINABLE LONG-TERM INFRASTRUCTURE TO IDENTIFY AND TRACK CHILDREN WITH LEAD POISONING AND CHILDREN EXPOSEDTO LEAD3) INCREASED NUMBERS OF CHILDREN TESTED FOR BLOOD LEAD4) IMPROVED DATA USAGE LEADING TO BETTER IDENTIFICATION OF GEOGRAPHIC AREAS AND POPULATIONS AT HIGHER RISK FORLEAD EXPOSURE5) INCREASED ABILITY TO TARGET INTERVENTIONS (E.G., EDUCATION AND OUTREACH) TO HIGH-RISK GEOGRAPHIC AREAS ANDPOPULATIONS6) INCREASED KNOWLEDGE AND AWARENESS OF PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONALS, LEAD PREVENTION WORKFORCE, PARTNERS, ANDOTHER STAKEHOLDERS ABOUT LEAD PREVENTION AND INTERVENTIONS THROUGH LEAD PREVENTION TRAINING PROGRAMS.

PREVENTING CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING IN OREGON - PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYTHE OREGON HEALTH AUTHORITY?S CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (CLPPP) IS APPLYING FOR THE CDC FUNDING OPPORTUNITY, CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EXPAND AND ENHANCE CLPPP?S CONTINUED EFFORTS TO ASSURE THE CORE PUBLIC HEALTH FUNCTIONS OF CHILDHOOD BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND SURVEILLANCE ARE MET IN A TIMELY MANNER, TO IMPROVE DATA COLLECTION IN AN EFFORT TO REDUCE HEALTH DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN, AND TO ENSURE EFFECTIVE FOLLOW-UP AND IMPROVE LINKAGES TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES FOR CHILDREN EXPOSED TO LEAD. ALONG WITH THESE SECONDARY PREVENTION MEASURES, CLPPP WILL ALSO ENGAGE IN PRIMARY PREVENTION ACTIVITIES THROUGH TARGETED OUTREACH AND EDUCATION TO HIGH-RISK POPULATIONS AND COMMUNITIES ACROSS OREGON. THESE EFFORTS WILL INCLUDE CULTURALLY AND LINGUISTICALLY APPROPRIATE COMMUNITY-BASED EDUCATION THAT IS SPECIFIC TO THE PARTICIPANTS AND IS BASED ON LOCAL SURVEILLANCE AND RISK VULNERABILITY DATA AND IN COLLABORATION WITH TRUSTED ORGANIZATIONS AND COMMUNITY LEADERS. CLPPP HAS MANY PARTNERS ALREADY COMMITTED TO WORKING WITH THE PROGRAM TO IMPROVE DATA COLLECTION AND SURVEILLANCE AND TO FURTHER REDUCE CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING IN THE STATE. CLPPP WILL USE THESE PARTNERSHIPS TO: IMPROVE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING FOR CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE AT RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE; IMPROVE THE PROGRAM?S SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM DATA TO CAPTURE MISSING RACE, ETHNICITY, AND SOCIOECONOMIC DATA; IMPROVE REFERRAL RATES TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES FOR CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE WHOSE BLOOD LEAD LEVELS ARE ABOVE THE CDC REFERENCE VALUE; AND DECREASE DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BY RACE, ETHNICITY AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS. CLPPP WILL ACHIEVE THESE OUTCOMES THROUGH A VARIETY OF ACTIVITIES THAT ARE BOTH ONGOING AND NEW FOR THE PROGRAM. THESE ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: DEVELOPING AND HOSTING ITS FIRST LEAD ADVISORY COMMITTEE SINCE 2 016; UPDATING THE CURRENT STATEWIDE LEAD SCREENING/TESTING PLAN AND RISK QUESTIONNAIRE BASED ON LOCAL DATA; UPDATING AND IMPROVING THE ORPHEUS SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM AND CASE MANAGEMENT PROTOCOLS TO TRACK AND MONITOR REFERRALS TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES FOR CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS; PROVIDING FEEDBACK TO THE HEALTHCARE COMMUNITY ON COMPLIANCE WITH BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING REQUIREMENTS; COLLECTING RACE, ETHNICITY, AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS FROM HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS AND THROUGH DATA LINKAGES WITH OTHER STATE AGENCIES AND STAKEHOLDERS; AND PARTNERING WITH COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS TO PROVIDE LEAD POISONING PREVENTION EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR FAMILIES AT HIGH RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE.

STATE OF ALASKA/CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN - UNDER THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT, THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND SOCIAL SERVICES, ENVIRONMENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH PROGRAM (EPHP), DEMONSTRATES ITS UNDERSTANDING OF THIS CDC COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT?S GOALS AND OBJECTIVES TO PROTECT CHILDREN FROM LEAD EXPOSURE BY 1) ENSURING BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING; 2) ENHANCING BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE; 3) IMPROVING LINKAGES OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES; AND 4) DEVELOPING TARGETED, POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS. EPHP HIGHLIGHTS PLANS TO ENGAGE IN OUTREACH AND EDUCATION TO PREVENT CHILDHOOD LEAD EXPOSURE IN ORDER TO IMPROVE BLOOD LEAD SCREENING RATES FOR CHILDREN UNDER 6 YEARS OF AGE IN ALASKA AND TO OVERCOME BARRIERS OF ACCESS TO HEALTH CARE SERVICES. EPHP DESCRIBES WHY AND HOW THEY ARE UNIQUELY QUALIFIED TO ADDRESS LEAD PREVENTION IN ALASKA AND HOW THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL BE AN EFFECTIVE MECHANISM FOR ADDRESSING THE HEALTH CONCERNS OF ALASKAN CHILDREN WITH POTENTIAL EXPOSURE TO LEAD

CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN - THE CHICAGO DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH (CDPH) WILL FOCUS ON SERVING CHILDREN THE AGES OF SIX AND UNDER WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEVELS AND THEIR FAMILIES (INCLUDING PREGNANT WOMEN). WE WILL MONITOR, FOLLOW UP AND PROVIDE EDUCATION, TESTING AND CASE MANAGEMENT TO FAMILIES AND EARLY LEARNING CENTERS. WE WILL ALSO UPDATE AND ALIGN POLICIES AND PROCEDURES FOR THE ENTIRE CITY OF CHICAGO AS IT RELATES TO CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING AND PREVENTION. CDPH WILL DEVELOP CURRICULA AND PLAN A ONE-DAY LEAD CONFERENCE. CDPH WILL PROVIDE CONTINUING EDUCATION CREDITS AND TRAINING IN LEAD POISONING PREVENTION TO CHICAGO PEDIATRICIANS. WE WILL HAVE TARGETED MARKETING MATERIALS INCLUDING BILLBOARDS IN DIFFERENT COMMUNITY AREAS. WE WILL STRENGTHEN OUR COMMUNITY PARTNERS AND IMPLEMENT TARGETED POPULATION INTERVENTIONS.  CDPH WILL PROVIDE APPROPRIATE CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION EDUCATION AND RESOURCES FOR FAMILIES AND COMMUNITIES WITH THE CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN GRANT.

CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN IN WA STATE - WE PROPOSE TO REDUCE HEALTH DISPARITIES AND IMPROVE HEALTH EQUITY ASSOCIATED WITH CHILDHOOD LEAD EXPOSURE AND POISONING IN WASHINGTON STATE THROUGH FOCUSED AND INTENTIONAL EFFORTS AROUND (1) INCREASING BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, (2) ENHANCING SURVEILLANCE AND DATA QUALITY TO BETTER IDENTIFY HIGH RISK POPULATIONS, AND (3) ENSURING EFFECTIVE FOLLOW-UP AND LINKAGES TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES FOR CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS. TO ACCOMPLISH THESE OBJECTIVES WE WILL BUILD A DIVERSE LEAD ADVISORY COMMITTEE, DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAM PLANS FOCUSED ON EVIDENCE-BASED STRATEGIES AND ACTIVITIES, DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT AN EVALUATION AND PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT PLAN, AND LEVERAGE EXISTING AND NEW PARTNERSHIPS AND COLLABORATIONS TO ENSURE BROAD REACH AND IMPACT, ESPECIALLY AMONG DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED POPULATIONS.

CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN INCLUDING BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, SURVEILLANCE, AND LINKAGES OF LEAD EXPOSED CHILDREN TO SERVICES. - IN RESPONDING TO CDC-RFA-EH21-2102 NOFO, ?CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN?, THE TENNESSEE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH REQUESTS $350,000.00 TO FUND STRATEGIES AND ACTIVITIES THAT WILL 1) ENSURE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING 2)ENHANCE BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE; AND 3)IMPROVE LINKAGES OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES . BY THE END OF THE PROJECT PERIOD, THE TN CLPPP WILL IMPROVE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING RATES FOR CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE AT RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE, IMPROVE USE OF SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM DATA TO CAPTURE MISSING DATA ON CHILD DEMOGRAPHIC AND FOLLOW-UP INFORMATION, IMPROVE RATES OF CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE WHO MEET TENNESSEE STATE CASE DEFINITIONS AND ARE REFERRED TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES, AND DECREASE DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BY RACE/ETHNICITY AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUSAMONG THE FUNDS REQUESTED, $117,559.00 WILL SUPPORT THE SALARY AND FRINGE BENEFITS FOR A PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR AND PROGRAM DIRECTOR (1.0 FTE) AND AN EPIDEMIOLOGIST I (1.0 FTE). THE PROGRAM DIRECTOR WILL SERVE MULTIPLE ROLES INCLUDING THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR AND PROJECT DIRECTOR TO ADMINISTER THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT, EVALUATION AND PERFORMANCE MONITORING WILL BE OVERSEEN BY THE PROGRAM DIRECTOR AND IN COLLABORATION WITH THE EPIDEMIOLOGIST.  A FULL TIME EPIDEMIOLOGIST I WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE SURVEILLANCE AND DATA MANAGEMENT TASKS OUTLINED IN THE FUNDING NOTICE. THIS POSITION WILL ASSURE THE QUALITY AND INTEGRITY OF TN CLPPP QUARTERLY DATA SUBMISSIONS, CONDUCT PROGRAM EVALUATION ACTIVITIES, PERFORM STATISTICAL DATA ANALYSES, PREPARE DOCUMENTS AND REPORTS, DISSEMINATE FINDINGS TO PROGRAM STAFF AND STAKEHOLDERS, AND DEVELOP NEW DATA PROCESSES, AS INDICATED. AN AMOUNT OF $142,000.00 IS REQUESTED TO COVER CONTRACTUAL COSTS INCLUDING THE INCREASED HOURS AVAILABLE FOR 1) A HEALTH SPECIALIST IN CHATTANOOGA HAMILTON COUNTY TO OUTREACH/EDUCATION REGARDING BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND RE FERRALS TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES INCLUDING LEAD EDUCATION STATION; 2) UT EXT WILL BE PARTIALLY SUPPORTED BY THE CDC GRANT FOR MAINTENANCE OF THE LEADTRK SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM. THE PERSONNEL INCLUDES AN ENVIRONMENTAL SPECIALIST THAT WILL PROVIDE STAKEHOLDERS AND PRIMARY CARE PROVIDERS, TRAINING, DEVELOPMENT OF AN EXPERT WORKGROUP TO DEVELOP A STATEWIDE SCREENING PLAN, AND A PILOT PROJECT WITH A PROVIDER TO IDENTIFY BARRIERS/CHALLENGES REGARDING BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING OF ALL REQUIRED DATA VARIABLES; ASSIST IN THE COORDINATION OF THE ADVISORY COMMITTEE AND EXPERT WORKGROUP; AND TO PROMOTE SCREENING AND FOLLOW-UP WITH MEDICAL PROVIDERS, EARLY INTERVENTION STAFF, AND FAMILIES. THE CONTRACTS PROVIDE THE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH WITH ENVIRONMENTAL EXPERTISE AND LOCAL SUPPORT THAT DOES NOT EXIST WITHIN THE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH, DIVISION OF FAMILY HEALTH AND WELLNESS.

A COMMUNITY-BASED APPROACH TO IMPROVING LEAD SAFETY IN SNOHOMISH COUNTY - CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING IS ARGUABLY ONE OF THE MOST PERSISTENT AND DELETERIOUS ENVIRONMENTAL HAZARDS IN THE UNITED STATES. OUR REGION IS UNFORTUNATELY HOME TO NUMEROUS LEAD HAZARDS, INCLUDING AN INDUSTRIAL WASTE SITE CONTAMINATED WITH LEAD AND OTHER TOXINS AND A SIGNIFICANT NUMBER OF HOMES BUILT PRIOR TO 1978. DESPITE THE IRREVERSIBLE EFFECTS OF LEAD POISONING ON A CHILD?S GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT, LITTLE WORK HAS BEEN DONE TO PREVENT LEAD EXPOSURE OR TO ADDRESS LEAD-RELATED HEALTH INEQUITIES IN SNOHOMISH COUNTY, WASHINGTON. A LONG-TERM SHIFT IN AWARENESS AND ATTITUDES ABOUT LEAD SAFETY IS URGENTLY NEEDED IN OUR COMMUNITY. AS THE SNOHOMISH COUNTY HEALTH DISTRICT, OUR MISSION IS TO SPEARHEAD EFFORTS TO PROTECT, PROMOTE, AND ADVANCE THE COLLECTIVE HEALTH OF OUR COMMUNITY.  WE RECOGNIZE THAT THERE IS A SIGNIFICANT NEED IN OUR JURISDICTION TO 1) CONTINUE TO ENSURE THAT CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS (EBLL) ARE LINKED TO APPROPRIATE SERVICES, AND 2) TO COORDINATE CROSS-SECTOR PARTNERSHIPS AIMED AT LEAD HAZARD IDENTIFICATION AND REMOVAL, PARTICULARLY IN ENVIRONMENTS WERE CHILDREN AT HIGHEST RISK LIVE AND PLAY.  IN ALIGNMENT WITH COMPONENT B OF CDC-RFA-EH21-2102, WE WILL ACHIEVE THIS THROUGH MEANINGFUL PARTNERSHIPS WITH HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS, LOCAL HOUSING AUTHORITIES, CHILD CARE PROVIDERS AND REGULATORS, GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, AND THE COMMUNITIES MOST AFFECTED BY LEAD EXPOSURE. PROGRAM ACTIVITIES WILL ENCOMPASS DIRECT LINKAGES TO SERVICES, COMMUNITY-WIDE AWARENESS AND EDUCATION, SUSTAINABLE IMPLEMENTATION OF LEAD-SAFE POLICIES, AND SUPPORT FOR LEAD HAZARD IDENTIFICATION AND REMOVAL. THROUGH THIS COMPREHENSIVE APPROACH, WE AIM TO PRODUCE A SUSTAINABLE INCREASE IN THE RATE OF CHILDREN WITH EBLLS WHO ARE LINKED TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES AND TO DECREASE EBLL DISPARITIES.

PREVENTING CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING WHERE CHILDREN LIVE, LEARN AND PLAY: ADDRESSING CURRENT AND EMERGING SOURCES OF LEAD EXPOSURE IN KING COUNTY COMMUNITIES - THE LEAD AND TOXICS PROGRAM (LTP) PROPOSAL, ?PREVENTING CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING WHERE CHILDREN LIVE, LEARN AND PLAY: ADDRESSING CURRENT AND EMERGING SOURCES OF LEAD EXPOSURE IN KING COUNTY COMMUNITIES? WILL REDUCE HEALTH INEQUITIES WITH COMMUNITY-DRIVEN INTERVENTIONS TO PREVENT LEAD POISONING AND IMPROVE LINKAGES TO DEVELOPMENTAL SERVICES FOR LEAD POISONED CHILDREN THROUGH STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS WITH COMMUNITIES OF COLOR. COMMUNITIES OF COLOR HAVE LONG BEEN CHARTING THE PATH FORWARD ON ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE AND OUR PROGRAM PARTNERS DRIVE THE WORK TO PREVENT LEAD EXPOSURE IN HOME, SCHOOL, AND CHILDCARE ENVIRONMENTS. THE LTP PROPOSAL IS DESIGNED TO IMPROVE HEALTH EQUITY AMONG PEOPLE OF COLOR, IMMIGRANTS AND REFUGEES IN SOUTH SEATTLE AND SOUTH KING COUNTY ? AN AREA OF KING COUNTY WITH THE HIGHEST RATES OF POVERTY AND ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN. OUR PROPOSED STRATEGIES ARE THE RESULT OF MORE THAN 3 YEARS OF LISTENING TO AND LEARNING FROM OUR PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS, REVIEW OF COMMUNITY HEALTH DATA, READINESS AND EXPERIENCE OF OUR COMMUNITY PARTNERS, AND COORDINATION WITH LOCAL AND STATE COMMUNITY HEALTH IMPROVEMENT INITIATIVES. PROPOSED ACTIVITIES TO PREVENT LEAD POISONING, INCREASE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REDUCE HEALTH INEQUITIES BUILD ON THE SUCCESS OF ESTABLISHED COMMUNITY-LED STAKEHOLDER GROUPS COMMITTED TO WORKING ON LEAD-RELATED ISSUES. OUR PARTNERS WILL LEAD THREE COMMUNITY ?ACTION GROUPS?: 1) MEDICAL PROVIDER EDUCATION AND OUTREACH (INCREASE BLOOD LEAD TESTING), 2) PRODUCTS (LEAD POISONING PREVENTION), AND HEALTHY HOUSING (LEAD POISONING PREVENTION). SELECTED COMMUNITY LEADERS FROM THESE ACTION GROUPS WILL ALSO PROVIDE INPUT TO THE STATEWIDE LEAD ADVISORY COMMITTEE TO HELP DRIVE POLICY CHANGE AND CHAMPION COMMITTEE ACTIVITIES AT THE LOCAL LEVEL. PROPOSED STRATEGIES TO IMPROVE LINKAGES OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES BUILD ON KING COUNTY-FUNDED PROGRAMS TO INTEGRATED BLOOD LEAD SCREENING STATUS INTO INTAKE FOR EARLY  SUPPORT FOR INFANT AND TODDLER (ESIT), HOME VISITOR, AND NURSE FAMILY PARTNERSHIP PROGRAM SERVICES. THESE SERVICE PROVIDERS ARE WELL PLACED TO PROVIDE EFFECTIVE REFERRALS FOR BLOOD LEAD TESTING, DEVELOPMENTAL SERVICES, AND TO ASSESS LEAD EXPOSURE RISK OF THE FAMILY FROM HOUSING SOURCES. THE HEALTHCARE ACTION GROUP WILL WORK TO STRENGTHEN PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN FOCUS COMMUNITIES AND MEDICAL PROVIDERS TO INFORM STRATEGIES TO INCREASE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND INCREASE PROVIDER EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES ABOUT LEAD RISKS, EXPOSURE SOURCES, AND RESOURCES FOR IMPACTED FAMILIES.THIS FOCUSED, COMMUNITY-DRIVEN APPROACH WILL ACCELERATE LOCAL CHANGES TO INCREASE BLOOD LEAD TESTING, IMPROVE ACCESS TO DEVELOPMENTAL SERVICES, AND PREVENT CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING FROM PRODUCTS USED IN FOCUS COMMUNITIES. PRODUCT TESTING DATA WILL BE SHARED WITH THE CDC CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (CLPPP) AND WILL INFORM THE NATIONAL CONVERSATION ABOUT SYSTEMS AND POLICIES NEEDED TO ELIMINATE THESE PRODUCTS FROM OUR COMMUNITIES. LTP WILL SUSTAIN ITS IMPACT BY LEVERAGING CURRENT AND FUTURE INITIATIVES IN KING COUNTY AND CONTINUE TO WORK WITH OUR STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH TO IMPROVE LOCAL SURVEILLANCE ACTIVITIES AND TO SUPPORT THE WORK OF THE NEWLY FUNDED STATEWIDE LEAD ADVISORY COMMITTEE.

CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN - LEAD POISONING REMAINS A SIGNIFICANT PUBLIC HEALTH PROBLEM IN NEW YORK STATE (NYS). THE NYS DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH (NYSDOH) CONTINUES TO INVEST SUBSTANTIALLY IN SECONDARY AND PRIMARY PREVENTION PROGRAMS, AND AS A RESULT, THE NUMBER OF CASES OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING HAS STEADILY DECLINED SINCE 1998. DESPITE THESE IMPORTANT GAINS, NYS CONTINUES TO HAVE THE GREATEST NUMBER OF CASES OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING IN THE NATION. FROM 2016 THROUGH 2019, BLOOD LEAD TESTS IN NYS IDENTIFIED AN ANNUAL AVERAGE OF 13,893 CHILDREN UNDER AGE SIX WITH BLOOD LEAD LEVELS (BLLS) AT OR ABOVE THE CDC REFERENCE VALUE OF 5?G/DL, A RATE OF 16.5 PER 1000 TESTED STATEWIDE (INCLUDING ALL TEST TYPES). THOUSANDS MORE ARE LIKELY TO BE AT RISK GIVEN THE PREVALENCE OF ASSOCIATED RISK FACTORS IN NYS (E.G., POVERTY, OLD AND DETERIORATING HOUSING STOCK). THE FINANCIAL IMPACT OF NYS?S HIGH BURDEN OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING IS SOBERING. EVIDENCE SUGGESTS THAT THE SOCIETAL COSTS OF LEAD POISONING ON LIFETIME EARNINGS, TAX REVENUE, EDUCATIONAL SERVICES AND JUVENILE JUSTICE SYSTEM GREATLY OUTWEIGH THE COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH REMEDIATING LEAD POISONING HAZARDS. NYS HAS ADDRESSED THESE NEEDS BY MAINTAINING A COMPREHENSIVE INTERACTIVE STATEWIDE BLOOD LEAD REGISTRY AND SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM, AND INVESTING IN STATEWIDE LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAMS FOR CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS (EBLLS), INCLUDING TWO PRIMARY PREVENTION PROGRAMS TARGETED TO HIGH-RISK COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE STATE. THESE PROGRAMS ARE SUPPORTED BY A SIGNIFICANT INVESTMENT OF NYS FUNDING, AS WELL AS LAWS AND REGULATIONS MANDATING UNIVERSAL TESTING AND APPROPRIATE FOLLOW-UP CARE FOR CHILDREN WITH EBLLS AND DEFINING REQUIREMENTS FOR LABORATORY REPORTING AND THE ASSESSMENT AND REMEDIATION OF LEAD HAZARDS. THIS PUBLIC HEALTH APPROACH HAS CONTRIBUTED GREATLY TO THE DECLINE IN CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING IN NYS OVER THE PAST 20 YEARS, BUT IN MANY COMMUNITIES, LEAD POISONING PERSISTS AS A MAJOR THREAT TO CHILD DEVELOPMENT  AND EDUCATIONAL OUTCOMES. ADDITIONAL AGGRESSIVE ACTION TO INCREASE TESTING RATES AND REDUCE EXPOSURE TO LEAD HAZARDS BEFORE CHILDREN ARE POISONED REMAINS A STATE PUBLIC HEALTH PRIORITY. THE PROPOSED WORK DESCRIBES A COMMUNITY AND SYSTEMS-BASED APPROACH THAT WILL CREATE A MORE SUSTAINABLE AND EFFECTIVE INFRASTRUCTURE TO ADVANCE NYS?S AIM OF ELIMINATING CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING. COMPONENT A.THE PROPOSED WORK IS ORGANIZED AROUND THREE GOALS: ? ENSURING BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING ? ENHANCING BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE ? IMPROVING LINKAGES OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES COMPONENT B.THE PROPOSED WORK IS ORGANIZED AROUND DEVELOPING TARGETED, POPULATION-BASED PRIMARY PREVENTION INTERVENTIONS.  ACTIVITIES PROPOSED TO REACH THIS GOAL INCLUDE: ? EVALUATING AND UPDATING PROCEDURES FOR THE NYS PUBLIC HEALTH LAW-MANDATED CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PRIMARY PREVENTION PROGRAM (CLPPPP) TO ENSURE THAT PRIMARY PREVENTION FUNDS ARE EQUITABLY DISTRIBUTED TO THE MOST AT-RISK COMMUNITIES.? A GIS MAPPING PROJECT TO GUIDE OUR PRIMARY PREVENTION ACTIVITIES AND OUTREACH AND EDUCATION CAMPAIGNS. ? TARGETING COMMUNITIES AT HIGHEST RISK FOR EBLL WITH A MULTIFACETED MEDIA CAMPAIGN. THE OBJECTIVES AND ACTIVITIES OUTLINED UNDER EACH GOAL WILL LEVERAGE NYSDOH?S EXISTING LEAD POISONING PREVENTION INFRASTRUCTURE, CAPITALIZE ON NYSDOH?S IMPRESSIVE NETWORK OF STATE AND LOCAL PARTNERS, TARGET MORE VULNERABLE POPULATIONS IN TERMS OF SES, RACE/ETHNICITY, AND/OR REFUGEE STATUS FOR PRIMARY PREVENTION ACTIVITIES, AND BUILD A MORE SUSTAINABLE, EFFECTIVE AND COHESIVE SYSTEM FOR ELIMINATING CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING.

NEW MEXICO CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM - THE NEW MEXICO CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (NM-CLPPP) SURVEILLANCE ACTIVITIES CONTINUE TO PRODUCE DATA FOR THOSE TESTED AND PROVIDE CASE MANAGEMENT OF THOSE WHO HAVE ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS (REFERENCE LEVEL OF 5 ?G/DL).  THE PURPOSE OF THIS APPLICATION IS TO STRENGTHEN NM?S PRIMARY AND SECONDARY PREVENTION OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PROGRAMS.  THIS WILL BE ACHIEVED BY IMPROVING CORE PUBLIC HEALTH FUNCTIONS, THROUGH TARGETED POPULATION-BASED POLICY INTERVENTIONS WITH A FOCUS ON COMMUNITY-BASED APPROACHES TO ELIMINATE LEAD HAZARDS.  THE FOCUS ON IMPROVEMENTS TOWARD INCREASING LOCAL PARTNERSHIPS AND THE GOAL OF INCREASING TESTING RATES WILL, IN TIME, HELP IDENTIFY THE GEOGRAPHIC LOCATIONS OF THE HIGHEST BURDEN OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING IN NM. FURTHER, IT WILL INCREASE AWARENESS ABOUT THE SOURCES OF LEAD EXPOSURE (IN GENERAL AND FOR SPECIFIC LOCATIONS) AND THE IMPORTANCE OF BLOOD-LEAD TESTING TO ENABLE INFORMED POLICY DEVELOPMENT.THE NM PRIORITIZATION MATRIX ALLOWS US TO TARGET THE COUNTIES AND/OR COMMUNITIES THAT ARE AT A HIGHER RISK FOR LEAD POISONING.  WORKING WITH THE ADVISORY COMMITTEE, WE WILL UPDATE/DEVELOP DATA INTERPRETATION AND CONSIDER OTHER POSSIBLE DATA SOURCES THAT WOULD HELP WITH TARGETING POPULATIONS THAT ARE AT-RISK FOR LEAD POISONING.WE PLAN TO INCREASE STATEWIDE INTERVENTIONS BY PROVIDING LEAD HOME ASSESSMENTS FOR THOSE WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS. THIS WILL PROVIDE MUCH NEEDED OUTREACH AND EDUCATION TO REDUCE THE NUMBER OF NM LEAD POISONING HAZARDS DERIVED FROM HOUSING, POTTERY, FOLK REMEDIES, ADULT OCCUPATIONS/INDUSTRY, AND OTHER ENVIRONMENTAL SOURCES.  NM CLPPP PLANS TO ACHIEVE OUTCOMES AND PRODUCE OUTPUTS BY UTILIZING THE PRIORITIZATION MATRIX AND ADVISORY COMMITTEE TO GUIDE AND STRENGTHEN THESE FOUR CORE STRATEGIES, 1) BLOOD-LEAD LEVEL TESTING, 2) STRENGTHENING SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS, 3) STRENGTHEN LINKAGES TO ENSURE LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN RECEIVE RECOMMENDED SERVICES, AND 4) STRENGTHEN TAR GETED POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS.

IDAHO - CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN - CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDRENFOA: CDC-RFA-EH21-2102GRANTEE NAME: IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND WELFAREPROJECT ABSTRACTTHE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND WELFARE, DIVISION OF PUBLIC HEALTH (DIVISION) HAS PRIORITIZED CHILDREN?S HEALTH AND AVOIDING UNINTENTIONAL INJURY AS PART OF THE DIVISION?S STRATEGIC PLAN. TO ADVANCE THIS PRIORITY, THE DIVISION, THROUGH ITS ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH PROGRAM (EHP), REQUESTS $300,000 ANNUALLY FROM THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION (CDC) TO CREATE A CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM FOCUSED ON PRIMARY AND SECONDARY PREVENTION STRATEGIES FOR CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE AND LINKING LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES. CHILDREN EXPOSED TO LEAD ARE VULNERABLE TO LONG-TERM HEALTH AND DEVELOPMENTAL EFFECTS, INCLUDING INTELLECTUAL AND BEHAVIORAL DEFICITS. PRIMARY AND SECONDARY LEAD PREVENTION STRATEGIES, ALONG WITH BLOOD LEAD SCREENING TESTS, WILL REDUCE AND PREVENT ENVIRONMENTAL LEAD HAZARDS AND CONNECT LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO MEDICAL, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND SOCIAL SERVICES TO IMPROVE HEALTH OUTCOMES IN IDAHO.IDAHO RULES REQUIRE PROVIDERS AND LABORATORIES TO REPORT BLOOD LEAD LEVELS GREATER THAN CDC?S REFERENCE VALUES IN CHILDREN AND ADULTS. HOWEVER, THE TOTAL NUMBER OF IDAHO CHILDREN RECEIVING BLOOD LEAD TESTING OR SCREENING WHOSE RESULTS ARE LESS THAN THE CDC?S REFERENCE VALUE IS UNKNOWN. THIS DENOMINATOR DATA IS NEEDED TO REDUCE DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BY RACE/ETHNICITY, SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS, AND GEOGRAPHIC LOCATIONS. EHP WILL DEVELOP AN EXPANDED LEAD SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM AND CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM TO CAPTURE MISSING DATA ON CHILD BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND INCREASE FOLLOW-UP ACTIVITIES. ANTICIPATED LONG-TERM OUTCOMES FROM THIS FUNDING INCLUDE:?DECREASED DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BY RACE/ETHNICITY AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS; ?DECREASED SOCIETAL COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH CHILDHOOD LEAD E XPOSURE;?IMPROVED RATES OF CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS LINKED TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES; ?DECREASED LEAD HAZARDS IN HOUSING OCCUPIED BY VULNERABLE POPULATIONS (SUCH AS CHILDREN). THE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND WELFARE APPRECIATES THIS OPPORTUNITY TO INCREASE LEAD POISONING PREVENTION STRATEGIES FOR IDAHO?S CHILDREN AND ENSURE THAT A COMPREHENSIVE SYSTEM OF IDENTIFICATION, REFERRAL, FOLLOW-UP, AND EVALUATION IS IN PLACE FOR CHILDREN EXPOSED TO LEAD.

MS LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND HEALTHY HOMES - PROBLEM:  LEAD POISONING IS ONE OF THE MOST PREVENTABLE ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH PROBLEMS IN YOUNG CHILDREN.  LEAD IS A COMMON AND HIGHLY TOXIC SUBSTANCE IN THE ENVIRONMENT, AND LEAD POISONING HAS BEEN CAUSED BY THE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF COMMERCIAL PRODUCTS. BETWEEN 2017 AND 2020, THERE WERE APPROXIMATELY 779 CHILDREN LESS THAN 72 MONTHS OF AGE WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS ?5?G/DL IN MISSISSIPPI. GOALS AND OBJECTIVES: THE OBJECTIVES FOR THIS PROJECT ARE TO ENHANCE A COMPREHENSIVE SYSTEM FOR IDENTIFYING ISSUES RELATED TO CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING, ENVIRONMENTAL HAZARDS, AND SAFE HOUSING; AND TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR CHILDREN AND THEIR FAMILIES. LONG-TERM GOALS INCLUDE DECREASING THE ADVERSE HEALTH EFFECTS OF LEAD EXPOSURE AND SOCIETAL COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH CHILDHOOD LEAD EXPOSURE. THE ACTIVITIES FOR THIS PROJECT FOCUS ON COLLABORATIONS AMONG FAITH AND COMMUNITY-BASED PROGRAMS, AND CHILD CARE AND MEDICAL PROVIDERS; SERVICE LINKAGES; MANAGEMENT AND SURVEILLANCE REPORTS; POPULATION AND COMMUNITY-BASED INTERVENTIONS; PRIMARY PREVENTION THROUGH CARE COORDINATION, AND ENVIRONMENTAL INVESTIGATIONS; EDUCATION AND OUTREACH; AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT.  METHODOLOGY: PROGRAM ACTIVITIES WILL BE IMPLEMENTED THROUGH PARTNERSHIPS IDENTIFYING GAPS IN THE COMPREHENSIVE SYSTEM THAT SERVE CHILDREN, AND EVIDENCE-BASED PRACTICES AND STRATEGIES. MISSISSIPPI STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH HAS AN ARRAY OF PARTNERSHIPS ACROSS THE STATE, WHICH INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO: REGIONAL HOUSING AUTHORITIES, MS DIVISION OF MEDICAID (MS DOM), FIRST STEPS EARLY INTERVENTION PROGRAM OF THE MS STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH, MSDH SERVICES FOR CHILDREN AND YOUTH WITH SPECIAL HEALTHCARE NEEDS, UNIVERSITY OF MISSISSIPPI, MS AMERICAN ACADEMY OF PEDIATRICS, MS DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY, MS DEPARTMENT OF MENTAL HEALTH, GREEN AND HEALTHY HOMES INITIATIVE, LOCAL MUNICIPALITIES, COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS AND CIVIC ORGANIZATIONS.COORDINATION: THE MISSISSIPPI LEAD POISONING PR EVENTION AND HEALTHY HOMES PROGRAM WILL UTILIZE COLLABORATIVE MODELS AMONG STATE AGENCIES, COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS AND PROVIDERS TO REDUCE CHILDREN?S EXPOSURE TO LEAD. THE GOAL IS TO IMPROVE CARE COORDINATION ACROSS SYSTEMS THAT SERVE CHILDREN AND THEIR FAMILIES AND TO ADDRESS MULTIPLE HEALTH AND SOCIAL NEEDS IN A MORE INTEGRATED MANNER. EVALUATION: THE EVALUATION FOR THIS PROGRAM INCLUDES PROCESS AND OUTCOME EVALUATION AS IT RELATES TO THE CONTRIBUTIONS OF THE PROGRAM AND STAKEHOLDERS. THE EVALUATION WILL DETERMINE THE OVERALL EFFECTIVENESS OF THE PROGRAM THROUGH SUCH ACTIVITIES AS MEASURING THE COORDINATION AND LINKAGE OF SERVICES, IDENTIFYING GAPS IN THE SYSTEM, PARTNERSHIP ASSESSMENTS, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF EVIDENCE-BASED PRACTICES.

VERMONT'S CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN - PROJECT ABSTRACT - COMPONENTS A AND BTHE MISSION OF THE VERMONT DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH HEALTHY HOMES LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (HHLPPP) IS TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH AND SAFETY OF ALL VERMONT HOME ENVIRONMENTS THROUGH SURVEILLANCE, COLLABORATION, EDUCATION, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF COMPREHENSIVE POLICIES AND COORDINATED PROGRAMMATIC ACTIVITIES.  IN THE CASE OF THIS GRANT APPLICATION, THE HHLPPP FOCUSES ON THE ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH ISSUE THAT IS AT ITS CORE?CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING. VERMONT HAS BEEN WORKING TO PREVENT CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING SINCE ITS FIRST CLPP PROGRAM WAS FUNDED BY CDC IN 1993.VERMONT HAS SOME OF THE OLDEST HOUSING STOCK IN THE COUNTRY, WITH NEARLY 70% OF HOUSING BUILT BEFORE 1978, MAKING THE ENTIRE STATE A HIGH-RISK AREA FOR CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING. OVER THE PAST 20 YEARS, VERMONT HAS MADE STEADY PROGRESS IN REDUCING THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN WITH BLOOD LEAD LEVELS AT OR ABOVE THE CURRENT CDC REFERENCE VALUE. UNFORTUNATELY, THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC HAS IMPACTED THE PERCENTAGE OF CHILDREN GETTING SCREENED FOR LEAD. THIS GRANT GIVES HHLPPP THE OPPORTUNITY TO REDOUBLE OUR EFFORTS INTERNALLY AND WITH OUR EXTERNAL PARTNERS.VERMONT HHLPPP HAS MANY INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL PARTNERS ALREADY WORKING TOGETHER ON LEAD POISONING PREVENTION, PROVIDING AN INFRASTRUCTURE FROM WHICH TO TRY NEW PREVENTION STRATEGIES. THIS INFRASTRUCTURE INCLUDES VERMONT?S LEAD LAW THAT REQUIRES OWNERS OF PRE-1978 RENTAL PROPERTIES TO PERFORM ESSENTIAL MAINTENANCE PRACTICES AND A REGULATION REQUIRING HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS TO UNIVERSALLY TEST ALL 1- AND 2-YEAR-OLD CHILDREN FOR LEAD.VERMONT HAS FOUR LONG-TERM OUTCOMES FOR THE FIVE-YEAR PROJECT PERIOD:OUTCOME 1: IMPROVED BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING RATES FOR CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE AT RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE OUTCOME 2. IMPROVED USE OF SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM DATA TO CAPTURE MISSING DATA ON CHILD DEMOGRAPHIC AND FOLLOW-UP INFORMATION OUTCOME 3. IMPROVED RATES OF CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE WITH BLOOD LEAD LEV ELS GREATER THAN OR EQUAL TO 5 ?G/DL WHO ARE LINKED TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES.OUTCOME 4.  DECREASED DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BY RACE/ETHNICITY AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS.HHLPPP WILL IMPROVE THE HEALTH AND SAFETY OF ALL VERMONT HOME ENVIRONMENTS THROUGH PRIMARY AND SECONDARY PREVENTION OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING. VERMONT HAS MADE STEADY PROGRESS IN REDUCING THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN WITH BLOOD LEAD LEVELS. CONTINUED PROGRESS RELIES ON (1) ENSURING BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, (2) ENHANCING BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE, (3) IMPROVING LINKAGES OF LEAD EXPOSED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES, AND (4) DEVELOPING TARGETED, POPULATION-BASED POLICY INTERVENTIONS.THE SPECIFIC STRATEGIES THAT VERMONT WILL USE TO MOVE TOWARD THESE LONG-TERM OUTCOMES INCLUDE: CONVENING A STATEWIDE LEAD ADVISORY COMMITTEE; UPDATING OUR STATEWIDE SCREENING AND TESTING PLAN BASED ON LOCAL DATA IN COLLABORATION WITH STATEWIDE LEAD ADVISORY COMMITTEE; UPDATING OUR HHLPSS BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM TO THE NEWEST VERSION; DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING PLANS FOR SURVEILLANCE DATA COLLECTION, DATA QUALITY CHECKS, AND DATA DISSEMINATION WITH A FOCUS ON DATA INTEROPERABILITY; CONDUCTING ANALYSES OF SURVEILLANCE DATA TO IDENTIFY LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN, HIGH-RISK POPULATIONS, AND GEOGRAPHIC AREAS; CONTINUING TO USE OUR SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM TO IDENTIFY CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS REQUIRING FOLLOW-UP; PARTNERING WITH INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL PROGRAMS AND ORGANIZATIONS THAT PROVIDE SERVICES TO MITIGATE THE EFFECTS OF ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS; CONTINUING TO CONNECT CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS TO MEDICAL, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND SOCIAL SERVICES; AND DEVELOPING STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS AND POLICIES TO IMPLEMENT TARGETED, POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS AIMED AT PRIMARY PREVENTION OF LEAD EXPOSURE WITH A FOCUS ON COMMUNITY-BASED APPROACHES FOR LEAD HAZARD ELIMINATION.

RHODE ISLAND CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE - PURPOSE:  TO MAXIMIZE FUNDING AND LEVERAGE PARTNERSHIPS TO INCREASE PRIMARY AND SECONDARY LEAD POISONING PREVENTION ACTIVITIES TO PREVENT AND ULTIMATELY ELIMINATE CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING BY FOCUSING ON ENDING DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS.  THE RHODE ISLAND DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH (RIDOH) HEALTHY HOMES AND LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (HHLPPP) WILL STRIVE TO TAKE PUBLIC HEALTH ACTION TO IMPROVE HEALTH EQUITY BY IMPLEMENTING, SUPPORTING, AND EXPANDING EFFORTS TO ENSURE AND INCREASE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, MAINTAINING AND EXPANDING SURVEILLANCE, AND IMPROVE LINKAGES OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES.SITE:  THE ENTIRE STATE OF RHODE ISLAND IS A HIGH-RISK AREA COMPOSED OF AGING HOUSING STOCK WITH DETERIORATING PAINT. APPROXIMATELY 80% OF RHODE ISLAND?S HOUSING STOCK WAS BUILT BEFORE 1978. RI DESIGNATES CITIES WITH A CHILD POVERTY RATE GREATER THAN 25% AS CORE CITIES. 67% OF ALL MINORITY CHILDREN LIVE IN THE CORE CITIES. THEREFORE, THEY ARE AT INCREASED RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE AND ITS ASSOCIATED ADVERSE HEALTH CONSEQUENCES. 74% OF THE CHILDREN LIVING IN THE CORE CITIES ARE CHILDREN OF COLOR. THESE CITIES HAVE THE OLDEST HOUSING STOCK IN THE STATE. 94% OF RESIDENCES IN THE CORE CITIES WERE BUILT BEFORE 1978 WITH 61% CONSTRUCTED BEFORE 1940. THE PERCENTAGE OF PRE-1940 HOUSING IN THE CORE CITIES IS APPROXIMATELY TWICE THE STATEWIDE RATE. RI?S PRE-1940 PERCENTAGE IS HIGHER THAN ALL OTHER STATES EXCEPT FOR MASSACHUSETTS AND NEW YORK. RI?S HIGH LEAD POISONING RATE COMES AS NO SURPRISE SINCE AT LEAST 82% OF RENTER-OCCUPIED HOMES AND 77% OF OWNER-OCCUPIED HOMES IN RI WERE BUILT BEFORE 1978. 87% OF EXTREMELY LOW-INCOME FAMILIES WHO RENT AND HAVE CHILDREN UNDER SIX YEARS LIVE IN HOMES BUILT BEFORE 1978.JUSTIFICATION: RHODE ISLAND IS A SMALL STATE WITH A BIG CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PROBLEM BASED ON OUR LEAD EXPOSURE RISK INDEX (LERI). SURVEILLANCE DATA SUPPORT DISPARITIES IN BLLS BY SOCIAL DEMOGRAPHIC AND GEOGRAPHICAL FACTORS. 61%  OF CHILDREN IDENTIFIED AS LEAD POISONED IN A HIGH-RISK JURISDICTION IN 2020 WERE CHILDREN OF COLOR. 83% OF ALL HISPANIC CHILDREN IDENTIFIED IN RI AS HAVING AN EBLL IN 2020 LIVED IN HIGH-RISK JURISDICTION. SHELTERING IN PLACE DURING COVID-19 MAY HAVE ADVERSELY IMPACTED LEAD POISONING RATES IN RI. LEAD SCREENING RATES HAVE DECREASED 24%, WITH A DISTURBING 22% INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF NEW LEAD POISONING CASES IN 2020 CAUSING OUR INCIDENCE RATE TO RISE 2.5%.PROGRAM OBJECTIVES: HHLPPP?S LEAD ELIMINATION SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM (LESS) CAN COLLECT AND REPORT DATA TO THE CDC TO SUPPORT ALL PERIODS OF PERFORMANCE OUTCOMES LISTED BELOW. THE APPROACHES TO ACCOMPLISHING ALL OUTCOMES ARE DESCRIBED IN THE STRATEGIES AND ACTIVITIES.  1.IMPROVED BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING RATES FOR CHILDREN LESS THAN SIX YEARS OF AGE AT RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE 2.IMPROVED USE OF SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM DATA TO CAPTURE AND DECREASE MISSING DATA ON CHILD DEMOGRAPHIC AND INCREASE FOLLOW-UP INFORMATION 3.IMPROVED RATES OF CHILDREN LESS THAN SIX YEARS OF AGE WHICH ARE LINKED TO AND ACCEPT RECOMMENDED SERVICES 4.DECREASED DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BY RACE/ETHNICITY AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS.

CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE PROGRAM - ABSTRACT: HEALTH AND HOSPITAL CORPORATION OF MARION COUNTY DOING BUSINESS AS MARION COUNTY PUBLIC HEALTH DEPARTMENT (MCPHD) IS APPLYING TO THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION (CDC) CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN PROGRAM. MCPHD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (LPPP), A COMPONENT OF THE HEALTHY HOMES, ENVIRONMENTAL CONSUMER MANAGEMENT & SENIOR CARE DEPARTMENT, WILL USE FUNDS TO INCREASE EFFORTS TO IDENTIFY AND CONNECT LEAD POISONED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES AND INCREASE SURVEILLANCE EFFORTS WHILE WORKING CLOSELY WITH PARTNERING AGENCIES TO ENSURE A COMPREHENSIVE SYSTEM OF REFERRAL, CASE MANAGEMENT, FOLLOW-UP CARE, AND EVALUATION ARE IN PLACE TO SERVE EFFECTED CHILDREN AND FAMILIES. LPPP ACTIVITIES WILL RESULT IN:(1)INCREASED NUMBERS OF CHILDREN LESS THAN SIX YEARS OLD TESTED FOR BLOOD LEAD: LPPP WILL RAISE AWARENESS THROUGH EDUCATION AND OUTREACH, WORK WITH PRIMARY CARE PROVIDERS (PCP) TO ENSURE ELIGIBLE AND AT-RISK CHILDREN RECEIVE BLOOD LEAD TESTS, AND PROVIDE BLOOD LEAD TESTING AT CHILDCARE FACILITIES, OUTREACH EVENTS, AND DURING HOME VISITS. (2)IMPROVED DATA USAGE THAT LEADS TO A GREATER IDENTIFICATION OF GEOGRAPHIC AREAS AND POPULA-TIONS AT HIGH RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE: LPPP WILL CONDUCT REGULAR DATA REVIEWS, IDENTIFYING ?HOT SPOTS? AND INCREASING TARGETED OUTREACH TO THOSE AREAS. (3)INCREASED ABILITY TO TARGET INTERVENTIONS TO HIGH-RISK POPULATIONS: REGULAR REVIEW OF DATA WILL IDENTIFY COMMUNITIES THAT NEED EDUCATION, OUTREACH, AND BLOOD LEAD TESTING.(4)INCREASED IDENTIFICATION OF CHILDREN EXPOSED TO LEAD AND LINKS TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES: EDUCATION, TARGETED OUTREACH, INCREASED BLOOD LEAD TESTING, AND WORKING DIRECTLY WITH PCPS TO IDENTIFY CHILDREN EXPOSED TO LEAD AND LINK THEM TO NECESSARY SERVICES. (5)COORDINATED EFFORTS FOR LEAD INSPECTIONS AND SCREENINGS: DEVELOP A COUNTYWIDE ADVISORY COMMITTEE AND COUNTYWIDE CATALOG OF WRAPAROUND SERVICE PROVIDERS, IN-OFFICE TESTING SITES, AND POINTS OF CARE SCREENING.

SOUTH DAKOTA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH APPLICATION FOR THE 2021 CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION & SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN - LEAD POISONING AMONG YOUNG CHILDREN CAN LEAD TO POOR COGNITIVE DEVELOPMENT AND BEHAVIORAL DISORDERS THAT CAN HAVE LONG LASTING IMPACT THROUGHOUT THE LIFESPAN. HOWEVER, THE SD DOH DOES NOT CURRENTLY HAVE A LEAD PROGRAM TO SUPPORT PREVENTION, RAPID IDENTIFICATION, AND FOLLOW-UP OF CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS. TO RAISE AWARENESS OF THE IMPORTANCE OF BLOOD LEAD SCREENING AND TESTING IN THE STATE AND FACILITATE THE CASE MANAGEMENT OF CHILDREN IDENTIFIED WITH ELEVATED LEAD LEVELS, SD DOH PROPOSES ESTABLISHING THE SD CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE PROGRAM. OUR AIM IS TO CONVENE A LEAD ADVISORY GROUP TO HIGHLIGHT THE NEED FOR BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, AND IMPROVING LINKAGES TO RECOMMENDED MEDICAL, ENVIRONMENTAL, OR SOCIAL SERVICES. THE PROGRAM'S CAPACITY AND PERFORMANCE WILL BE ASSESSED TO ENSURE HIGH QUALITY SERVICE TO CHILDREN, PARENTS, AND PROFESSIONALS WITH A FOCUS OF DECREASING ADVERSE HEALTH EFFECTS AND SOCIETAL COSTS OF CHILDHOOD LEAD EXPOSURE.

CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION - PROJECT ABSTRACTIN ORDER TO ELIMINATE LEAD HEALTH HAZARDS IN DELAWARE, THE DIVISION OF PUBLIC HEALTH PROPOSES ACTIVITIES THAT CAN BE CLASSIFIED BY TWO LINES OF ATTACK. THE FIRST USES PRIMARY PREVENTION ACTIVITIES, THE SECOND INCLUDES SECONDARY AND TERTIARY ACTIVITIES OF CHILDREN WHO HAVE BEEN LEAD POISONED OR AT RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE. THIS NEW CDC GRANT FUNDING WILL STRENGTHEN THE HEALTHY HOMES AND LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM BY SUPPORTING THE MEDICAL AND COMMUNITY COLLABORATIONS THAT WILL ENHANCE BOTH PRIMARY AND SECONDARY CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION IN DELAWARE. PARTNERSHIPS WILL BE FURTHER DEVELOPED, ACTIVITIES COORDINATED, AND COMMUNITIES MOBILIZED FOR ACTION THROUGH EDUCATION AND OUTREACH. ASSISTANCE FROM CDC WILL ENSURE SUSTAINED DATA TRACKING AND SURVEILLANCE WILL BE ENHANCED AND EXPANDED IN THE STATE. MEASURABLE OBJECTIVES INCLUDE: REINFORCING STATE AND LOCAL COLLABORATIONS THAT WILL PROMOTE BOTH PRIMARY AND SECONDARY CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION; STRENGTHENING MEDICAL AND COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS TO INCREASE ACTIVITIES AND COORDINATE COMMUNITIES TO MOBILIZE FOR ACTION THROUGH LEAD HAZARDS AWARENESS EDUCATION AND OUTREACH; ENSURING SUSTAINED LEAD SCREENING OF CHILDREN, DATA TRACKING AND SURVEILLANCE; ENGAGING COMMUNITIES IN IDENTIFIED HIGH RISK AREAS IN DELAWARE BY TARGETED OUTREACH AND EDUCATION.THE EXPECTED LONG-TERM OUTCOMES ARE:SCREENING AND CASE MANAGEMENT PLAN: ALL DELAWARE CHILDREN WILL RECEIVE A BLOOD LEAD LEVEL TEST AT 12 MONTHS AND 24 MONTHS. CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED LEAD LEVELS ? 5 UG/DL WILL BE FOLLOWED UP AND PROVIDED APPROPRIATE SERVICES INCLUDING ENVIRONMENTAL HAZARD REDUCTION; DEVELOPMENTAL, NUTRITIONAL AND MEDICAL ASSESSMENTS OF CHILDREN WITH HIGH LEAD LEVELS. SURVEILLANCE: FAMILIES OF CHILDREN AT HIGH RISK FOR LEAD POISONING WILL BE AWARE OF THEIR CHILDREN?S BLOOD LEAD LEVEL STATUS BY THE TIME CHILDREN ARE TWO YEARS OF AGE. THE PROGRAM WILL MATCH LEAD SCREENING DATA WITH MEDICAID AND WIC ENROLLMENT DAT A TO IDENTIFY AND NOTIFY FAMILIES OF CHILDREN WHO HAVE NOT BEEN SCREENED FOR LEAD POISONING.PRIMARY PREVENTION: THE TOTAL NUMBER OF CHILDREN IN DELAWARE WITH ELEVATED LEAD LEVELS ? 5 UG/DL WILL BE REDUCED TO LESS THAN 1% OF THE CHILDHOOD POPULATION THROUGH IMPLEMENTATION OF SYSTEMS THAT CONTROL AND ELIMINATE LEAD SOURCES PRIOR TO THE CHILDREN BEING EXPOSED. OUTPUTS TO ACHIEVE THIS GOAL INCLUDE - CONDUCTING LEAD RISK ASSESSMENTS OF ALL HOMES THAT HAVE FAMILIES WITH CHILDREN WITH HIGH LEAD LEVELS; VIGOROUS ENFORCEMENT OF DELAWARE?S RENOVATION, REPAIR, AND PAINTING REGULATION (RRP) AND RAISING CONTRACTOR AND THE PUBLIC?S AWARENESS OF THE NEED TO REPAIR HOMES IN A LEAD-SAFE MANNER AS WELL AS PARTNERING WITH HOUSING AUTHORITIES AND LOCAL CODE ENFORCEMENT AND PERMITTING OFFICES IN CITIES AND TOWNS; USE ENHANCED LEAD DATA TRACKING AND GIS MAPPING TO IMPLEMENT POPULATION-BASED PREVENTION INTERVENTIONS IN DELAWARE?S HIGHEST RISK GEOGRAPHIC AREAS. STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS: CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION REMAINS A PRIORITY IN DELAWARE, WITH EXPANDING AND STRENGTHENING STRATEGIC RELATIONSHIPS WITH MEDICAL, COMMUNITY AND GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS OF VITAL IMPORTANCE. OUTPUTS TO ACHIEVE THIS GOAL INCLUDE ? PROVIDE FREE LEAD POISONING PREVENTION TRAINING TO EMPLOYEES OF PUBLIC AND PRIVATE MEDICAL OFFICES, BUILDING CODE OFFICES, HOUSING AUTHORITIES, AND NON-PROFIT COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS; PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR THE GOVERNOR-APPOINTED CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING ADVISORY COMMITTEE.THIS CD GRANT WILL EXPAND AND ENHANCE THE STATE OF DELAWARE?S CAPACITY TO ELIMINATE CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING AS A MAJOR PUBLIC HEALTH PROBLEM, WHICH ALIGNS WITH DELAWARE?S STRATEGIC PLAN TO ERADICATE CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING. A STATEWIDE CHILDHOOD BLOOD LEAD-SCREENING PLAN, A BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM, AND CASE MANAGEMENT STANDARDS FOR CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS ARE ALL IN PLACE.

CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS INCHILDREN - CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDRENWITH FUNDING FROM THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION AWARDED IN 1996, THE ENVIRONMENTAL EPIDEMIOLOGY PROGRAM (EEP) DEVELOPED A SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM FOR ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS (EBLL) IN CHILDREN AND HAS CONTINUED TO COLLECT AND ANALYZE BLOOD LEAD RESULTS ON CHILDREN TO THIS DAY. THE EEP, LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENTS, AND OTHER UTAH AGENCIES AND PROGRAMS CONTINUE TO COLLABORATE TO REDUCE AND ELIMINATE LEAD EXPOSURE TO UTAH?S CHILDREN. THE EEP OBJECTIVES INCLUDE: 1) ENHANCE AND MAINTAIN AN ACTIVE, ONGOING STATEWIDE SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM FOR CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS, 2) ENSURE THAT LABORATORY-BASED SURVEILLANCE OF CHILD BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IS COMPLETE BY COLLECTING DATA ON ALL BLOOD LEAD TESTING OF UTAH RESIDENTS, 3) ENSURE THAT CHILDREN WITH AN EBLL RECEIVE APPROPRIATE MEDICAL FOLLOW-UP, 4) ARRANGE FOR CASE MANAGEMENT AND ENVIRONMENTAL INVESTIGATIONS OF LEAD EXPOSURE, 5) IDENTIFY EXPOSURE PATTERNS AND HIGH-RISK POPULATIONS WITHIN THE STATE, 6) PROVIDE APPROPRIATE PREVENTION INTERVENTION AS NEEDS ARE IDENTIFIED, 7) PROVIDE EDUCATION TO IDENTIFIED AT-RISK POPULATIONS, AND 8) ENHANCE THE COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS BETWEEN PUBLIC AGENCIES AND PRIVATE HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS TO PREVENT LEAD POISONING IN YOUNG CHILDREN.IN UTAH, THE PREVALENCE RATE OF CHILDREN 0-5 YEARS OLD, WITH AN ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVEL (? 10 ?G/DL) WAS 0.2 % DURING 2019, A DECREASE FROM 4.0 % IN 1996. IN 2017, THE UTAH DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH LOWERED THE BLOOD LEAD LEVEL OF CONCERN TO ? 5.0 ?G/DL TO BE CONSISTENT WITH CDC?S GUIDELINES. THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD, BASED ON THE NEW LEVEL OF CONCERN WAS 1.3% IN 2018 AND 0.8% IN 2019. LEAD-BASED PAINT, PAST MINING ACTIVITIES, AND OTHER NON-TRADITIONAL LEAD EXPOSURES HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS THE ROUTES OF LEAD EXPOSURE TO CHILDREN IN UTAH. ALTHOUGH THE RATES HAVE BEEN DECLINING THERE ARE AREAS WITHIN THE STATE THAT HAVE H IGH-RISK MINORITY POPULATIONS, ESPECIALLY IN THE MORE POPULATED AREAS. OF THE 299,566 CHILDREN, AGES 0-5 YEARS, LIVING IN UTAH, 39,842(13.3%) LIVE IN POVERTY CONDITIONS.   PARTICULARLY, MINORITY GROUPS OCCUPY HOUSING THAT IS LESS EXPENSIVE, OLDER, AND IN CLOSER PROXIMITY TO INDUSTRIAL OR HAZARDOUS WASTE SITES. THERE ARE AN ESTIMATED 768,594 HOUSING UNITS IN UTAH AND OF THOSE, IT IS ESTIMATED 11.1% WERE BUILT BEFORE 1950 AND 42.2% WERE BUILT BEFORE 1980. SOME OF THESE COMMUNITIES ARE IN HEALTH DISPARITY OR ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE NEIGHBORHOODS WITH LITTLE RESOURCES TO RENOVATE OR MAINTAIN THOSE HOMES. THE EEP, WITH THE ASSISTANCE FROM THE CDC, WILL IMPROVE AND ENHANCE THE SURVEILLANCE FOR LEAD POISONING, IDENTIFY HIGH-RISK COMMUNITIES AND POPULATIONS AND ENCOURAGE SCREENING OF THESE HIGH-RISK POPULATIONS. THE INCREASE IN SURVEILLANCE IS CRITICAL TO MONITOR INCIDENCE TRENDS AND TO DEVELOP APPROPRIATE SCREENING AND INTERVENTION STRATEGIES FOR CHILDREN RESIDING IN UTAH. THE EEP WILL INCREASE ACTIVITIES IN PUBLIC HEALTH EDUCATION AND PRIMARY PREVENTION. THE DATA OBTAINED THROUGH THE SURVEILLANCE ACTIVITIES AND THE TIMELY ANALYSES AND REPORTING WILL BE PERFORMED AND SHARED WITH FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH OFFICIALS, HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS, AND HOUSING AUTHORITIES TO ASSIST THE EFFORTS TO REDUCE AND ELIMINATE CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING IN UTAH.

MONTANA CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE PROGRAM - PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYMONTANA HAS A RICH HISTORY NATURAL RESOURCE AND ENERGY DEVELOPMENT WHICH BEGAN IN THE 1860S DURING THE WESTERN GOLD RUSH AND HAS CONTINUED THROUGH PRESENT DAY. METALS RECOVERY HAS A LEGACY OF SMELTING WASTES AND TAILINGS WITH ELEVATED LEAD AND OTHER METALS IN SEVERAL MONTANA COMMUNITIES. ADDITIONALLY, MANY OF MONTANA?S CITIES BEGAN AS MINING TOWNS IN THE 19TH CENTURY. AN ESTIMATED 64% (332,000 OF 520,000 HOMES) WERE BUILT BEFORE 1980 WHEN LEAD-BASED PAINT WAS BANNED (1978) AND COULD BE CONTAMINATED WITH LEAD PAINT. IN ADDITION TO LEAD PAINT, LEAD SERVICE LINES FOR DRINKING WATER MAY BE COMMON WITH OLDER HOMES AND AGING INFRASTRUCTURE IN MANY MONTANA COMMUNITIES. THE HEALTHCARE COMMUNITY IN MONTANA MAY NOT PERCEIVE A NEED TO TEST PATIENTS FOR LEAD POISONING. A 2012 SURVEY CONDUCTED BY THE MONTANA DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES (DPHHS) FOUND THAT FEW PROVIDERS SCREEN MEDICAID-ENROLLED CHILDREN ACCORDING TO PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS, MOST PROVIDERS (94%) BELIEVE THERE IS LOW RISK OF LEAD POISONING IN THEIR AREA, AND THAT THE MOST COMMON RISK FACTOR CITED BY PROVIDERS IS THE AGE OF THE CHILD?S HOME (71%). IN 2019 AND 2020, ONLY 37 CASES OF ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS (BLL) AMONG CHILDREN < 6 YEARS WERE REPORTED TO DPHHS; DPHHS MAY NOT BE IDENTIFYING 97% OF MEDICAID-ENROLLED CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLL. DUE TO LACK OF FUNDING, DPHHS HAS NOT HAD AN ACTIVE LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM FOR OVER A DECADE. FUNDING THROUGH THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL PROVIDE DPHHS THE RESOURCES TO ESTABLISH A MONTANA CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE PROGRAM (CLPPSP) WHICH WILL CONSIST OF TWO STAFF, A PROGRAM COORDINATOR AND AN EPIDEMIOLOGIST, WITH AN ANNUAL BUDGET OF $300,000. THE MONTANA CLPPSP WILL USE OUR CHILDHOOD BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM TO COLLECT AND REPORT DATA TO THE CDC TO SUPPORT THE FOLLOWING INTERMEDIATE AND LONG-TERM OUTCOMES: 1) IMPROVED BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING RATES FOR CHILDREN  LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE AT RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE; 2) IMPROVED THE USE OF SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM DATA TO CAPTURE MISSING DATA ON CHILD DEMOGRAPHIC AND FOLLOW-UP INFORMATION; 3) DECREASED DISPARITIES IN BLOOD LEAD LEVELS BY RACE/ETHNICITY AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS; AND 4)IMPROVED RATES OF CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS LINKED TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES.THE MONTANA CLPPSP WILL ENGAGE IN SECONDARY PREVENTION ACTIVITIES OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING TO ENSURE BLOOD LEAD TESTING, ENHANCE BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE AND REPORTING, AND IMPROVE LINKAGES TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES. KEY TASKS DPHHS AIMS TO ACCOMPLISH IN PROJECT YEAR 1 INCLUDE: RECRUIT AND HIRE AN EPIDEMIOLOGIST, CONVENING A LEAD ADVISORY COMMITTEE, PUBLISH A CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION SCREENING AND TESTING STRATEGIC PLAN, UPDATE REPORTABLE CONDITIONS RULES TO INCLUDE REPORTS OF ALL BLOOD LEAD TEST RESULTS, ENSURE THAT DPHHS?S SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM HAS THE ABILITY TO COLLECT AND TRACK FOLLOW-UP AND ENVIRONMENTAL INFORMATION, CONTRACT WITH SELECT LOCAL HEALTH JURISDICTIONS TO ENHANCE ACTIVITIES FOR LEAD POISONING PREVENTION BY COORDINATING WITH COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS THAT PROVIDE SERVICES TO MITIGATE THE EFFECTS OF ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS AND CONNECT CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS TO RECOMMENDED MEDICAL, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND SOCIAL SERVICES. DURING PROJECT YEARS 2?5, DPHHS AIMS TO CONTINUE AND EXPAND MANY OF THE ACTIVITIES STARTED IN PROJECT YEAR 1.

NEBRASKA CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM - CHILDREN AND FAMILIES IN NEBRASKA FACE UNIQUE AND DISPROPORTIONATELY HIGH RISKS OF LEAD EXPOSURE. THE PURPOSE OF THE NEBRASKA CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (NECLPPP) IS TO PREVENT LEAD POISONING AMONG CHILDREN IN NEBRASKA BY ENSURING BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, ENHANCING BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE, AND IMPROVING LINKAGES OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO SERVICES. NECLPPP WILL PLAN, DEVELOP, IMPLEMENT, AND EVALUATE STRATEGIES AND ACTIVITIES FOR PRIMARY AND SECONDARY PREVENTION TO ACHIEVE THE PERFORMANCE OUTCOMES. NECLPPP WILL MAINTAIN AN ADVISORY COMMITTEE TO ASSIST IN PROVIDING TESTING AND PREVENTION GUIDANCE FOR PUBLIC HEALTH AND HEALTH CARE COMMUNITIES. NECLPPP WILL STRENGTHEN BLOOD LEAD TESTING TO UTILIZE DATA TO UPDATE AND MAINTAIN NEBRASKA'S BLOOD LEAD TESTING PLAN, WHICH WILL RESULT IN IMPROVED BLOOD LEAD TESTING RATES FOR CHILDREN AT RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE. NECLPPP WILL STRENGTHEN BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE BY CONTINUING THE OPERATION OF A STATEWIDE BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM AND IMPROVING DATA QUALITY AND COMPLETENESS. NECLPPP WILL PARTNER WITH OTHER AGENCIES TO FACILITATE DATA SHARING AGREEMENTS FOCUSED ON IMPROVING DATA INTEROPERABILITY. ROUTINE SURVEILLANCE DATA ANALYSES WILL BE CONDUCTED, WHICH WILL RESULT IN THE INCREASED IDENTIFICATION OF HIGH-RISK POPULATIONS AND TRENDS. NECLPPP WILL IDENTIFY, REFER, AND MONITOR CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS, WHICH WILL RESULT IN IMPROVED RATES OF CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS LINKED TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES. WE WILL CONTINUE TO PARTNER WITH 18 LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH DEPARTMENTS ACROSS NEBRASKA. EACH LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH DEPARTMENT WILL PROVIDE CASE INVESTIGATIONS AND FOLLOW-UP, SERVICE COORDINATION, AND REFERRALS OF CHILDREN TO MEDICAL, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND SOCIAL SERVICES. TIMELINESS OF FOLLOW-UP ACTIVITIES WILL BE TRACKED THROUGH NEBRASKA'S DATA SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM AND REVIEWED TO ENSURE QUALITY AND EFFICACY. NECLPPP HAS MANY PARTNERS COMMITTED TO PREVENTIN G CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING, AND BY STRENGTHENING THESE PARTNERSHIPS, STAKEHOLDERS WILL CONTINUE ACTIVITIES BEYOND THIS PROJECT PERIOD AT THE LOCAL, REGIONAL, AND STATEWIDE LEVELS.

STRENGTHENING CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN HARRIS COUNTY. - THE HARRIS COUNTY PUBLIC HEALTH (HCPH) CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (CLPPP) AIMS TO REDUCE LEAD EXPOSURE AND LEAD POISONING BY ENHANCING BLOOD LEAD SCREENINGS AND DEVELOPING TARGETED POPULATION-BASED POLICY INTERVENTIONS. PARTNERING WITH THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION (CDC) WILL FURTHER ALLOW THE PROGRAM TO USE PRIMARY PREVENTION STRATEGIES TO EDUCATE FAMILIES WITHIN HARRIS COUNTY COMMUNITIES ABOUT THE EFFECTS OF LEAD, INCLUDING PREVENTIVE MEASURES NECESSARY TO REDUCE THE EXPOSURE OF LEAD AND AVERT LEAD POISONING. ADDITIONALLY, HCPH'S CLPPP HAS ESTABLISHED PARTNERSHIPS WITH TWO HARRIS COUNTY WOMEN, INFANTS, AND CHILDREN (WIC) CLINICS THAT SERVE CHILDREN IN LOW-INCOME HOUSEHOLDS AND THOSE ENROLLED IN MEDICAID. THIS COLLABORATION WITH THE WIC CLINICS DEMONSTRATES AN EFFECTIVE METHOD FOR SCREENING HIGH-RISK CHILDREN WHO HAVE NOT BEEN PREVIOUSLY SCREENED FOR LEAD AND INCREASING AWARENESS WITHIN THE TARGET POPULATION. HCPH'S CLPPP WILL CONTINUE TO STRENGTHEN OUR CURRENT EXTERNAL PARTNERSHIPS WITH SCHOOLS, CLINICS, STAKEHOLDERS, AND INTERNAL PARTNERSHIPS WITH HCPH PROGRAMS, INCLUDING LEAD HAZARD CONTROL, OBESITY REDUCTION, AND EARLY CHILDHOOD HEALTH & WELLNESS, BY IMPROVING THE LINKAGE OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES. OUR PROGRAM LOOKS FORWARD TO SEEKING FUTURE COLLABORATIONS WITH EXTERNAL AND INTERNAL PROGRAMS BY CREATING AN EVERLASTING IMPACT ON OUR NEIGHBORING COMMUNITIES.

LEAD POISONING PREVENTION - CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION - PURSUANT TO THE NOTICE OF FUNDING OPPORTUNITY (NOFO) CDC-RFA-EH21-2102: CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN, THE SOUTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROL (DHEC) IS REQUESTING $350,000 IN ANNUAL COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT (CA) FUNDING TO IMPLEMENT COMPONENT A OF THE 5-YEAR PROJECT. THIS FUNDING WILL ALLOW US TO FURTHER OUR WORK TO PREVENT AND DIMINISH THE EFFECTS OF LEAD EXPOSURE. PROPOSED CA FUNDING WILL SUPPORT 8 POSITIONS WITH DIRECT RESPONSIBILITIES FOR CHILDHOOD LEAD. DHEC?S EFFORT TOWARDS LEAD TO BE FUNDED BY THIS CA INCLUDES 2.87 FULL-TIME-EQUIVALENTS AND 80% OF A PART-TIME POSITION. ALL POSITIONS ARE CURRENTLY FILLED. FUNDING ALSO SUPPORTS A SUBRECIPIENT CONTRACT WITH THE CATAWBA INDIAN NATION, SC?S ONLY FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED TRIBE. THE SUBRECIPIENT CONTRACT SUPPORTS ACTIVITIES UNDERTAKEN TO IMPROVE SURVEILLANCE, OUTREACH, AND LINKAGES TO SERVICES FOR TRIBAL CHILDREN WITH OR AT-RISK FROM LEAD EXPOSURES. DHEC, A CENTRALIZED STATE-LEVEL HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCY, IS WELL-POSITIONED TO ADDRESS STRATEGIES 1-3 IN COMPONENT A OF THE NOFO: (1) ENSURING BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, (2) ENHANCING BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE, AND (3) IMPROVING LINKAGES TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES. OVER THE 5-YEAR FUNDING CYCLE, DHEC PROPOSES TO IMPLEMENT OR MAINTAIN THESE ACTIVITIES (SEE WORK PLAN, LOCATED IN OUR PROJECT NARRATIVE, FOR MORE DETAIL AND ADDITIONAL PROPOSED ACTIVITIES):STRATEGY 1  ON-GOING -MAINTAIN CURRENT LEAD SURVEILLANCE, REPORTING AND FOLLOW-UP SYSTEM.
