YEARS 2-5 USE THE LEAD ADVISORY COMMITTEE TO DEVELOP AND DISSEMINATE PROVIDER GUIDANCE AND TO ASSIST IN IDENTIFICATION OF DISPARITIES IN HEALTH OUTCOMES AMONG AT-RISK POPULATIONS. IMPROVE LEAD EDUCATION PROVIDED TO COMMUNITIES AT RISK. ST RATEGY 2   ON-GOING MAINTAIN THE CURRENT SCION DATA SYSTEM. CONTINUE USE OF PROVIDER SCORE CARDS (REPORT CARDS) TO IMPROVE QUALITY AND TIMELINESS OF LEAD TESTING DATA SUBMISSIONS.  YEAR 1 IMPLEMENT A DATA-SHARING AGREEMENT WITH THE CATAWBA INDIAN NATION. IMPLEMENT ENHANCEMENTS IN SCION THAT FACILITATE IDENTIFICATION OF HEALTH-OUTCOME DISPARITIES.  YEARS 2-5 WORK TOWARDS DATA-SHARING AGREEMENTS WITH HUD/LOCAL HOUSING AUTHORITIES, AND WITH OSHA. WORK TO INCREASE LEAD RISK SCREENING AND BLOOD LEAD TESTING FOR PREGNANT WOMEN. DETERMINE PROCESS/OUTCOME MEASURES TO EVALUATE IMPACT OF ACTIVITIES ON COMMUNITIES WITH CURRENT OR HISTORIC DISPARATE HEALTH OUTCOMES.STRATEGY 3   ON-GOING CONTINUE TO IDENTIFY CHILDREN WITH EBLLS AND REFER FOR RETESTING, NURSING CASE MANAGEMENT, AND ENVIRONMENTAL LEAD RISK ASSESSMENTS.  YEARS 1-2 DEVELOP A CATALOGUE OF SERVICES FOR CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS (EBLLS) AND THEIR FAMILIES, DEFINING ?RECOMMENDED SERVICES? BEYOND MEDICAL AND NURSING MANAGEMENT AND ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT. IMPLEMENT DATA SYSTEM IMPROVEMENTS TO TRACK PROGRESS OF EBLL INVESTIGATIONS AND OF REFERRALS FOR RECOMMENDED SERVICES.  YEAR 3-5 IMPROVE ACCESS OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO EARLY CHILDHOOD INTERVENTION (ECI) SERVICES; WORK TO ADD EBLL AS A ?TOXIC EXPOSURE? UNDER ECI ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA.DHEC?S PROJECTIONS FOR OUTCOMES OF THIS NOFO INCLUDE 10% IMPROVEMENTS IN SURVEILLANCE DATA QUALITY MEASURES (E.G., RACE/ETHNICITY, ZIP CODE) AND IN QUALITY AND COMPLETENESS OF DATA SUBMITTED TO THE CDC. WHILE FOCUSED ON ALL CHILDREN UNDER SIX YEARS OF AGE, WE EXPECT TO SEE A 10% INCREASE IN NUMBERS OF CHILDREN 9-35 MONTHS OF AGE RECEIVING A BLOOD LEAD TEST. BASED UPON INCREASES IN TESTING, WE PROJECT AN ACCOMPANYING INCREASE IN CASE-FINDING FOR PEDIATRICS EBLL CASES (UP TO 10%) DURING THE PROJECT PERIOD. WE WILL WORK WITH FAMILY PRACTICE AND OBSTETRIC CARE PROVIDERS TO ESTABLISH BASELINES AND GOALS FOR PRENATAL EBLL SCREENING A

HENNEPIN COUNTY CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION - HENNEPIN COUNTY LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROJECTHENNEPIN COUNTY, THROUGH ITS DEPARTMENT OF HOUSING AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT, IS PLEASED TO SUBMIT THIS APPLICATION TO THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL NOTICE OF FUNDING OPPORTUNITY FOR CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROJECTS (CDC-RFA-EH21-2102). HENNEPIN COUNTY HOUSING AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (HCHED) IS SEEKING $275,000 IN ANNUAL FUNDING UNDER COMPONENT B TO REDUCE THE INCIDENCE OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING WHILE INCREASING THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN SCREENED THROUGH A MULTIFACETED APPROACH FOCUSED ON PRIMARY PREVENTION.HENNEPIN COUNTY HAS EXPERIENCED A DRAMATIC REDUCTION IN CHILDHOOD LEAD EXPOSURE, HELPED ALONG BY THE EFFORTS OF MANY OF THE PARTNERS REPRESENTED IN THIS APPLICATION. DESPITE THESE EFFORTS, TOO MANY CHILDREN CONTINUE TO BE AFFECTED BY LEAD EXPOSURE, AND THAT EXPOSURE IS NOT UNIFORM ACROSS THE COUNTY. AT THE CENSUS TRACT SCALE, 45 OF MINNESOTA?S HIGHEST RISK TRACTS ARE LOCATED IN HENNEPIN COUNTY. THE HIGHEST PREVALENCE RATE IN A CENSUS TRACT IN HENNEPIN COUNTY IS NEARLY 8.5% AND THE TOP 20 TRACTS ALL HAVE PREVALENCE RATES OF AT LEAST 3.5%, WELL OVER THE COUNTY AVERAGE OF 1.1% AND STATE AVERAGE OF 0.9%. IN 2019, 21,890 HENNEPIN COUNTY CHILDREN UNDER AGE SIX (72 MONTHS) RECEIVED A BLOOD LEAD TEST. OF THOSE TESTED, 198 HAD AT LEAST ONE BLOOD LEAD TEST RESULT OF 5 ?G/DL (MICROGRAMS PER DECILITER) OR MORE. WITH THIS APPLICATION, HCHED EXPECTS TO INCREASE THE NUMBERS OF CHILDREN TESTED WHILE STRENGTHENING OUR ABILITY TO TARGET HIGH RISK POPULATIONS AND CENSUS TRACTS THROUGH DATA ANALYSIS. HCHED WILL SEEK COMMUNITY PARTNERS TO IMPROVE OUR ABILITY TO TARGET INTERVENTIONS TO AT RISK POPULATIONS AND DECREASE DISPARITIES ALONG WITH DECREASING THE LEAD HAZARDS ON HOUSING AND EXPOSURE FROM NON-PAINT SOURCES OF LEAD.THESE OUTCOMES WILL BE ACHIEVED BY STRATEGIES INCLUDING WORKING WITH THE MN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH TO IDENTIFY THE HIGHEST RISK POPULATIONS AND GEOGRAPHIES THROUGH ANALYSIS OF DATA INCLU DING EXISTING BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE, COUNTY LEVEL DATA ON BIRTHS, AND GIS BASED DEMOGRAPHIC AND HOUSING DATA. HCHED WILL SEEK OUT COMMUNITY PARTNERS WHO SERVE THESE IDENTIFIED TARGETED GEOGRAPHIES AND HIGH RISK POPULATIONS. THESE COMMUNITY PARTNERS WILL BE INVITED TO RESPOND TO A REQUEST FOR PROPOSAL. ALL TOO OFTEN COMMUNITY PARTNERS ARE ASKED TO ENGAGE THEIR SPECIFIC COMMUNITY AND PROVIDE THEIR INPUT BUT NOT PROVIDED ANY FUNDING FOR THEIR EFFORTS. HCHED WILL AWARD CONTRACTS WITH SUCCESSFUL PROPOSERS TO HELP DEVELOP CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE COMMUNICATION PLANS AND ANY NEEDED MATERIALS AND ALSO DELIVER OUTREACH TO THEIR GEOGRAPHIC AREA OR POPULATION PROMOTING BLOOD LEAD SCREENING, PROVIDING EDUCATION, AND DELIVERING TARGETED INTERVENTIONS. AT THE SAME TIME, WE WILL ALSO IMPROVE OUTREACH TO FAMILIES AFFECTED BY LEAD EXPOSURE THROUGH NON HOUSING BASED SOURCES, ESPECIALLY AMONG IMMIGRANT AND REFUGEE POPULATIONS. HEHED WILL DEVELOP A COMPREHENSIVE COMMUNICATION PLAN IN COORDINATION WITH OUR COMMUNITY PARTNERS AS MENTIONED ABOVE AND WE COMPLETE 4 MEDIA CAMPAIGNS INCLUDING AT LEAST 3 SOCIAL MEDIA CAMPAIGNS.

PUERTO RICO CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDREN - A LEAD SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM WILL FINALLY HELP PUERTO RICO DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH UNDERSTAND AND CHARACTERIZE THE RISKS OF CHILDREN UNDER THE AGE OF 6 YEARS FOR LEAD POISONING. FURTHERMORE, SURVEILLANCE HAS BEEN RECOGNIZED AS AN ESSENTIAL COMPONENT FOR SUCCESSFUL ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH PRACTICE, TO IMPROVE QUALITY CONTROL AND PRACTICE MEASURES, TO ESTABLISH EVIDENCE-BASED, EFFICIENT PUBLIC POLICY THAT MATCHES AVAILABLE RESOURCES WITH THE PEDIATRIC POPULATION NEEDS. THERE IS NO DOCUMENTATION OF THE LEVEL OF KNOWLEDGE ON THE TOPIC OF LEAD AMONG OUR PEDIATRICIANS, BUT IT IS SUSPECTED THAT NATIONALLY THERE IS A GREAT NEED FOR MORE EDUCATION ON ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH TOPICS IN GENERAL, INCLUDING LEAD. THE PUERTO RICO CHAPTER OF THE AMERICAN ACADEMY OF PEDIATRICS WILL LAUNCH A LEAD TESTING ECHO IN MAY 2021. BUT THE EDUCATION OF PEDIATRIC HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS MUST BE A CONTINUED AND LONG-TERM EFFORT TO BE MORE EFFECTIVE.

TO DEVELOP AND MAINTAIN AN ACTIVE ONGOING AND SUSTAINABLE STATEWIDE SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM FOR CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS. - PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYLEAD POISONING IS A COMMON, PREVENTABLE CHILDHOOD ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH PROBLEM IN THE UNITED STATES. THE IMPACT OF LEAD WITHIN THE BODY HAS BEEN WELL DOCUMENTED WITH RESEARCH INDICATING NO THRESHOLD FREE FROM ADVERSE EFFECTS. ACCORDING TO THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION (CDC), ?NO SAFE BLOOD LEAD LEVEL IN CHILDREN HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED. EVEN LOW LEVELS OF LEAD IN BLOOD HAVE BEEN SHOWN TO AFFECT IQ, ABILITY TO PAY ATTENTION, AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. AND EFFECTS OF LEAD EXPOSURE CANNOT BE CORRECTED?. (CDC, 2019) COMMON RISK FACTORS FOR LEAD EXPOSURE IN WYOMING INCLUDE NATURAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXPOSURES, OLDER HOMES WITH LEAD PAINT, FOUNDRIES, OLD SHOOTING RANGES, AND A LARGE POPULATION OF HUNTERS WHO RELOAD RIFLE AND SHOTGUN SHELLS FOR THEIR OWN USE. BASED UPON KNOWN LEAD RISK FACTORS AND THE RURAL AND FRONTIER NATURE OF THE STATE, THE RISK OF CHILDHOOD LEAD EXPOSURE CANNOT BE ISOLATED TO A SPECIFIC POPULATION OR GEOGRAPHIC REGION. FURTHERMORE, WYOMING LACKS CURRENT CAPACITY TO COLLECT, ANALYZE, AND USE LEAD DATA TO INFORM A RISK BASED SCREENING SYSTEM. IN THE ABSENCE OF A RISK-BASED SCREENING PLAN, THE WYOMING DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH, PUBLIC HEALTH DIVISION (WDH-PHD) CURRENTLY RECOMMENDS UNIVERSAL CHILDHOOD LEAD SCREENING AT 12 AND 24 MONTHS OF AGE FOR ALL CHILDREN.  THE WDH-PHD DOES NOT CURRENTLY FUND BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE AND PREVENTION ACTIVITIES. HOWEVER, BLOOD LEAD TEST RESULTS ARE A REPORTABLE DISEASE/CONDITION IN WYOMING AND ALL BLOOD LEAD TEST RESULTS ARE REQUIRED TO BE REPORTED TO WDH-PHD. ALL FOLLOW-UP ON ELEVATED LEAD TEST RESULTS RECEIVED BY WDH-PHD IS CURRENTLY CONDUCTED BY EXISTING WDH-PHD STAFF WHO MAINTAIN ADDITIONAL PRIMARY JOB DUTIES. ALTHOUGH WDH-PHD DOES NOT CURRENTLY FUND A DEDICATED LEAD PROGRAM, WDH-PHD STAFF AND STAKEHOLDERS INCLUDING MEDICAID, WIC, PUBLIC HEALTH NURSING, PROVIDERS, ETC. HAVE MET INTERMITTENTLY FOR THE PAST TWO YEARS TO DISCUSS COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS TO IMPROVE CHILDHOOD LE AD SCREENING AND PREVENTION ACTIVITIES, SETTING THE STAGE FOR CURRENT INTEREST IN THIS GRANT OPPORTUNITY.IF AWARDED, WDH-PHD WILL IMPLEMENT THE CORE COMPONENT A ACTIVITIES REQUIRED UNDER THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY IN ORDER TO DEVELOP AND MAINTAIN AN ACTIVE, ONGOING, AND SUSTAINABLE  STATEWIDE SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM FOR CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS. WDH-PHD WILL REACH ALL CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OF AGE WITH A TOTAL ESTIMATED REACH OF 34,240 WYOMING CHILDREN BASED UPON CDC POPULATION ESTIMATES. (CDC WONDER, 2021)

ADPH CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE 2021 CDC PROJECT - THE ALABAMA CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM (ACLPPP) STRIVES TO ENSURE CHILDREN ARE PROTECTED FROM LEAD POISONING. THIS EFFORT REQUIRES BUILDING AND MAINTAINING INFRASTRUCTURE TO ENABLE EXPANSION UPON THE SERVICES ALREADY PROVIDED BY THE ACLPPP. THIS FUNDING WILL ALLOW US TO STRENGTHEN THE PRIMARY AND SECONDARY PREVENTION STRATEGIES FOR CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE WHICH INCLUDE: 1) BLOOD LEAD LEVEL TESTING AND REPORTING, 2) SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS, 3) LINKAGES OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES, AND 4) POLICY DEVELOPMENT FOR TARGETED, POPULATION-BASED INTERVENTIONS WITH A FOCUS ON COMMUNITY-BASED APPROACHES FOR LEAD HAZARD ELIMINATION.STRENGTHENING THE FOUR IDENTIFIED PREVENTION STRATEGIES WILL RESULT IN IMPROVEMENTS IN THE HEALTH OF CHILDREN IN ALABAMA LESS THAN SIX YEARS OF AGE WHO ARE THE MOST VULNERABLE POPULATION TO LEAD EXPOSURE. PROGRAM SUCCESS WILL BE MEASURED BY INCREASING BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING RATES FOR CHILDREN IN ALABAMA LESS THAN SIX YEARS OF AGE, IMPROVING DATA QUALITY IN SURVEILLANCE SYSTEMS FOR MORE RELIABLE FOLLOW-UP INFORMATION, IMPROVING LINKAGES AND SERVICES TO CHILDREN LESS THAN SIX YEARS OF AGE WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS, AND DECREASING LEAD HAZARDS IN HOUSING OCCUPIED BY THE TARGETED POPULATION. UNIVERSAL SCREENING FOR ALL CHILDREN LESS THAN SIX YEARS OLD IS DESIRED; HOWEVER, PRIORITY WILL BE GIVEN TO HIGH-RISK CHILDREN DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED BY LEAD EXPOSURE AND LEAD POISONING, PARTICULARLY THOSE CHILDREN LIVING IN AREAS THAT INCLUDE: HOMES BUILT BEFORE 1978; LOW-INCOME OR SUBSIDIZED HOUSING WITH SUSPECTED OR KNOWN LEAD HAZARDS; HAZARDOUS WASTE SITES OR INDUSTRIAL EMISSIONS CONTAINING LEAD; RACIAL AND ETHNIC MINORITIES; AND RECENT IMMIGRANTS. WHILE A CORE INFRASTRUCTURE IS CURRENTLY IN PLACE, THIS FUNDING WILL ALLOW THE ACLPPP TO IMPROVE UPON THE SERVICES ALREADY AVAILABLE TO LEAD AFFECTED CHILDREN AND THEIR FAMILIES.

REDUCE THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN & PREGNANT PERSONS EXPOSED TO LEAD & INCREASE NUMBER OF AT RISK CHILDREN & PREGNANT PERSONS BEING TESTED TO ENSURE CASE MANAGEMENT & ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES ARE CONDUCTED. - THE BURDEN OF CHILDHOOD LEAD EXPOSURE IN ILLINOIS REMAINS ONE OF THE HIGHEST IN THE NATION. OLDER HOMES WITH DETERIORATED LEAD PAINTCONTINUES TO BE THE PRIMARY SOURCE OF LEAD EXPOSURE IN ILLINOIS. BASED ON A NATIONAL SURVEY, 65 PERCENT OF PRE-1978 ILLINOIS HOUSINGUNITS HAVE LEAD-BASED PAINT, AND OF THOSE 72 PERCENT HAVE SIGNIFICANT LEAD HAZARDS. LEAD RISK EVALUATION IS CONDUCTED USING THE ILLINOISCHILDHOOD LEAD RISK QUESTIONNAIRE TO DETERMINE POTENTIAL LEAD EXPOSURE HAZARDS. ONE QUESTION PERTAINS TO THE HIGH-RISK GEOGRAPHICAREA. ILLINOIS HAS DESIGNATED HIGH RISK ZIP CODES BASED ON A VARIETY OF CONSIDERATIONS, INCLUDING HOUSING AGE AND POVERTY RATES. WEPROVIDE FUNDING THROUGH GRANT AGREEMENTS WITH MANY OF OUR LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENTS TO CONDUCT CASE MANAGEMENT ANDENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES. IN ADDITION, WE PROVIDE TRAINING FOR THESE AGENCIES AND ONGOING REVIEWS AND GUIDANCE TO ENSURE SUCCESSFULOUTCOMES. FOR THOSE THAT CHOOSE NOT TO PARTICIPATE IN THE GRANT, IDPH EMPLOYS ITS OWN CASE MANAGERS AND RISK ASSESSORS WHOPERFORM THE REQUIRED HEALTH INTERVENTION IN THOSE AREAS. ILLINOIS MAINTAINS DATA IN HHLPSS TO TRACK BLOOD LEAD TEST RESULTS AND ENSUREFOLLOW-UP FOR CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS. ADDITIONALLY, WE PROVIDE REFERRALS AND LINKAGES TO SUPPORTIVE HEALTH ANDEDUCATIONAL SERVICES. WE WORK CLOSELY WITH MANY PARTNERS TO ASSIST IN OUR EFFORTS, INCLUDING: IMMUNIZATION PROGRAM, VITAL RECORDS,MINORITY HEALTH SERVICES REFUGEE HEALTH, PLUMBING AND WATER QUALITY PROGRAM, DHS, WIC, IEPA, AND ATSDR.IN ADDITION TO PROVIDING THESE SERVICES, WE PLAN TO ROLL OUT A STATEWIDE PR CAMPAIGN TO BRING AWARENESS TO THE EFFECTS OF LEADEXPOSURE AND THE IMPORTANCE OF LEAD RISK EVALUATION AND TESTING.THERE IS NO SAFE LEVEL OF LEAD IN THE BODY. ILLINOIS CONTINUES TO COLLABORATE WITH LOCAL AGENCIES, FEDERAL, STATE AND LOCAL PARTNERS TOELIMINATE THE INCIDENCE OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING. OUR VISION IS TO PROVIDE A LEAD-SAFE ENVIRONMENT FOR ALL CHILDREN.

LOS ANGELES COUNTY?S PATHWAY FOR AT-RISK COMMUNITIES TO BECOME SAFER, EDUCATED, AND EMPOWERED THROUGH THE PROMOTION OF LEAD POISONING PRIMARY PREVENTION INITIATIVES FOR A LEAD HAZARD FREE ENVIRONMENT. - ?LOS ANGELES COUNTY?S PATHWAY FOR AT-RISK COMMUNITIES TO BECOME SAFER, EDUCATED, AND EMPOWERED THROUGH THE PROMOTION OF LEAD POISONING PRIMARY PREVENTION INITIATIVES FOR A LEAD HAZARD FREE ENVIRONMENT? PROJECT WILL BUILD ON LOS ANGELES COUNTY DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH?S LEAD FREE HOMES LA (LFHLA) COUNTYWIDE ABATEMENT PROGRAM BY INTRODUCING A VARIETY OF PRIMARY PREVENTION STRATEGIES INTO AND ON TOP OF EXISTING AND PLANNED OUTREACH AND ENROLLMENT ACTIVITIES. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO: (1) EDUCATE THE COUNTY?S ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH (EH) INSPECTOR WORKFORCE ON THE EFFECTS OF LEAD POISONING, LEAD HAZARDS THAT CAN BE CITED AS HOUSING VIOLATIONS, AND IDENTIFYING AND ENFORCING LEAD SAFE WORK PRACTICES; (2) INCREASE COMMUNITY IMPACT ON LFHLA OUTREACH AND ENROLLMENT INITIATIVES BY BRINGING COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND OTHER KEY STAKEHOLDERS INTO THE OUTREACH AND ENROLLMENT DESIGN, PLANNING, AND EXECUTION; (3) DEVELOP LFHLA?S COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT WORKFORCE BY FORMALIZING ENGAGEMENT BEST PRACTICES; (4) ENHANCE THE CULTURAL COMPETENCY OF OUTREACH MATERIALS AND INCREASE THE NUMBER OF LANGUAGES THE MATERIALS ARE AVAILABLE IN TO SUPPORT TARGETED OUTREACH; (5) IDENTIFY, DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT NEW OUTREACH APPROACHES AND MESSAGES TO ENGAGE PREVIOUSLY UNCONTACTED PROPERTY OWNERSHIP TYPES; (6) UTILIZE A COMMUNITY-BASED APPROACH TO CONDUCT TARGETED PRIMARY PREVENTION INTERVENTIONS TO EDUCATE THE MOST AT-RISK FAMILIES ABOUT LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND OTHER AVAILABLE HEALTH AND HOUSING SERVICES; AND (7) BUILD AND FOSTER STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS TO INCREASE ACCESS TO BLOOD LEAD TESTING ACROSS THE LFHLA TARGET AREAS.

CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION PROGRAM - CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING PREVENTION AND SURVEILLANCE OF BLOOD LEAD LEVELS IN CHILDRENCDC-RFA-EH21-2102KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTPROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYTHE MOST COMMON SOURCE FOR LEAD EXPOSURE IN KANSAS?S CHILDREN IS LEAD-BASED PAINT IN OLDER HOUSING. STATEWIDE, 28.4% OF HOMES WERE BUILT BEFORE 1950 AND 44.0% WERE BUILT BETWEEN 1950 AND 1979.  IN THREE MAJOR COUNTIES, SEDGWICK (21.0% AND 47.2% RESPECTIVELY), SHAWNEE (23.5% AND 51.5% RESPECTIVELY), AND WYANDOTTE (50.6% AND 34.7% RESPECTIVELY), THE PERCENTAGE OF HOUSING LIKELY TO CONTAIN LEAD-BASED PAINT IS SIMILARLY HIGH. KANSAS HAS AREAS WITH HISTORICAL LEAD CONTAMINATION FROM INDUSTRY AND MINING ACTIVITIES, AS WELL AS CURRENT INDUSTRIES WITH THE POTENTIAL FOR ADULTS TO BRING LEAD CONTAMINATION INTO THE HOME. THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN UNDER AGE 6 YEARS THAT WERE TESTED FOR BLOOD LEAD PEAKED IN 2011 WITH 34,621 INDIVIDUAL CHILDREN TESTED. ACCORDING TO DATA SUBMITTED TO THE CDC, 28,079 CHILDREN WERE TESTED IN 2019.  ACCORDING TO THE INTERCENSAL POPULATION ESTIMATES, THE POPULATION OF 0 TO < 6 AGED CHILDREN IN KANSAS HAS DECREASED BY ABOUT 11,000 FROM 2014 TO 2018. WHEN CONTRASTING TWO YEARS, STATEWIDE THERE WERE 406 CHILDREN IN 2014 AND 472 CHILDREN IN 2019, AND 243 CHILDREN IN 2020 BETWEEN 0 AND LESS THAN 6 YEARS WITH CONFIRMED LEVELS OF 5 UG/DL AND GREATER. THE HIGHER POPULATED COUNTIES OF SEDGWICK, SHAWNEE, AND WYANDOTTE HAD 162 CASES (39.9%) IN 2014 AND 161 CASES (34.1%) IN 2019 BETWEEN THEM.  TWO ADDITIONAL COUNTIES, MONTGOMERY WITH COUNTY-WIDE ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINATION FROM AN OLD ZINC SMELTING SITE AND SALINE WITH A MAJOR BATTERY MANUFACTURING PLANT WITH HISTORICAL VIOLATIONS FOR THE NATIONAL AMBIENT AIR QUALITY STANDARD FOR LEAD, HAD AN ADDITIONAL 26 CASES (6.4%) IN 2014 AND 43 CASES (9.3%) IN 2019 BETWEEN THEM.  OVER THE PAST 15 YEARS, TYPICALLY LESS THAN 15% OF CHILDREN ARE SCREENED FOR BLOOD LEAD EACH YEAR LEAVING MUCH UNKNOWN ABOUT THE TRUE BURDEN OF BLOOD LEAD POISO NING IN THE STATE. THE PERCENT OF MEDICAID ENROLLED CHILDREN UNDER 6 YEARS OF AGE THAT HAVE BEEN TESTED FOR BLOOD LEAD WAS HIGHEST IN 2011 AT APPROXIMATELY 17.4% AND WAS NOT TRACKED FOR SURVEILLANCE PURPOSES AGAIN UNTIL FUNDING RESUMED IN 2018. THE PERCENT OF MEDICAID ENROLLED CHILDREN UNDER 6 YEARS OF AGE THAT HAVE BEEN TESTED FOR BLOOD LEAD HAS STEADILY DECLINED TO 13.9% IN 2019. STRATEGIES AND ACTIVITIES ARE OUTLINED IN THE APPLICATION TO FURTHER EVALUATE BARRIERS ASSOCIATED WITH TESTING AND IMPLEMENT A PLAN TO ADDRESS THE MOST COMMONLY CITED ISSUES TO INCREASE TESTING RATES AMONG AT-RISK CHILDREN STATEWIDE.   FUNDING FROM THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WOULD BE USED TO SUPPORT THE 3 MAIN CORE COMPONENTS OUTLINED IN THE NOTICE OF FUNDING OPPORTUNITY WHICH ARE; ENSURING BLOOD LEAD TESTING AND REPORTING, ENHANCING BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE, AND IMPROVING LINKAGES OF LEAD-EXPOSED CHILDREN TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES. THE OVERALL PURPOSE OF THE PROGRAM IS TO REDUCE CHILDHOOD LEAD EXPOSURE AND POISONING IN KANSAS THROUGH SECONDARY PREVENTION STRATEGIES AND ACTIVITIES. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY INCREASING THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN LESS THAN 6 YEARS OLD TESTED FOR BLOOD LEAD, CONDUCTING BLOOD LEAD SURVEILLANCE TO IDENTIFY CHILDREN WITH ELEVATED BLOOD LEAD LEVELS, IMPROVED DATA LINKAGE AND DATA USAGE BETWEEN PARTNERS, AND INCREASING IDENTIFICATION OF LEAD EXPOSED CHILDREN LINKED TO RECOMMENDED SERVICES.
